description:
This was three stars until we ordered dessert. The chocolate custard earned them a fourth star after a mediocre meal. 

The space is super cute and right next to sightglass coffee and Trick Dog bar (both of which share a bathroom with Central Kitchen). Very open and airy. Only have beer and wine. At first sight, the menu looks super fresh and exciting and it was difficult for us to choose what we wanted. We settled on:

- an order of fry bread (YUM, but $$)
- the avocado and tomatoe salad (pretty good, the lime zest elevated it above basic)
- summer squash salad (extremely lacking in flavor and seasoning)
- mashed potatoes with chicken cracklings (watery and underwhelming)
- braised lamb (super tender and flavorful, would come back for).
- the chocolate custard with coffee ice cream and chocolate cookie crumble (amazing, totally worth it)

The food wasn't too bad for the price and the reputation, I was expecting better. My friend and I agreed, there are more places in the city we'd want to try before coming back here.
author: Anna Lai M.

description:
We had a reservation and came here for dinner on a Friday evening. We started with the fry bread and added in the burrata and roasted garlic. We also had some sort of charcuterie-type meat (can't remember what it was called) that was delicious. The fry bread was the highlight of the meal, though. Absolutely delicious, warm and seemed as if it just came out of the oven. 

The heirloom tomato and avocado salad was good, but nothing overly impressive. It was exactly what it said it was, not an overly inventive dish. We also had the rotating pasta dish, which as the time were little mini raviolis cooked in some kind of butter-based sauce. Absolutely delicious, a little overly expensive for what you get but still a delightful dish. We also ordered a half roasted chicken since that seemed to be one of the staples on the side. The chicken was a tad dry in some places but very moist in others, there were a ton of small bones that made it hard to eat and left a mess trying to do so. The whipped potato was the only side dish that we ordered and was good, but I'm not a huge fan of anything smoked so I tried to avoid the butter portion.

Honestly, even after eating all of this, the fry bread was still the highlight so we skipped desert and opted for another order of that again. The service was good, they didn't seem to come by as often as I would've liked and completely forgot my friend's beer until we mentioned it about 80% of the way into the meal. It's a really cute restaurant, just not sure that it warrants a second trip.
author: Katie Y.

description:
At first, I was hesitant because of the 3.5 star rating. But don't let that deter you. This was one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco! Everything was outstanding from the food to service. 

Stand outs were the Frye bread, beef tartare and the octopus. Octopus was super tender and some of the best I've ever had. The roasted chicken was also great. Definitely recommend this place to anyone considering it! 

We also brought our own wine. Heads up, it is a $25 corkage fee. Enjoy!
author: Mehul S.

description:
I'm surprised this is my first review for central kitchen. I had come here for my birthday a long time ago, maybe 3 years? And loveeeed it! So to come back again for the first time in a while, I was nervous I would be disappointed. I can assure you, I was NOT. I've gone to a TON of really nice dinners/restaurant a and this place is still my favorite. We always do the 'let the kitchen decide' and never disappoints. You can check my pics with what we got and loved almost all of it. The only two items that were meh were the Brussels sprouts and mashed potatoes or whatever they were. Everything else was ahhhh-mazing. 

We also brought our own wine. Corkage fee was $25. Based on previous reviews, seems like it increased from the $20 I read prior. 

Hopefully won't be another 3 years till I go back
author: Katlyn H.

description: This was such a cute restaurant! We loved everything, starting with the frybread, maybe flybread. My husband and I are still going back and forth since we can't remember what it was called. Anyways, this delicious thing was like a fluffy, perfectly salted beignet and we got it with a side of burrata. SO good. We also ordered the squid ink pasta, eggplant, and grilled octopus. They were all equally delicious.. Finished the meal with the chocolate pudding. Needless to say, we'll be back to try other dishes on the menu as I believe it changes daily..
author: Kim I.

description: Two stars because the food is good, but nothing explains the incredibly inattentive service in an almost empty restaurant, even if they provide a free appetizer after having us wait our dinner for over half hour. Plus it is expensive.
author: Eirini P.

description:
We always have a great dinner here! My foodie friend, who I've been bringing to all my favorite SF restaurants, was definitely impressed. 

THE COST: $188.57 for 3 drinks, 3 starters, 3 entrees, and 2 desserts (dinner for 3). A reasonable cost for such a nice meal!

THE SERVICE: Always great. Our entrees were taking a little long, barely in any noticeable way, and our server brought us out a few jars of pickled veggies and pita chips! We hadn't complained or made any indication our food was coming out slowly. This was a really nice gesture.

LARDER
* Smoked Trout Rillette ($14) - 3.5 stars
Good, but not super memorable.

* Beef Tartare ($13) - 4.5 stars
Excellent soft, flavorful meat, on fantastic bread!

VEGETABLES
* Beet & persimmon ($13) - 4 stars
Super soft, fresh beets. Great dish just for the quality of the ingredients. 

* Cauliflower & Broccoli di Cicco ($14) - 4 stars
Lovely!

PASTA
* Fennel Pollen & Nutmeg Tagliatelle ($22) - 4.5 stars
Their pasta is always amazing, this was a fantastic savory option.

* Autumn Squash Tortelloni ($19) - 4 stars
A great sweet counter to the tagliatelle, love the autumn flavors!

FROM THE HEARTH
* Duck Breast ($29) - 4 stars
Excellent soft meat, great flavors & textures

DESSERT
* Chocolate Custard ($10) - 4 stars
Always a solid choice! The savory hints, crumble, and smooth ice cream make this great.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I was impressed. Ordering vegetarian I was a little nervous but the chef made it work. Beet & persimmon dish (sans yogurt) was amazing. The celery root caramelle pasta was super buttery but delicious. Mushroom and Sunchoke was my favorite- it was unique and a perfect balance of savory with a kick of sweet. 
Service was also great.
author: Rob M.

description: My friends took me out here for my birthday a couple of weeks ago. It was a Friday night, but we made a reservation, so I can't speak for wait times, but at around 8:30, there didn't seem to be too much of a line! We ordered a couple of appetizers to start -get the Brussels sprouts! I think they were hands down the favorite for everyone. Then we all ordered a main dish- we somehow managed to order one of every pasta. I got the mezzaluna but I tried all of them, and I think my favorite was actually the beef raviolini. The pasta was fresh, but portions were small! I wasn't hungry when the meal ended, but I could have eaten more, which for the price, I would have also wanted more. However, the pasta was truly fantastic!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Despite some less than stellar reviews from some of my go-to yelpers, I decided to go and try Central Kitchen out myself.  Armed with an Opentable $50 gift certificate, fruits of making reservations with them, we were lucky to find a parking place that was barely legal after circling around for 10-15 minutes.  Those who say there's plenty of street parking are using alternate facts.  There's almost no parking!  When we entered, I liked the feel of it immediately.  I bet when it's sunny that skylight really lights up the room.  It reminded me a little of Foreign Cinema.  Our waiter was friendly and professional in just the right ratio, but what's with all the secrecy about what will be served on the well priced "Let the Kitchen Decide"  menu?  I've been seeing this a lot lately.  Are they afraid if you know what you'll be served, you'll try to make changes, or what?  I asked our server, and he said he didn't know, but, if I wanted him to he could go back to the kitchen and ask. Just too coy, unless they change it up throughout the night based on what they want to unload from the kitchen.  We opted out and dined instead on:

Chicory Salad with asian pear, mandarin, chevre and spiced nuts $13.  3.5 stars- I thought this paired some rather disparate things, but it tasted good, and the bitterness of the chicory did a good job of offsetting the fruit.  The chevre pieces were just way too big though.

Cauliflower and Romanesco - with soft boiled egg, duck salami,  bagna cauda $14. 4 stars-  I was caught off guard with this being served cold.  I guess just the bagna was cauda, because the rest was not warm at all and the egg especially would have been better warmer, but there was a lovely nuttiness to the flavor, and it was visually stunning

Bacon Wrapped Rabbit - braised leg, lentils, onion and golden raisins $29. 3.5 stars.  I'm torn on this.  It was in fact a roulade, with a rabbit forcemeat wrapped in bacon set on a bed of the other ingredients.  It was tender and flavorful, but not at all as described, and rather a small portion for that price point

Black Pepper and Mushroom Agnolotti -beef brisket, spring onions and potato $20. 4 stars - This was probably the best dish we had, albeit a rather small portion for the price.  Very rich, it was a deeply flavored filling and toothsome pasta.

Some suggestions:
1. Get someone to rewrite the item descriptions to match what they are actually serving
2. Edit ingredients on some of the items.  More doesn't necessarily mean better.
3. Valet parking would make people less cranky

Food:  30:40
Service:  17/20
Atmosphere/Intangibles: 18/20
Value:  15/20
Overall:  80/100
Barely makes it in to the 4 star category
author: Diane B.

description:
Central Kitchen is owned by the same people as flour+water. I'm going to be very controversial here and say flour+water is WAY overrated, and Central Kitchen is so much better in all respects. Seriously.

I was able to get a reservation for a celebratory dinner just a few days before for a Saturday night at 6 PM. The staff is just so lovely - answered all our questions promptly, gave great recommendations, etc. I also love the high ceilings and the natural lighting, which made the space seem very open and airy.

Come with people who like to share food (no Joey Tribbiani), as everything is meant to be shared. My friend and I shared a salad, bread, a small vegetable dish (charred asparagus), 2 pastas, and we were STUFFED. The menu is seasonal, so go off the staff's recommendations. The salad was seriously the best I've ever had in my life (walnuts, goat cheese, bacon, gem lettuce, edible flowers - nothing crazy) and I eat a lot of salad. It was just so thoughtfully put together. The pasta (green garlic rigatoni and pappardelle with pork belly) was incredible. Blew flour+water... out of the water. 

This is going to be my go-to spot from now on for any last-minute dinners without a wait. Can't wait to come back!
author: Denise L.

description:
Loved the ambience, food and service at Central Kitchen. As a vegetarian I was happy to see many options. I had the lemon and snow pea mezzaluna pasta which was perfectly cooked. The lemon was also a refreshing change from the standard marinara/alfredo/pesto sauces. For dessert I had the chocolate pudding which was a tad on the sweeter side. I wish they had more options for dessert. The only other choices were ice cream or sorbet.
Overall it's a great place for a date night, I especially liked the pretty fairy lights they've used everywhere.
author: Shree K.

description:
Vibe and atmosphere, +1 star.
Fantastic service, +1 star.
Food quality, flavor ambition, paper weight/typography of menus, +1 star.

Unfortunately, that's as much as I can say to it. In my mind I have a notion of how many dollars worth of calories will satiate both my stomach and my brain, but Central Kitchen only went 3/5 of the way there for me. When eating, you want quality and quantity--Central Kitchen absolutely delivers in the quality aspect, but I was left longing for more of a quantity aspect.

Everything here is shared. I know this because it is in ALL CAPS in the top right of their menu.

That said, the opportunity to explore different flavor profiles and presentations was the best part of my Central Kitchen experience.

Squid corzetti? Taste-bud-opening.

Cheese Ricotta? Dream-pervading.

WHIPPED potatoes? I'm done. (No but actually, this was one of the most interesting dishes I experienced, even though it was an extremely simple profile. I had no idea that potatoes could be served with this consistency and intensity. Perhaps juxtaposing it with our Melons & Cucumber dish amplified its savoriness. Or maybe its crunchy Chicken side was what topped off the experience for me. Honestly, it was just great, to put it succinctly.)

But I was overall left wanting more--not quite flavor-wise, but actual calories. We went to a different restaurant afterwards to fulfill the remaining 2 stars worth of calories that were remaining from our stomachs from a 5-star night.
author: Nick C.

description:
Average is a fair one word description to summarize the overall experience.

We had reservations for a party of five for dinner, and we arrived a little earlier and enjoyed drinks at the bar (Trick Dog) next door. We were seated on time. It was dimly lit, almost too dark. We were in a corner making it a little cramped, but it wasn't unbearable. The atmosphere was nice, and the aesthetics make it look like a very hip  and trendy restaurant.

Our table ordered most of the pasta menu, the whipped potato, a few drinks, and dessert. The portions were very small for the price. We were given complimentary sourdough bread with cultured butter. I had the green garlic campanelle, which was too oily for my taste. I was not a fan of it.  I ended up switching my dish with my boyfriend, who got the bucatini. That dish was a handful of flavors, but I wouldn't eat it again. We both preferred each other's orders over our own and agreed our entrees were okay. The whipped potato, however, was delicious after adding our leftover butter in it. I would recommend it. I didn't order a drink, but the table seemed content with theirs.  For dessert we got the chocolate custard and sorbet and was the better part of the meal. The chocolate custard was good, but it wasn't mind blowing amazing or a must order again. 

As for the service... Our waitress was very nice and prompt. After ordering and receiving our drinks, she asked if we were ready to order entrees. We had one person at the table who needed a couple more minutes to decide, and she said she would be back. She did not come back until 15 minutes later. After flagging her down to take our orders, we did not see her again and were helped by another waiter. There was no check up during our entrees, but he was nice and engaging when we ordered dessert. At the end when the check was paid and signed, we saw our original waitress again just to pick up the check.

I found myself trying to balance out the underwhelming elements with the decent elements throughout the dinner. There was no memorable or wow factor that would make me want to try it again. This review is from a perspective of someone out of town.
author: Kate P.

description:
This place is popular for amazingly incredible, unique food cooked with fresh ingredients, a beautiful presentation , and lots of love and inspiration   Everything I tried melted on my tongue.   The taste was superbly flavorful and savory.  What I love here was the colorful presentation on each dish. The pasta dish was totally the bomb.  Each dish was simple but with intense flavors. 

The service was outstanding. Our waiter was polite, friendly, and super hard working.  The portion was huge.  The food was rich so I got filled up quickly.  Luckily, the delicate and delightful meal was perfectly paired with wines.  

Central Kitchen is lovely with  beautiful light, comfortable seating and cute decor. Love the dining atmosphere here, very warm ambiance.  Highly recommended. Everything on the menu is absolutely mouthwatering and worth waiting for.  YummmmY!

Tip:   Tough to get seating without a reservation.   So RSVP early!
author: Ivory B.

description:
I went there last night on a Friday.  It was a very fun, energetic vibe.  Beautiful setting.  We got to sit near the open wood fire grill which was really interesting if you like to see how the food is prepared. 

They were able to accommodate for my friend who is vegan and allergic to nuts which I wish I could give them an extra star for.

We started by getting 5 salads & the amaaaazing fermented veggies.  All were beautifully presented and very delicious.  The Yuba salad was our favorite of the salads (we got 2) but the charred asparagus, seared blood oranges, cured asparagus, beets, fermented sunchokes, pickles were all close seconds mmm...  Other notable dishes were the polenta my vegan friend had & the pork cheeks another friend had.  He actually said he'd never had meat that tender fall off the bone like that.  

The desserts were amazing too.   

We ate most everything too fast for pictures but here are the only two I have.

PS.  Get the bread and butter and olive oil.   Totally worth it.
author: A K.

description:
Service was ~1
Food 4

First I must give a shout out to the server with a black long sleeve top on and blonde pigtails who did not give a damn at all about acknowledging her table at all. We asked her opinion about doing the taste and I don't know if she could have been any colder or disinterested, but then she was totally rude by ignoring us and then other servers just picked up. As she walked around. We came on 12/8/17

5/5 mushroom and sun choke salad WOW I can't even describe how wonderful and expected this was, I didn't recognize a lot of the flavors but just was so intrigued and wanted more. 

Crab and tortellini pasta 4/5 the lemon came through well 

5/5 brown butter sage and pumpkin pasta AMAZING so rich, perfectly sweet and savory 

2/5 short rib just had no flavor at all! Really disappointing on this dish. And it was a bit tough.
author: Morgan S.

description:
This place is probably one of the best places I've been in SF. It just has really clean-tasting quality food. 

My favorite dish was the heirloom tomato salad, which had chunks of bread, a generous amount of olive oil, burrata, and sizeable chunks of multicolored tomatoes. I still have dreams about this dish, it was so good. These tomatoes had a sweetness I've never encountered before in a tomato, and were just bursting with flavor. And I have no idea who thought of putting bread in there, but good on them, because it was just an amazing mish mash of textures. I know it sounds like I'm exaggerating, but this was probably one of my favorite dishes I've had ever.

The short rib was also really tender and flavorful. They just perfected what short rib should be. I could cut it with a fork, but it just melted in my mouth and still had enough fat within the meat to create that melting feel. It was awesome.

And the chocolate custard. Wow. This thing was so packed with coffee and chocolate flavor that it was unbelievable. I'm not huge on dessert, but they really knocked it out of the park on this one.

Pretty much everything I had here was absolutely amazing. If you're going to splurge a bit and want to try some quality flavorful food, I think this is definitely a place to try.
author: Eric Y.

description: We ordered the chefs picks and wow they were delicious. Our favorites were the chocolate custard, fried bread with burrata, and pasta with corn. The wines are great too nomnom.
author: Lisa A.

description: I went here for the first time for a first date. A good place for first impression with the restaurant's nice aesthetic, delicious foods and good suggestions for wine pairings. Staffs were helpful and friendly, portions run smaller than normal American standard but it was good quality. I would go back here to take my friends and family.
author: Wendy N.

description:
I've been slowing easing into the Mission. Being here for 3 years now, The Mission is one neighborhood I've been meaning to spend more time in so when an opportunity came up to have dinner at this joint, I quickly jumped on it. 

Situated by a pretty popular and colorful bar, Central Kitchen is truly an oasis on his own. When you enter pass the gates, you'll notice a big pile of wood to the left and stringing lights leading you to the door. Inside is a beautiful ambiance! Sky lighting, hanging lights, a water feather, lots of plants, as if you were out on someone's porch or an outside meditation area. So cute!! 

Our server was fantastic! I forgot his name unfortunately but he was so accommodating, he was quick, checked up on us often and was playful enough to make us feel welcomed. I really enjoyed the staff of the joint, thought that really help create the experience. For dinner, here's what we had: 

-From the Larder menu, we chose the Beef Tartare for $12. The tartare was served on grilled sourdough with parmigiano and chili. There was a lot going on in the tartare, full of flavor and texture. Soooooo good! This was one of my favorite dishes of the evening. I REALLY liked that they cut the bread up before putting the tartare on so you could share the dish. Very thoughtful. 

-From the Vegetables menu, we chose the Little Gems salad for $13. This was a HUGE salad served with green goddess mix of romaine, beautifully sliced radishes, fine herbs like dill and mint and almonds. The dressing had a slight sour taste like a vinaigrette flavor which accentuate the herbs and greens. It was a light bite since shared amongst me and my friend. 

-Along with our main dish, we also got the seared asparagus for $11 from the vegetables menu. OH EM GEE, you don't expect asparagus to be this good! Nicely seared over some yogurt, tahini and served with green strawberries and something called a za'atar spice with sesame seeds. Nice balance of salty and sweet, asparagus is cut up into small pieces. This was a GREAT side options for our meal and I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS. 

-The star of the show, for dinner we both shared the 24oz bone in Ribeye from the Large Plates menu for $72. Sticker shock at first, I know, but SOOOO WORTH IT! The steak comes medium rare, perfect. The dish was served with roasted garlic, grilled lemon, sea salt and au jus on the side and chili. On top the steak, they sprinkled some chicharron. WOW, what a dish!! The steak was perfectly cooked, and sliced nicely to share. The chicharron was homemade and spiced nicely, loved the roasted garlic, soooo spreadable for the steak. Everything was perfect. You need to try this dish!! 

-We got a lot of food but you ALWAYS have room for dessert so we got the Chocolate Custard for $9. Served in a mason jar, you start with the custard, then topped with candied almonds, chocolate crumbs and coffee ice cream. It was a great way to end the evening. Not too heavy, just a nice few bites of chocolate and coffee. 

As you can see, I had an amazing time here. From the ambiance details to the service, to the amazing food. This place did not disappoint. I can't wait to return with other friends so I can show them what a great place this is. If you're in the area, you need to make reservations and come by to check them out. You will not be disappointed!!
author: Rockne H.

description: Central Kitchen uses a wonderful space with the "classic" SF/City feel of an urban restaurant. Exposed ceilings, interesting and cool fixtures (fountain, vines, etc.), friendly and competent wait-staff and an open kitchen drive the intense satisfaction I felt when leaving. It was a great experience. I didn't even spend more than 10 seconds contemplating the bill when it came, though in retrospect it was quite an expensive evening. Well worth it.
author: Jasper L.

description:
Maybe I came first thing for brunch when the place wasn't busy or crowded, but I had a pleasant experience here. The fried chicken benedict was delicious, drinks like the Baker Beach (cactus pear, blackberry, bubbly wine) and Bodega Bay (death & taxes black lager, coffee ice cream) quite good, and the service pretty friendly. The open-air feel of the whole venue, which lets in lots of light, is also a perfect setting for brunch. 

Will definitely try again for dinner.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Delicious cocktails. Wonderful beef tartare. 
Very happy with my meal at Central Kitchen. 
Secure a reservation online before you go.
author: Opal D.

description: We had trout rilette, heirloom tomato and avocado salad, cucumber melon salad, a smoked eggplant dish, a fresh pasta dish with mini pork meatballs, one more vegetable thing I'm forgetting, and the chocolate custard for dessert.  Everything was delicious and plating was a work of art. Ingredients were fresh, thoughtfully sourced and cooked/prepared perfectly. Further, the atmosphere, IMHO, is PERFECT for a date or out with a group of friends. I loved the lighting and the ambiance. Service was just right. Prices felt reasonable for SF farm-to-table fare that I guess I would categorize as talented chefs showing off their skills for highlighting the best seasonal flavors - is that still called California cuisine? I'll be back for sure.
author: Sara S.

description:
The service at this place is disorganized, untimely and inattentive.  The food arrived before the drinks, I asked for a taste of wine and had to flag down the waitress to check in and see if I wanted more tastes or a glass. No check in about the dishes either.  

The space is something between casual barn or backyard but it's very loud. I like the vibe and on a warm day would be great to have the fresh air and light. 

The food:
Smoked Salmon rillettes: very yummy, great flavor, light, salmon was fresh and salty enough but not fishy, the other ingredients added a lightness and bright flavors.

Avocado and mushroom salad: yummy! A very surprising combo, quinoa chips added a crunch, dressing was spot on. A unique dish that I've never had before. It's great for sharing and feels hearty. 

The papardel was thick and tough, watery sauce and not much duck. This did not impress, it just felt heavy. The flavors were bland.

The autumn squash tortellini was great flavor, nicely balanced, the pasta was a bit thick and not tender, but I'm just picky and not a fan of al dente.
author: Inga W.

description:
I hosted a few people for dinner in their private dining area and j thought that the food was very good. Service was also good but we didn't feel like it was worth what we spent there. All the pastas were great me so was the fish. The salads were also really good and everyone really liked all the food. 

The chef sent a couple of pastas on the house to our party which was a great gesture. Our server wasn't very attentive and it almost felt like they were just there because they had to be there as the tip had already been agreed to as part of a party size greater than 6.
author: Rohan D.

description: We ended up here after we got to Flour + Water too late to walk in. What a great find! The room is large and spacious and full of light. Service was friendly and down-to-earth, and our server could thoroughly describe every dish we had a question about. The concept is shareable plates of various sizes, including three large entrees (chicken, steak, pork chop). Our group of four ordered a halibut crudo, two salads, two vegetables, a pasta, and one large entree (a half-chicken) and it was plenty of food. and...delicious! each dish was very different from the others and the portions were just the right amount to share among four people. We had two desserts which were simple and also very yummy. I would come back here in a minute (but would also like another shot at Flour + Water :-)
author: Carol G.

description: Went on Wednesday night. The two of us got the beet salad, beef cheeks, 2 pastas (pork belly pappardelle and beef raviolini) and the chocolate mousse dessert. The portions were on the smaller side, but we were able to try two different pastas so that was ok. The pastas were definitely the highlights of the meal. Super light and yummy. Perfectly al dente. The yelp rating does not do this place justice! One star off because it was freezing inside. I had to wear my jacket the whole time.
author: Tina G.

description:
Thomas McNaughton is slowly taking over the Mission like Thomas Keller has taken over Yountville. 

Ok, that comparison might be a bit unfair to Keller who's a GOD as we all yelpers know. 

But one thing is for sure, Central Kitchen 2.0 is better than before. 

A hearth oven can be seen as soon as you walk into this lively setting of a restaurant. I LOVE LOVE LOVE the natural light that fills their space! We came for brunch and there were plenty of seats available. Brunch is pretty casual here: seat yourself, grab your own utensils and water, order at Salumeria next door and they'll deliver it to your table. Phew! eliminates the whole waiting game and no need to really tip 20%! (unless they really kissed your butt!) 

I kept it light and healthy with a chopped salad of radicchio, romaine, peas, olive, provolone, pepperoncini, salumi, cucumbers tossed with a red wine vinaigrette. Classic and easy on the dressing, but not easy on the parmesan cheese! do you see the MOUND of queso piled on top of my greens?! heaven! I enjoyed my iced tea too. 

I did manage to take a bite out of my friend's fried chicken sandwich! OMG. Why the hell did I get a salad? 0_o  this fried chicken sammich is perfect in all accounts. Crispy, juicy, flavorful with a spicy aioli and a soft bun. You get some house made pickles on the side. The only thing wrong with this sandwich is the $14 price and it doesn't come with fries nor a salad which is a minor let down, really. 

I'll definitely be back to enjoy more of Central Kitchen's offerings. Pasta, sandwiches and maybe I'll even get a sighting of the cutie chef.
author: Janice C.

description:
I came in with very high standards since this is Flour and Water's sister restaurant, the latter being of my favorite restaurants of all time. The restaurant is located in a nice area of the Mission that is within walking proximity to Alamo Cinema, so it's a great place to grab dinner before watching a movie. Décor and ambiance were great, but the food was just ok compared to Flour and Water. However, it definitely is easier getting a reservation at Central Kitchen, so it's a place worth checking out if you're in the area.

[Dinner]
I went with a friend who was vegetarian, so the restaurant has great options for that and we ended up splitting everything family style. My favorite dish was the mushroom and avocado dish, followed by the fry bread, charred summer squash, and finally the vegetarian tomato and ricotta tortelli dish. Even though the pasta comes from the same place, I had high expectations for this pasta dish, but all the pasta I've had at Flour and Water tasted better, so I was a tiny bit disappointed. They recommend two-three dishes per person if splitting family style, but we ordered fewer dishes and felt full after. 

[Drinks]
I had the Dolores Park cocktail. It was reasonable for the price and tasted great. 

[Service / Décor]
I really love the ambiance and wooden décor in the restaurant. It is dimly lit and the two-person tables are rather tight together, but I think overall its very cozy and enjoyable for dinner. The service was great and our server gave us some great recommendations.

I definitely would come back to Central Kitchen given its great location in the Mission to Alamo and the overall experience, so I would definitely at least giving this place a try if you can't get a lucrative reservation over at Flour + Water.
author: Alice Z.

description:
What a bad dining experience! We came with another couple and high hopes for a celebratory dinner. We specifically inquired ahead of time and were told that the various dietary restrictions in the party could be accommodated with no issue. 

When we arrived we were told that the chef did not feel comfortable giving us the chefs tasting and we would be limited to the items (basically none) on the menu. This would have been perfectly acceptable had we not specifically asked ahead of time! 

Service was mediocre at best. I asked for olive oil with our bread (which at $6 is already kinda pricey!). I had to ask multiple times before it was ever brought out. The server had a haughty attitude that was really off putting. 

The entree that was placed before me was a couple of spoonfuls of lentils with a few steamed cauliflower florets. Bland and incredibly disappointing. And $20+

Definitely will not be going back. Stick to flour + water and you'll fare much better!
author: Gowri R.

description: First of all, the atmosphere in this place rocks! Beautiful finishes, natural light, and fun to sit at the counter where we got seated right away with the 2 of us, no reservations. Overall, very classy service and food. I just object to some dishes being called "small plates" and some "entrees" yet both are served family style and portions are pretty small. We loved the tastes of everything ordered but again, just have to order a lot of dishes for $20 each to feel satisfied, which gets pricey.
author: Lisa P.

description: Loved it. Beautiful execution, fresh ingredients, perfect portioning. Can't remember all the dishes we had, they were all good. As were the aperitifs. To note, they do not have a full liquor license so stiffer drinks to be had next door at the adjoining bar. The space was elegant and much to my liking, likely one of my favorite interiors, elegant, feels feminine, light, slightly industrial, soft-modern. Highly recommended.
author: Juls C.

description: One of my favorite restaurant in the neighborhood! I don't understand how central kitchen and flour + water only have three stars. They serve quality food, with real, fresh products. High end , complex dishes that are just great and innovative. Totally changes from the typical American mediocre food that you get in most restaurants. Oh and the decoration inside is so pretty, and they also leave a note at the entrance with the playlist of the songs they're playing for the night. LOVE IT.
author: Constance P.

description:
So delicious and filling. This was a restaurant week menu where I was actually full (for days!) after.

The service was great, wine was unique, and loved all the starter plates to nosh on. Then came a pasta, and another pasta with lamb, which I thought was the protein course, but nope, a giant platter of chicken and sides came out after. Yum! 

I wish we could have chosen a smaller resto week menu, but I'll be back to eat again!
author: Victoria C.

description: Excellent bar food, classy venue, mannered and respectful bartenders and a solid beer selection.
author: Will D.

description: The housemade pastas here are top-notch, although rather small for the price.
author: Teresa D.

description:
Stellar food and service in a funky Mission District spot

Visited for a work event and thoroughly enjoyed this "hipsterestaurant." We had an upstairs dining area. Not sure what the main dining area looks like, but the staff described different spots in the complex of buildings. 

The cheeses, charcuterie, pates, and fry breads were yums. And the tasting menu was a blast-- braised beef, pumpkin and vegetable filled pastas, an escarole dish, and more. Not a ton of food, but the flavor and quality are impressive. Good stuff!

Dessert was an option of sorbet or a mousse with coffee ice cream in a mason jar. I picked the latter, dolloped off the ice cream, and really enjoyed the treat. 

Service was excellent all around. Everything was set, ambience was perfect for a group event. Drinks were rarely left empty and the crew was attentive. Most of us were even able to find parking without much issue. On an aside, there is interesting people watching of the residents across from restaurant windows. One can't help but notice a few life scenes as you eat. 

Definitely worth the visit for a special occasion...
author: Rob L.

description:
Lovely little place.  We really enjoyed the Veggie and Pasta dishes.  Though the Hearth item was delicious we found it was rather ordinary.

Veggie:
1. Mushroom & Avocado - really delightful!  Definitely a favorite.  The description didn't do it enough justice.  We considered this a signature Central Kitchen dish.  The favors were unique and memorable.  
2. Heirloom Tomatoes - another winner.  A perfect summer dish

Pasta
1. Tomato & Ricotta Tortelli - delicious and again perfect for summertime

Hearth
1. Grilled Salmon - fish was perfectly cooked and delicious but we found it boring compared to the other dishes.

Wine
Le Deplaude de Tartaras, Viognier Blend, Poussieres d'Etioles, Collines Rhodaniennes - yum yum yum!

Can't wait to return and try their other dishes
author: Lev E.

description: Went there for my birthday-perfect in every way-cool, spacious (very important) not overly noisy (even more important) space. Food was perfectly portioned, unique and tasty. Service was might fine too. It's rare for a place to just get it right, this place got it right.
author: Anne C.

description:
I frequently work with Central Kitchen regarding their private dining and have always received wonderful feedback from my clients.  They really enjoy the atmosphere for a private event (they turn Salumeria into a private dining space) and have said the food is excellent time and time again.  Their private dining team is awesome to work with and have helped me when I've been in a bind more than once.  

I have also eaten here personally for brunch and enjoyed their brunch options as well as the ambiance of dining in their main dining room.  I highly recommend Central Kitchen for an intimate private dinning experience as well as a casual weekend lunchtime spot.
author: Kelsey K.

description: First of all,​ we were pleasantly​​ surprised by the interior​ design ​of the restaurant. It looked very simple but elegant, almost minimalistic. The food was freshly prepared, maybe on the small portion side. If you are hungry, you probably need to order more than one dish. The custard pudding was the best sweet ending...
author: Michelle C.

description: One of our favorite places in sf. Very California fresh. The veggie dishes are fantastic. The pastas are as good as flour and water. Meats are great. The location itself is awesome especially on a warm night when they open the ceiling.
author: Adam S.

description: The food here is delicious!!! I love how the menu changes every week. The gem salad and duck breast were our favorite dishes of the night. We will definitely be coming back to try the tasting menu.
author: MARILYN C.

description: This is a really nice place for a date or small group! Lively but not too loud. Food options include some good meat-y pastas and seafood dishes. Nice wines.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I had a nice experience at Central Kitchen. The staff was very accommodating in meeting the needs of my fellow diners (there were a few vegetarians and some sugar/gluten/dairy free folks).

Their pasta comes from the main restaurant of this group, Flour + Water. I have to say, I enjoyed the stuffed pastas more than the regular (i.e. bucatini). 

The veggie appetizers (sunchoke + mushrooms, broccoli + cauliflower) were really delicious, along with the bread. The steak tartare was also tasty but felt heavier than other tartares I've had, somehow.
author: J. A.

description:
Portion sizes here are an astronomical joke, especially considering they're meant to be shared family style. That bit of food ain't satisfying any family I know! Servings would suffice as part of a multi-course tasting menu, but as stand-alone dishes, they'll have you calling the pizza delivery place you've got on speed-dial two hours later. 

Sparing Central Kitchen from a harsher review is their expertise in melding flavors:
-- I fell in love with the yin-yang of sweet fig & bitter mustard greens in the mushroom & fig salad ($13)
-- cauliflower & mushroom mezzaluna ($19) featured autumnal ingredients like apple and pine nuts and brown butter. Topped with a nice grating of salty cheese (parm?) & finished off with a squeeze of citrus, the flavors were definitely intense, however, I was dissatisfied with the pasta's extreme firmness
-- frozen berries with whipped creme fraiche & a sunflower poppy seed streusel ($9) was tart, a bit savory, & visually & texturally amusing. 

Their petite portions burst with big, satisfying flavor, but Central Kitchen is such a tease, I can't give them a 5th star until I see more on my plate. I've heard of leave them wanting more, but this is just torture!
author: Fancypants X.

description: Love this place! The menu is great, you can taste how much consideration goes into their plates. Everything tastes fresh and delicious. Truly recommended.
author: Fiorella B.

description:
They know how to make a drink but not how to poor it. First one was delicious but small so I asked for a drink with more volume- came out with a half full glass completely filled with ice
This is four SIPS in -
author: Francis C.

description:
Fantastic service. Lili was very helpful to guide our table in recommendations. We tried a number of menu items and we're pleased with all.

Great business casual ambience; adjacent meat/cheese/wine shop and a hopping bar next door.

Easy parking
author: Thomas B.

description:
This place is underrated. It was an absolutely fantastic experience. Food, decor, service, drinks - all amazing.

We went for dinner.

Starting:
Sourdough bread and butter - grr at having to pay for bread but, dang, that was awesome butter and some kind of magic, alfredo sauce-like, cheese spread. But seriously, don't charge for bread...

kabocha squash and apples - kabocha, aka japanese pumpkin, is king of squashes. It's good just about no matter what you do with it. That said, they could definitely do more with it. Raw kabocha chunks in a light sauce is like a random late night snack at my house. Roast it, grill it, dice it, something...

Arancini - totally amazing. Perfectly sized, perfectly cooked and seasoned, perfect basically.

Duck - delicious duck. Not like the absolute best ever but it was still fantastic. 

Wagyu Steak - wow. really really really good. Incredibly well prepared, perfectly seasoned, amazing cut of meat. The accompaniments were fantastic as well.

Also, they bent over backwards to make sure they knew about any food restrictions and that each item was in line with that. Really above and beyond.

Can't wait to go here again.
author: Ryan B.

description: Deeeefinitely coming back here. I love chef's table seating and their's is a little different because it is raised and faces over the dining area. It was fantastic! And the food was off the charts! Modern American cuisine. Ambience was stellar, felt classy and clean but not snobby, more classic. Like a West Elm photoshoot! Can't wait to come back here, it's just my kind of place.
author: Liza S.

description: The word "disappointment" would be too generous to describe our experience at Central Kitchen.  We had a 9:00 PM reservation just last Friday.  We weren't seated until 9:30 PM.  There was no reason in the order and timing of the courses.  The beets (from the beet and persimmon salad) were crunchy (in not a good way).  The mushrooms and sunchokes had an odd taste.  The beef tartare was underwhelming.   The black pepper beef and mushroom agnolotti was the tastiest thing we ordered.  The roasted carrots (which sounded like they would be flavorful due to the mole) were bland.  To add insult to injury, once we returned home from dinner, we were both violently sick.  Don't believe the hype, this restaurant isn't worth your time and expense.
author: Abbey G.

description: Excellent food! The tbd rose is amazing, and we split a few main courses among five people. I don't think the "let the kitchen chose" is worth it because we got to try so many options with just ordering a la Carte! The pasta is home made and I recommend the half chicken and Brussels sproutS!
author: Lauran K.

description:
Honestly cannot recommend this more. 
We did the tasting for two and were absolutely stuffed. Everything was incredible. Come hungry; I had a big lunch and by the time we got to the main and desert I could barely eat. 

Highlights:
Fry bread with burrata -- Amazing
Saffron pasta with nduja sausage and squid -- Quite possibly the best dish I have ever tasted. Such an amazing flavor profile-- spicy and rich. The handmade pasta was amazing. 
Curried pork chop -- I am mainly veg, so I'd actually never had a pork chop before. This was melt-in-your-mouth-delicious.
Chocolate custard with almonds, espresso cookie crumble and espresso ice cream -- one of my favorite desserts in SF. I had it last time I was at Central Kitchen, but this time could barely eat it since I was so full by that point. Still incredible. 

We got 11 items total, including little amuse bouche starters and sides. Like I said we left stuffed. Worth every dollar. Your taste buds will thank you. Do the tasting and then go back and order your favorites next time. 
Also should mention they were totally accommodating of my dietary preferences. I said no duck, no beef and no lamb, and they made it work.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Great food!  Service was great.  Get the squash, the ribs, the lemon bucatini, and the chocolate dessert.

You won't be disappointed.
author: Josh N.

description:
My girlfriends and I pick a new place to grab dinner once a month and I was super excited to try Central Kitchen. It's been raining nonstop in SF and we got lucky with a nice sunny night. They have a partially covered outdoor area with heaters that was the perfect place to sit. 

The food was to die for! There are a lot of vegetable dishes and every single one had the most amazing flavor. They change the menu here and there depending on what is fresh so the menu online might not match what they have when you go in. 

There was a large wine list with a lot of different price points. I'd recommend sharing everything so you can try a bunch of things. They also recommend ordering family style!

I can't wait to go back in the summer when it's even warmer!
author: Lauren E.

description:
SUMMARY: Went with a large group without a reservation on Sunday afternoon for a late brunch for a friend's birthday. Most of us ordered the fried chicken or burger. 

WHAT I TRIED: Fried chicken + Burger

-------------------MORE DETAIL-------------------

FOOD: DELICIOUS: The fried chicken was AMAZING. It was perfectly crispy/crunchy and seasoned. The burger was good but not exceptional - I had it with parmesan cheese instead of the stinky cheese (personal preference) and the combination of the burger was good, the meat patty just wasn't amazing. 

SERVICE: NEUTRAL:  Nothing spectacular. There isn't really a good waiting area so our group was waiting by the front door. The staff I think was (understandably) irritated with that, but there wasn't much we could do. 

AMBIANCE: NICE: I really liked the warehouse type of setting that was redone to be modern and no frills chic. Great casual but romantic ambiance for a nice meal.
author: Christina K.

description:
Came in for dinner with a friend on a Wednesday and it wasn't too crowded.  We were able to get a table fairly quickly but it was still early in the day. I really liked the skylight style ceiling and the greenhouse look the place had.  Our server was really knowledgable and knew the menu top to bottom.  My friend had a flight out after dinner and had her suitcase with her.  The host offered to hold it in the back for her which was a really nice jester and we took him up on the offer.  Fantastic service overall.

We split a handful of dishes so we could try a bunch of them.  The Beef tartar was the star of the show, just amazing.  We also had the little gems salad and the strozzapretti.  Both were very good and even though the portions seemed small we were full after the three items.  The strozzapretti was super filling.  Our bill was under $80 and we each had two drinks, pretty reasonable for the quality of the food.  I will go back again to try more of the menu.

The only flaw I had was the small beer selection but I could overlook that.
author: Scott M.

description:
Best meal I've had in SF. Seriously. The veggie offerings all looked amazing. I had the pea and burrata salad, pasta and steak tartare. Pasta was very good. Salad was excellent. Tartare was good-very pretty. 

The restaurant itself is beautifully designed. I love the open kitchen.

I highly recommend this restaurant. Will definitely come back next time I'm in town
author: Alexandra B.

description:
Listen to me closely. Do not come here if you don't love incredible food.  This place is heaven on earth.  I've been here a few times and pick the chef's choice with the wine pairing.  I always, and I mean ALWAYS, leave this place feeling wonderful about my decision making process when it comes to eating.  

Go here. Let them feed you.  Thank me later.
author: Carlos G.

description:
Please sir, may I have some more?  You may well feel like Oliver Twist after dining here.  You will wonder if the purpose of a restaurant is to feed hungry people, or tease them.  For what we paid, we expected to leave with either a full stomach, or at least satiated.  We ended up going to another restaurant to assuage our hunger.

The taste of our tiny dishes was good, but appetizer sized main dishes at the price of a full course meal isn't a good value.  I will choose to dine elsewhere.
author: Coran C.

description: Absolutely loved this spot. Everything we ordered was so delicious - fry bread with burrata, mushroom salad, squid pasta, tortellini and chocolate custard with coffee ice cream. The only two caveats: they do not have a full bar, fairly small portions for price. Regardless, I will most definitely be back.
author: Brittany B.

description: Central Kitchen what can I say the food was amazing and the setting was just right. We had the Fried bread and Beef tartare to start and the bread was serviced hot with roasted garlic and burrata which when put on the fresh cooked bread was delightful. and the tartare had just the right amount of flavor. For our mains we had the Rib eye, Short rib, Whipped potatoes, Cauliflower & Broccoli de cicco, and Fennel pollen & nutmeg tagliatelle. The meats were cooked to perfection and the sides were perfect. It was a lovely meal I wished we had stopped there because then I would have be able to give a 5 star rating but we had dessert and it was so underwhelming that I forget what they were and it was not a good end to a wonderful meal.
author: Therese L.

description:
This review is solely for Brandon Jew's pop up at Central Kitchen as he held a special Chinese New Year dinner since his restaurant, Mister Jiu won't be opened till Fall.  

To go along with the CNY celebration, Central Kitchen was decorated with red lanterns.  He offered a $75 family style menu featuring 10 items in four courses.  He also previewed some future dishes from Mister Jiu, like a two coursed preparation of duck.  

Food:

First Course 

Osmanthus Salad - Very refreshing!  The salad had citrus, daikon, and orange blossom granita. 

Winter Chop Suey - Chop Suey is a dish of random ingredients thrown together.  Jew's take on this dish consisted of mung bean sprouts, mustard, cashew, pear, and kohlrabi.  This dish wasn't very unique as it reminded me of a salad. 

Oxtail Terrine - The oxtail terrine was infused with black cardamom, licorice, star anise, and crispy garlic.  This dish reminded my cousin of the five spice beef that you can order at Taiwanese restaurants.  Simple, yet tasty!

Second Course 

Sizzled Fish - Jew used halibut for this dish and it included turnips, ginger, and black bean.  At the moment, I'm unable to eat raw food, therefore, I wasn't able to taste this dish.  My cousin said it was good, but the black bean was very faint.  

Hangtown Egg Foo Young - Egg Foo Young is basically an omelette dish.  Embedded in this egg foo young is lap cheong (Chinese sausage), watercress with fried oysters on top.  I loved the simplicity of this dish and it was very tasty.  I kept going back for more.  

Hot and Sour Cioppino - I thought the cioppino was just average.  None of the people in my group were huge fans.  Hubby said it was spicy, but he kept eating it.  The cioppino had today's catch (not sure what type of fish was used), tomatoes, coriander, yuba, and XO.  It was also garnished with cilantro, which soaked in my soup.  Therefore, I didn't care for the broth cause of the cilantro taste. 

Third Course

Hay and Tea Smoke Duck Breast - I believe this was Brandon's take on Peking duck as you use the same concept to eat it.  This dish was just okay.  I couldn't taste the tea or smokiness when I bit into the duck breast.  

Duck Leg Won Ton Soup - Delicious! This was another simple dish that out shined some of the others listed on the menu.   It's probably one of the better won ton's I've had in a while.  The duck meat and shrimp blended well together and the wrapper tasted homemade.

Dessert

Almond Milk Jello with Kishu Mandarins - Very creamy!  When I eat almond jello, it usually has a very strong flavor.  However, the almond flavor here was too light.  It was still delicious though.

Li Hing Mui and Guava Sorbet with Cherry Blossoms - The saltiness from the li hing balanced out the tartness of the guava sorbet extremely well.

Black Sesame, Coconut, Banana Cake with White Sesame Cream - The black sesame flavor went very well with the banana cake. Having both potentially strong flavors in the same dish here, I thought one would overpower the other but it was very balanced.

Overall, the three of us agreed that the simple dishes tasted the best.  Also, I was sightly disappointed that Brandon Jew didn't offer the sticky rice in the lotus leaf.  I was looking forward to tasting it.  I don't think the meal was worth $75/pp.  However, I would like to try Mister Jiu when it opens in the fall.
author: Candice H.

description: A must if you're in the area. Pasta made fresh and unbelievably cooked to perfection. The fry bread is a must with the burrata and roasted garlic. Perfect combination. The fry bread taste so light! And the burrata was so creamy and the garlic exceptional. Our waiter, Jeff(?), recommended the Little Gems salad and it did not disappoint. So tasty with a perfect amount of spice! The green garlic ranch will help those of you who may think the Calabrian chili spicy. We ended up ordering the Josey Bread and butter just to sop up the left over dressing. But then had to try the butter it came with and OMG!  My husband and I had the rigatoni and the pappardelle. So good in their own way. Pappardelle had a sweet nuttiness to it. The rigatoni had a delicious buttery, with a pleasant herbaceousness. Could not go wrong with either. Then, after ALL that, we shared the beef cheek and mashed potatoes. The beef cheek was SO tender and juicy. No knife needed. The mashies were so magnificent with the roasted butter although I like my mashies with chunks of potatoes. (Just like moms). No room for dessert but next time! They sounded amazing.
author: Diana A.

description:
Nice cozy atmosphere but very small portions of forgettable food at very high prices. Other than the chocolate custard dessert which was delicious, everything else -- starters, mid-courses, mains -- were nothing special, the food wasn't served quite hot enough, and the portions were tiny. For example: their porcini spaghetti was $32 (don't be fooled, the $21 on the menu is for a 'mid-course' portion, which basically means a half portion). $32 is well more than some of the best pasta dishes I had in NYC at Mario Batali restaurants and the like. And here's the kicker: it was decent, not great. Turns out the porcini is only in the pasta dough itself, not actually in the sauce, so the rich wild mushroom flavor you expect from porcini was nowhere to be found, and the tangy huckleberry sauce overpowered everything. I won't bother going into the details of the $16 onion soup or the $28 vegetable entree which amounted to a completely ordinary handful of broccoli, cauliflower and brussels sprouts with a drizzle of sauce. Something I would make at home on a Monday. (When I politely mentioned to the manager-in-training that that seemed high for just vegetables, he reminded me that 'produce in California is expensive.') 

I tend to like more homestyle, earthy, unpretentious kinds of restaurants myself, and I understand that others might prefer the adventurous kinds of places that experiment with all types of new flavor combinations. BUT, if a restaurant is going to go that route, shouldn't their palates be sophisticated enough to get the flavors balanced in the right way? Isn't that what you are paying for? 

In the end, Central Kitchen has the look and feel of a restaurant that should be great. But when it comes down to it, it's about the food. And here it simply falls short. Central Kitchen is one of those places that is trying too hard and in the process being delinquent on the basics. I believe there are many, many restaurants where you get a better food experience for about half the price.
author: Michael Z.

description:
I'm seriously loving this spot. The food was fresh, full of flavor, and seriously wholesome.

The seating was gorgeous with an "outdoor" terrace feel but covered up so you won't get rained on. I would love to come to this place for a fancier sit down dinner.

The only thing I was not a fan of - the long wait to order our food. We had only 4 parties in front of us for brunch, yet it took us about 35 minutes to wait until our turn. I'm not sure what happened in between, but it felt like everybody was just taking their dandy time.

Luckily, the food really does make up for it. Those donuts were out of this world and the avocado toast is to die for. They really go ham on the avocado spread and I am all about that. Not to mention price - while it is a bit more expensive, it's still pretty fair in comparison to what you can get in LA. So i'm completely satisfied.

Loving it and I will definitely be back here if I'm ever in the Mission again!
author: Laura C.

description:
From the creators of Flour and Water, Salumeria who have a long list of accolades, Central Kitchen is a cute little brunch place with outdoor seating (a ceiling which retracts), and is surprisingly easy to make reservations on Opentable. I loved the creative brunch menu, something you don't see in San Francisco as often as you might think. The food is on the expensive side, but overall pretty tasty. While this wasn't a home run, I would definitely come back and *absolutely* recommend you at least come by for the bacon sticky bun. 

MEDJOOL DATE STICKY BUN ($8) - 4 STARS:
I must admit this is the smallest $8 pastry I've ever eaten; however, it is a genius combo. It is topped with an incredible ricotta cheese spread which I could probably eat straight and BACON. For those unafraid of sugar, a great way to start your meal. 

MISSION HUEVOS ($15) - 3 STARS:
scrambled eggs. smoked tomato. avocado. charred padron-corn salsa. 
This was a crowd favorite when polling the waiters. I thought it was a unique take on huevos because it was topped with deep fried tortilla chips that had an amazing flaky texture that went perfectly with the eggs. The overall flavor depended on those chips - I wish there was a complementing sauce - and the eggs were not as soft scrambled as I prefer. 

FRIED CHICKEN BENEDICT ($18) - 3 STARS:
buttermilk biscuit. ham. hollandaise.
This was a very creative take on eggs benedict, and I loved the batter on the chicken which was fried extra crispy and the pairing with pancetta was brilliant. The chicken was small, more like nuggets, and a bit dry - I also have a personal preference for traditional english muffins. Excellent poached egg execution, fun combination, and appreciated the balance in the hollandaise, but not my favorite benedict.  

BAKED EGGS (3.5 STARS) - $17: 
pork stew. chickpeas. cabbage. chili bread crumbs. parmesan
This was flavorful but I felt it was too heavily filled with chickpeas, and needed a LOT more meat and sauce.
author: Jess C.

description:
This review is solely for the private dining experience at The Upstairs. 

Today, I had the privilege to dine at 'The Upstairs' at 3012 20th Street. A free standing event space steps away from the main Central Kitchen restaurant, providing a culinary adventure for private dining.
The place is a bit obscure and you can easily walk right pass it and miss it. Once you head up the mysteriously unfinished stairs you are met with a high vaulted ceiling room fit for up to 40 to dine.
Dinner was thoughtfully prepared and served family style. The flavors were well executed and the company made it an event to remember.

Parking is street and dress is smart casual. 
Service was friendly and attentive without interfering with the event conversations.
Wine/Water/Soda was never left empty.
author: Jess N.

description: Amazing food. Great service. The garlic and fry bread was out of this world. Menu doesn't look veggie friendly, but we made it work.
author: Matthew Z.

description:
More like 3.5 stars . . .  4.5 stars for food and 2.5 stars for service.

Went Labor Day weekend for our wedding anniversary.  I had told them in advance that it was our anniversary and had requested a quiet table . . .  we actually ended up in the middle of the restaurant at a pretty noisy table. 

SERVICE: Our server was nice but appeared to have the entire outdoor area as his section and had 6-7 tables (a couple of them larger tables--more than 4-tops) at a time.  This was too many tables.  There was always a long wait (several minutes to be greeted, 15 minutes for our glasses of wine after we had ordered them, and a long wait to order food--he said he would be back "in a minute" to take our order but it was more like 20), and over our five courses he never once came back to check on how the food was or how the wine was. 

Also, no one ever mentioned our anniversary or did anything.  I am not expecting free food or anything, but it would have been nice of them to acknowledge our special occasion in some way, since I did tell them in advance.  This was very disappointing as it was supposed to be a special (and rare) night out for us.

FOOD:  On the bright side, the food was EXCELLENT.  Heirloom tomato bread salad was absolutely delicious and we both agreed it was perfectly seasoned and balanced--although it was advertised with pole beans, and there were zero beans on that dish.  Charred squash with yogurt dressing was also yummy, but could have used more of the yogurt sauce.  Squid ink fusilli was scrumptious; I barely let the hubby have any! His pork with vadouvan and fennel was also very good. 

The chocolate custard dessert was wonderfully balanced, not too sweet with the salt and the bitterness of the coffee ice cream, and a little crunch from the cookie . . .  perfection.  I wanted to order another.

Wine was in the middle. The pinot was a bit too light and fruity, and the Malbec "Bordeaux"-style blend was definitely too sweet (and not very Bordeaux-like . . . we just got back from a trip to St Emilion in the Bordeaux region).  However the Mencia was a nice big red.

Overall, I am torn . . .  I loved the food and found the portion sizes and seasoning and balance to be very good across the board; the tomato salad and chocolate custard being real standouts . . .  but it really took something away from our anniversary experience to be at a noisy table in the middle of the room with such slow service.
author: Janice T.

description:
3.5 stars for brunch.

4.5 stars for dinner!

I came here for brunch a few weeks ago and wasn't super wow'ed by most of the dishes I got but was blown away by dinner when I came back for my friend's birthday.

Maybe it was the combination of a soothing atmosphere on a Sunday night or the rare, warm, San Francisco evening, but whatever it was, dinner was an exquisite experience. 

My 4 friends and myself split the porchetta, pork agnolotti pasta, apple pate, bread basket, a lovely burrata and melon salad, and the crudo. 

The standout dishes were the amazing, flavorful burrata with mixed melons, the perfect, al dente pasta, and the giant porchetta. Being affiliated with Flour & Water, I'm not surprised that the pasta was delicious, but the other dishes were a pleasant surprise. They were all perfect examples of classic California fare.

The service was lovely and the dishes were paced in the most perfect way. The Mission-Potrero location also allows for some fun exploring, as it's right next to gems like Sightglass, Flour & Water, Universal Cafe, Heath Ceramics, and other San Francisco classic places. 

I would love to come back when the restaurant is not too crowded, just like my experience, for another relaxing meal.
author: Kate M.

description: Central Kitchen has a very warm ambience ideal for a date or a cosy dinner with friends. The food is eclectic and interesting - not necessarily the most delicious. Their pastas are very well flavored, carrot and mash potatoes are good appetizers, not a fan of the trout entree, mushroom and sunchoke is pretty good. The star of the evening was definitely the chocolate coffee dessert that came in a short glass - the mix of textures and sweet, salt is lovely. Have to say the waitress was rude, a bit presumptuous with our menu and her being pissed off (for no reason) became very apparent in her dealings with us. It's expensive so I'm not looking to go anytime soon but I guess it's a place one can eventually try out in the mission for a fancy-ish dinner.
author: Where A.

description: The dishes no doubt were plated really well BUT for the price the taste is not worth at all! Guys save your money and goto places with better tasting food.
author: Khushboo S.

description:
I've been several times and I'd say it's not the most consistent experience, as there are times when the flavors don't quite go together.  But on my most recent visit, we loved everything.  

pate ciccioli - this pork pate had a really great texture and paired really well with the pickled radish.
squash and apple salad - this had a number of interesting ingredients, including some flavor from the lemongrass, some creaminess from the coconut milk base, some kick from jalapeños, some crunch from some fried crisps, some tartness from the apple, and texture from the squash.  all in all a really unique dish. 
Pork belly a la plancha - pork belly with radish, mustard greens, broth - this was yummy, although of course it's pork belly so be prepared for some fattiness
ling cod with miso, celery root and sunchoke - this is a pretty reliable dish and often on the menu. the cod was cooked really nicely.  
the hen - this had brussels sprouts, slaw, pureed sweet potato, pulled meat, and then the hen itself.  Possibly a few too many things going on, but still a good dish.

All in all, we had a great meal. 

(The only negative was that when the credit card bill came, it was $30 higher than the itemized check that had been shown to us earlier, so luckily I caught that before signing.  The server was very apologetic (it had been someone else who had brought the bill out), but of course that wasn't the best way to end the meal.)
author: Vivian W.

description: One of my favorite bites in the city.  I always go for the chefs pre-fix menu and have never left hungry.  Delicious food, great atmosphere, and extremely friendly staff.
author: Max G.

description:
All of the dishes I had were excellent. The decor and ambiance makes this place a great choice for a date night. The only reason why they don't get 5 stars is the service was slightly below average.

I will come back for the aged beef agnolotti--it was absolutely decadent. I was disappointed with the fennel panna cotta.
author: Courtney H.

description: Dinner here last week, and while food was very good, service was sorely lacking. Waited for some 10-15 minutes before someone came to our table (after waiting 15 minutes for our table to open up). Didn't eat anything until well after 45 minutes after our reservation, then snail slow service afterward... just didn't seem to care. Disappointing.
author: Sam E.

description: Awesome space. More spacious than it looks from the outside. Nice selection of wines. Small portions so be prepared to order a few items. Love the cappelletti--get it!
author: Yad L.

description: Went with the "let the kitchen decide option. This is really a gamble as I did not know what would be served but was told that it was a sampling of the menu. For the appetizers, we got an array of pickled veggies, burrata, pork pate, salumi taster plus fried bread. Then we got a plate of mushrooms with creme fraiche to share, followed by two pasta dishes. Really pleased with choices up to this point. When the main dish came, was a little disappointed that one large plate of roast chicken was served for the us to share with mashed potatoes and roast carrots. While the flavors were good, it was not an exciting dish nor a dish I would have ordered out of entire menu. For dessert, each of got our own espresso ice cream with some nuts, chocolate custard and crumble rather than Two desserts to share family style. OverAll a pleasant dining experience. Service was excellent and if I were to go back, I would not order the let the kitchen decide menu again.
author: Anna C.

description: I've been really into eggs lately, so I chose the slow-cooked eggs with black barley and nettle porridge for brunch. Not only did this dish taste superb, but it was also healthy. The veggies really jazzed up my roughage intake for the day. I also tried a bite of my friend's frittata, which was tasty, but was it supposed to be served cold?
author: Suany W.

description: The dishes we ordered were generally tasty and well-prepared. The ingredients were fresh. However, the overall experience just didn't live up to the high expectations we had of the restaurant. Not sure why this place is so popular.
author: Erick T.

description:
Wow - this place has really stepped it up a notch, TOP-NOTCH!  
The menu was recently changed and it's now more traditional/creative vs. set menu before, although one can still ask for it. 
The new dishes are AMAZING and I will post some pictures. From avocado salad to the pasta varietals, yum! 
Plus, the bone-in ribeye for two..that was unforgettable! It came pre-cut, and reminded me of Peter Luger in NYC.
Make sure to save room for dessert - the chocolate custard was amazing, but best shared as it's pretty rich.
Lastly, be sure to get good pairing suggestions on the wine. Kudos to our server Christina as she suggested some terrific whites w/ our appetizer and pasta, then a fantastic pinot to go with our whole chicken. 
p.s. Top chef Thomas(30 under 30) was there the entire time to make sure each dish was perfect!
author: Patrick L.

description:
Delicious food - though some small plates are overpriced for what you get.  Fry Bread -- essentially a beignet -- with undercooked garlic, and sides of bread in general).

The service is low key and very efficient.

The beverage options are limited and pricey so explore corkage for something extravagant.

Lastly the music (piped in from a crowded bar nearly ensuite) is more clubby and manic than the food deserves.

Excellent deserts.
author: David D.

description:
This place is one of my fiance's favorites, second to Delfina. The atmosphere is very pleasant and the food is very good. It feels like you're in the countryside with the little copper fountain they have and it's very airy with sunroofs. The food is Californian/American. We got beef tartare, agnolotti, and hen. The hen was my favorite.  It was so moist and the dressing was perfect with it. The agnolotti isn't as good as Delfina's. 

You can bring your own bottle and they have a 1for1 program, where the corkage fee gets waived if you get one of their bottles also.  The service was excellent, and our waitress took us up on our offer for her to taste the wine we brought. She appreciated our frankness that the agnolotti at Deflina is better, and even recommended her favorite restaurant, RN74. This place is in the same restaurant group (NiTimeas) as the bar Trick Dog, Flour + Water, Salumeria, and Aaxte, and DuNord. I've also been to Trick Dog for drinks, which is directly next door to Central Kitchen. We also came once just for drinks and there's a little bar we sat at in the back--beer and wine only but their vermouth drink is pretty close to a cocktail (kind of like an aperol spritzer).

I'm surprised it doesn't get a better rating on Yelp. When we went last time, they were going to close for a week and a half for renovations, so there are probably some cool changes and updates they made.
author: Sara M.

description:
Went there for Drinks and dinner.   Ambiance is rustic casual.  Loved that it had the outdoor feel with garden lights!   Also service was good.  Some of the dishes we ordered were sub-par.  I would have liked a bit more variety on the menu for meat carb-free options.  I liked the fact that we could bring our own bottle of wine and as long as you order a bottle of wine at the table, they uncork your bottle for free along with it.   So if you have a group of 4 or more, it balances it out.  
I ordered the roast chicken (half) and my husband ordered grilled albacore entree.   I wasn't too impressed with the entrees.   The chicken was food well and a generous portion but boring.  The tuna was 4 small pieces of slightly seared tuna in a shallow bowl some kind of soup.  It was a small dish and barely enough for my husband.   He ate half of my chicken as well.  One of My friend ordered mushroom and avocado with quinoa and a little gems salad and she liked them both.  
We ordered 2 appetizers- the shishito peppers which were just ok and fry bread wth green onion powder which tasted really good. 
Ambience - 4stars
Service - 4.5 stars
Food - 3 stars
Wine service - 4 stars
author: Rima S.

description:
3.5 STARS

What I love about Anthony Bourdain is his honesty, crassness, and that he's an all-around bad ass. Only Bourdain would have enough balls to talk about his gristle missile on CNN. And for him to say, it's "enormous"? Big balls, I tell you.

Even though I'm not a fan of Flour + Water, I've been wanting to go to their sister restaurant, Central Kitchen since they opened last year. Mixed reviews, however, kept me at bay.

That's until I read that Central Kitchen also offers brunch. Considering dinner for two at Central Kitchen would set us back over $200 for the tasting menu, I figure brunch was a safer bet. Except brunch is definitely not their strong suit. Not the day we went at least.

Perhaps Bourdain was right when he wrote in his book, "Kitchen Confidential" that brunch is a "dumping ground for the odd bits left over from Friday and Saturday".

My friend and I ordered the Fried Chicken Benedict w/ Biscuit, Ham & Hollandaise  ($17): http://bit.ly/GPA1pk. Besides the perfectly poached eggs, this dish was poorly executed: http://bit.ly/1eo9qM1. The tiny fried chicken nuggets were awful (super dry and stringy) and tasted like it had been fried early that am then kept warm under a heat lamp. Same goes for the biscuit. The dish was pretty to look at though.

Mr. NSS' Soft Scrambled Eggs w/ Kale, Ricotta & Rosemary Avocado Toast  ($14) didn't fare any better: http://bit.ly/19KTCxE. It was so bland with a mushy (not fluffy) texture. The blank look on his face when I asked how he liked his dish said it all. He also ordered a side of Smoked Bacon ($5) which was more sweet than smoky. It wasn't crispy either and was more like Chinese jerky. And no, it wasn't like Sweet Maple's millionaire's bacon which has a caramelized brown sugar crust and a peppery finish. 

As a side note, Central Kitchen is not a place I would bring a group of meat and potatoes type of guys who love a good hearty brunch. Stick to your local greasy diner for that.

Redeeming our lackluster brunch dishes were our shared apps. The Tonnato Deviled Eggs ($7) were a deliciously creamy bite with a salty oceany crunch from the bottarga (think bonito flakes but crunchy): http://bit.ly/1aIYxS3. The Chicken Liver Mousse ($8) was decadently rich and delicate in flavor: http://bit.ly/19PfgGV. It was definitely one of the better ones I've had.

Surprisingly, the Roasted Carrots w/ Buffalo Milk Custard, Grains & Seeds ($13) was the best dish during brunch and fondly reminded me of dishes I had at Atelier Crenn and Manresa: http://bit.ly/1an8YcN. The combo of the sweet baby carrots, silky smooth custard, toasty grains, and crunchy sunflower seeds were deliciously satisfying and seriously left me wanting more. Who would have known rabbit food would taste so phucking good?

Service was somewhat as bumpy as the food. We had reservations for brunch yet there was over a 30 minute wait to be seated. Factor in the insanely loud [bad] music blaring in the background it made us all a bit irritated. Now this coming from a girl that would sit in front of the speakers at raves; millenniums ago but still, I can tolerate loud music but not at a nice restaurant please. 

Luckily, things ran more smoothly when we were seated and my friend kindly asked our waiter if they can turn down the music (they nicely did--thank you!). The staff was very pleasant and the food service was timely. At the end of brunch, the hostess came to apologize for the wait which was much appreciated.

If they keep the music down, Central Kitchen would make such a cute and romantic date place. Urban chic, the space is very open with a lot of light coming through. Street parking was easily found and there's no meters in the area. Yay!

3.5 stars for Central Kitchen but rounding down because I wouldn't return to try their dinner menu. For that price point, you can go to La Folie, Danko, Spruce, or any other fancy schmancy one-Michelin starred restaurant.

After reading the excerpt from "Kitchen Confidential" about weekend brunch over and over again, I'm cool off brunch for a while. Not going to repeat some of the things he wrote but damn he's harsh: http://bit.ly/15EyhbM. B-i-g b-a-l-l-s, I tell you...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
The food was delicious but our party couldn't really enjoy the meal because the music was unbearably loud. We asked them to lower it (and we were there for a 6pm monday reservation so the restaurant was only 1/4 full) and they did but never low enough that we could relax and have a conversation with anyone but the person next to you and only if you shoved your heads together like you were on a reality tv show and planning how to cook a soufflé with 4 improbable ingredients.  And the music was bad music- not at all enjoyable for dinner. Why? Why bother having good ingredients and a fine chef and a table for 6 when it is just going to be a shoulder hunching experience? Why have black speakers stapled up all over the restaurant so you can never get away? -- I walked around and checked the sound levels and it was loud in every part of the restaurant. Why?
