The duck pate was lovely and the saffron pollen dusted pasta was delicious. The carrots with the short ribs were surprisingly underdone but the short ribs were nice. The trout was perfect- moist and mouthwatering. As is the case with most pricey restaurants the servings are  small. We grabbed a burritos for our 15 year old and 18 year old (congrats on getting into a good college dinner!) after dinner. 
The desserts weren't as good as Del Fina or many other equivalent restaurants -- the chocolate mousse was best. The buttermilk panne cotta was oddly flavored. The sorbet was fine. 
The seats are hard and were fine for all but grandma.
author: Julia W.

description:
Food was so hearty and flavorful!
Although the portions are on the smaller side, they are so rich and yummy, I didn't feel like we were deprived.
The frye bread was dusted with an amazing green powder... very tasty with the barrata!
The Avacado salad and pasta with pork belly was truly outstanding!
The only draw back was the service kinda dwindled after our last dish.  We would have ordered dessert but we think our server forgot about us!
There was another guy who saw we were waiting to pay and was very attentive which was nice!

We will plan to go back!
author: Ahnee M.

description:
Easy to find parking in the area, good energy and well executed, interesting food.  

LOVED:
*pork trotters
*dirty rice duck croquettes
*charred squid w/fregola, PERFECTLY tender & smoky.  My favorite of the evening. 
*albacore & avocado

GOOD:
*liver mousse, maybe a WHEE sweet for me? 
*chamomile oil cake, lovely dessert, light, refreshing, great textures

NOT GREAT:
*salmon was cooked well, but I just didn't like the flavor profiles, a NO for me

Bread is most likely available upon request.  

Thumbs down: I understand a dark and sexy bathroom, but I could barely see my feet or eyes, or anything.  Plus it doesn't help Trick Dog patrons next door share the bathroom facilities, which definitely makes me think twice about the cleanliness.  

Wish there were more pastas and fresh greens and less fried appetizers.  The small portions kept it light, but a lot of it was artery clogging options.
author: Cynthia C.

description: One of the very few one stars ever given, this place feels ridiculously expensive for the quality of food it serves, or lack thereof. The portions are on the small side, and the food itself comes off as very mediocre. There doesn't seem to be much sophistication or taste in its dishes. The only enjoyable part of the meal was the wine. Almost gives off the impression they have a bunch of inexperienced and unqualified persons attempting to put together ingredients into something that resembles high end dishes from more established restaurants. Money may be better spent on the numerous other restaurants in the Bay area.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Nice decor.  Warehouse high ceiling with waterfall and plants.  

Food is 3 star max.  Pasta dishes were great and everything else is mediocre.  Porchetta was simply terrible.  40% fat.  50% unflavored tough meat.  10% chewy inedible skin.  

2 star service as waiter was pushy in making us order more than than we could eat.  He insisted on adding a pasta which in retrospect was the only decent fish.  Then insisted on making the pasta dish extra large which we declined.   Then kept on giving us dessert menu and recommending his fav dessert when we said no dessert.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: Underrated and under-the-radar Mission restaurant that has pleased me well on each of my 3 visits.  The wine list is excellent, the food is spot-on, and the chocolate custard that's a menu mainstay is absolutely divine. Be sure to save some room to share it with a friend.
author: Kim S.

description:
Divine! 

I've been meaning to go to CK for a while. Anything by the Bon Vivants is pretty much a guarantee  (I love Trick Dog, Aatxe, Cafe du Nord). I was not disappointed. 

We enjoyed a lovely bottle of Viognier, which the waitress did us the courtesy of warning is it was a bit of an unconventional white. She was right, but that was exactly the kind of white I personally liked. 

All the food was great. I might have to find a way to obtain whipped Mt Tam that came with the bread -- so good! The smoked beet salad had great (surprise -) smoky flavor, that was so well complemented by the yogurt sauce. 

The char on the octopus was great. As the waitress suggested, we did a half order of one of the pastas (protip: you can do that), and I'm so glad she did. The lamb sauce with the bit of sweetness from the currants was great. 

The trout was great (perfectly cooked, crispy skin and all). The dessert was really good (chocolate pot de creme), but not anything extraordinary. 

This might be a new favorite for special occasions.
author: Rita K.

description:
Overpriced. 
Stuffy. 
Rude. 

The pork chop dish for two was dangerously undercooked. One look at the bloody, massive hunk of meat made my stomach twirl. Instead of sending it back (since the kitchen had done us the favor of cutting it off the bone I'm surprised they felt this was the appropriate temperature to serve it at...), we placed it aside and dreamed about all the excellent reincarnations of this dish that would happen in our kitchen later that night or the next day. The sides were also a proverbial 'noodle-scratcher'. Charred brocollini? Pickled something or another? Bulgur wheat?  It was boring and mundane. Flat-footed and pedestrian for what expectations I had of this place. 

Halibut tartar was also fishy. Something was off. A dish that sounded better on paper than what materialized in front of me. 

The hummus with pine nuts was a winner. Finally something to be happy about. So very flavorful. 

The onion soup was a joke. Skip this entirely. Not going to waste time describing what a total and utter let down it was. I'm angry just thinking about it. 

There was a pasta dish. And I wish I remember what it was. My friend ordered it, and it was, by far, the best thing on the menu. But again. It's pasta. If you fuck up pasta you may as well turn in your apron, chef. 

There was a desert with yogurt. Or was it cheese.. With what tasted like puréed kale. That was the worst choice of the night. 

Thank got the chocolate pudding was the last taste in my mouth... Otherwise this would have been a 2 star review. 

Service... Where to begin. Was it the unapologetic host? Or the server with little to no patience? Or was it her inability to be genuine and sincere?  Her smile was forced. So was her manners. The experience was painful. I get it, being brassy and abrasive can be cute... But not tonight sweetness. I noticed you kept ducking into that little store in the property every 20 minutes. Was it for another line? Disco snow makes you numb... And I'm guessing you needed it.
author: Jade D.

description:
Second time dining at Central Kitchen and I have to save this place is one of my favorite spots in SF.

Nice sophisticated atmosphere, good lighting and music in the back ground and the food is quite good and reasonably priced (rare in SF). 

What really shined though was the pasta and our server Joe-- best pasta I've had in the U.S. hands down. I heard they offer classes on pasta making too.
author: Rob S.

description:
This place is great! The ambiance is really nice - open and feels like your outdoors without being cold. The food is all small plate style so can get expensive but everything we had was so delish!

-raw tuna dish was amazing bites of fresh fish lightly salted and the texture was amazing
-fried bread - get it. just do it. have it with the garlic and burrata- don't wuss out. You're worth it. 
- heirloom tomato salad - had a great yogurt and spices on it that was more middle eastern/indian
-mashed potatoes - SO GOOD. just that comfort food you want
- hen - it was probably the least mind blowing dish - maybe because it's chicken but it was good not great.
- braised pork - very good. again not one of the best but I was satisfied. 

Service was attentive and not too much. 
everyone was nice even the doorman was pleasant.

Definitely would come back.
author: Ruby B.

description: It's just another stupid overpriced 'foody' restaurant in San Francisco.  I went there with a group of co-workers who were raving about how awesome this place was.  First, I could not believe the prices for things that, frankly, didn't seem cooked well and was designed to impress visually but was not filling.  I tried to be cool and spent like $50 for a teeny appetizer and a glass of house wine.  That's a lot of money for me.  Others in my group also felt kinda bummed that they needed to spend some money at this joint.  Anyways...this place is just around the corner from El Farolito on 24th St.  So, as soon as we were done, I went there and got me a Super Carne Asada and a horchata and life was normal again.  As I walked to the taqueria, I started to wonder about how quickly the gentrification was coming along in that neighbourhood.  This hip place was such a contrast to the the neighborhood is in terms of the people and other businesses.  It made me sad.  I won't go to this place again and I don't recommend others do either.  There are other places that could, frankly, use your money and give you a more satisfying experience.
author: Jo F.

description: My family, some friends, and I had dinner at Central Kitchen recently.  The food was good, but the portions were microscopic.  The tiny portions seemed even smaller as the menu and wait staff encourage you to "share".  Then music was way too loud, and our requests to have the music lowered didn't get much in the way of results.  Each of our family's spent $250 (without liquor!) and when we left the restaurant my son said, "I'm starving.  Let's go get something to eat."  We got some fast food, as it was late.  Our friends were also hungry after their dinner; one went home and had a burrito; the other had an omelette.  I would advise you to stay as far away as possible from Central Kitchen. None of us knows how they stay in business.
author: Kathy K.

description: The decor is nice and funky converted industrial. The piped in music competes with conversation a little too much. The food has many unique flavors and overall is excellent. Where the experience goes sour is on the portion size. Too much cost for too little. Seeing the suggestion on the menu "all dishes to be shared family style" adds expectation to the portion size and furthers the disappointment. A solid four star eatery if they double (literally) the portion size.
author: Mike M.

description:
Bottom line---not for me.
The pork with stone fruit, wild rice, kale & black pudding for $27 was not what I expected at all..  Slice after slice of white fat posing as pork belly--truly awful.
I had to send it back.
Waiter was wonderful--replaced it with the halibut that was overly salty but edible.

Loved the house wine.  Skylark served out of the tap.
Loved the ramp velouté with ash roasted potato & porcini for $13.  It was a beautiful, thick, soup- like dish with flavorful potatoes and mushrooms inside.

The seats were uncomfortable--we sat in the open ceiling section.  Wooden seats and concrete walls made for a tough 2 hours.
The music was very loud and self absorbed--someone in the back must have loved the hipster, blaring rock music--but not this diner.
It didn't make sense to have this music cranked with the clientele that was dining there tonight.  There was a wide range of ages but it didn't seem to matter.  Not good--a tad pretentious.


I do give credit for a creative take on a menu--but as I stated above--not for me.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Went for my birthday! This place is simply amazing! The service is highly attentive without being obnoxious. The food is simply delicious, elegant and beautifully presented! Love the small plates to share concept, this way you can taste a bunch without overeating! 
Top two on the current menu were:
Grilled Escarole- chanterelle mushroom purée and "the prosciutto of beef"....
Mushroom and lobster stuffed pasta in a brown butter sauce...

Thank you for a lovely birthday feast!
author: Laura H.

description:
We went here for a friend's birthday party and had the back room/daytime deli area rented out.  The ambiance was very nice with a good size elevated table large enough to sit 16 people comfortably along with all our drinks, food, etc.  They had a pre-fixe menu due to the size of our party with every dish being quite tasty.

They had a hen dish which was out of this world, never had hen that juicy, tender and flavorful!  The desserts were in individual containers which were just the right size and capped off a great dinner with even better service.  All of the persons serving us were extremely helpful, polite and willing to help with any request that we had.
author: Landon Y.

description: This is prob one of my favorite places in SF to have a date night or bring friends visiting. It has such a great vibe/ambiance, AMAZING food and service has always been good!
author: Sara E.

description:
A buddy of mine was visiting from Hong Kong so we got the ol' SF/college gang together for a nice meal.  We were fortunate to get a reservation (albeit at 9:15pm) at the super hip Central Kitchen, which was still super packed by the time we arrived.  The restaurant has some really cool and unique dining spaces and we were seated at a corner table by the bar.

We considered ordering the tasting menu for $90/person, but instead opted to share 7 dishes from the regular menu including two appetizers, three first courses, and two entrees.  To pair, we ordered a bottle of an Oregon pinot noir ($57).  Bread and butter are available upon request, and were both fantastic.  My only criticism is that each slice is served to order, which is kind of annoying.

Our first dish was the melon and cucumber salad ($12) with avocado, fig leaf yogurt, and fresno chili.  I really enjoyed how refreshing each bite was and it served as a fantastic palette cleanser as we began our meal.

Next came the beef tartare ($16) with fermented turnip, smoked curds, and plancha bread.  My buddies really enjoyed this dish, but I felt it fell a little short and could have used a touch of salt.  Textures however, were very pleasing.

This was followed by the seared rock cod ($15) with sourdough, rouille, and garlic scape-clam broth.  The fish was perfectly cooked and the broth was delicious and subtle.  This was a dish that we all agreed we would order again.

The charred squid ($15) with tomato, peppercorn fregola, and garum was one of my personal favorites from the evening, and I absolutely loved the charred spice flavors.  The grain it was served with was delicious and one that I would definitely make at home.

The eggplant ($14) with roman mint, teleme, and lentil-pint nut streussel was also another fantastic dish, and the eggplant was kept fairly firm.  The streussel was really yummy, especially when everything was enjoyed in one bite.

Our server recommended their hen ($25) with poached fig, pickled squash, basil, and pistachio and mixed roast of pork ($26) with peach, pickled chard, and mustard seed as our entrees.  By far my favorite dish of the evening was the hen, which must have been sous vide in order to achieve the tenderness of the dish.  It was amazing from first bite to last.  The pork was very nice as well, and my favorite bits were the fatty pork belly slices.  It was also very nice, but could not compare to the amazing hen.

For dessert, we ordered their take on peaches and cream ($10) as well as something I remember as a strudel with fruity sorbet ($10).  The texture on the basil ice cream with the peaches was unbelievable and I have never experienced anything like it.

Service was very good and attentive, and both the hostess and server were knowledgable about the dishes and their wines.  The dining experience was lovely, and something I look forward to repeating.  It's not the most affordable dinner in the world, and with drinks, tax, and tip, came out to about $100/person.  However, it was definitely memorable and to that end, totally worth it.

Food: 9/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$$$

Atmosphere: 9/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Came here for brunch. Meal was okay, but portions were small. Ordered the frittata which came out cold. When asked before ordering, there was no mention of the dish being served cold. 

A free side of bacon was provided to make up for this mistake. That said, for such an expensive brunch, I left hungry and not impressed. The service and portions need to match the quality of the food.
author: Brian H.

description:
Great experience, we had a business meeting/dinner at the central kitchen and then flour + water location both sister restaurants, and both experiences were excellent.
Central Kitchen was able to accommodate some delicious anti pasti's, appetizer such as Hummus Boards, Cheese Boards, Charcuterie Boardscocktails and then we proceeded across the street to the Flour + Water where we had a 4 course meal paired with bubbly, and wines, the place is underrated, every single person on our table loved the quality of food, service, and ambiance, a must try!
author: P R.

description:
The ambience was really enjoyable, warm and cozy! The best part really, as the food was bellow Sub Par and we even ordered their signature Porchetta. I never imagined that Porchetta could be anything but flavorful, but to my disappointment it was both over cooked on one side and almost raw on the other with no flavor whatsoever!!

Hate to leave a bad review, but after throwing down over 100 bones for just the dish and a salad, I felt robbed of an evening I was intending to be a super flavorful one with my Wife.
author: Rachel F.

description: We were a party of 5 on a Saturday evening. Despite the fact that our seating was 30 minutes delayed, the staff was friendly and helpful. The ambiance was hip, yet casual and laid-back. We had the Chef's selection, which was more than enough delicious food for all. My favorites were the arancini and the roasted hen.
author: Ron B.

description: Love the newest incarnation of this place with small veggie and larger meat plates to share. The pastas are also delicious. Not a cheap meal but I think actually worth the cost.
author: Katherine W.

description:
From the tasting menu and some dishes on the house (since my friend  works there), I had a fantastic dinner of 10+ plates. Although every dish is amazingly delicious, I will list some of the highlights last night:

Chilled pea soup: it came in an empty bowl with prosciutto, flax seed and pickle ramp. Then, the waitress will pour the freshly puréed pea soup into the bowl! The soup is light with a fresh spring flavor. 

Crispy pork trotter croquette: great texture with a sprinkle of salt on the surface. Love the flavor of the croquette and the plate presentation putting the croquette on top of the previous menu paper! 

Great food, beautiful indoor decor with a outdoor terrace feeling, and attentive service :)
author: Jennifer F.

description: Beautiful restaurant.   I went here for dinner with a group of friends, which is great since you get to share everything.  We ordered the liver, two pastas, the steak, and the porchetta for two.  My favorite was without a doubt one of the pastas.  It's probably since flour and water is one of their sister restaurants, but seriously their pastas are better than some pastas I had in Italy.  The steak was very flavorful and perfectly cooked.  The porchetta, although sounds great, I thought was somewhat disappointing.  The accompanying sides were very similar (all pickled vegetables), except for the potatoes which were probably my favorite side.  One thing I was disappointed about was that they only have beer and wine.  Being next door to Trick Dog I had hoped they would have cocktails.
author: Tiffany C.

description: This restaurant is really cool inside and has outdoor seating.  The food is pretty amazing: we had the king salmon, the duck confit pasta and the game hen. Each dish was decadent and beautiful and the service was very good. My only complaint is that the prices are sky high so I don't think my boyfriend and I could make it back to this location on a regular basis.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I took my dad here for his birthday this year. He's more of a meat and potatoes kind of guy, but I wanted him to try upscale food for a change. Here's what we tried, broken down by dish:

Dirty rice croquettes with duck & remoulade - these were great; fried perfectly crisp and I enjoyed the duck filling going with the cool remoulade. 

Liver mousse with hazelnut & pluot - this might have been my favorite dish of the night. Beautiful presentation with the toast and the pluot jam with hazelnut on top was the bee's knees. You can always ask for more toast as well.

Albacore tuna with charred avocado, padron & seeds - this dish was completely bland. There was no acidity to go with the tuna. The padron peppers were mostly flavorless. The one thing I enjoyed were the tomatoes.

Halibut with tomato, cucumber water, chili & olive crumb - the halibut was overcooked and again, most of the dish was bland. Olive crumb aside, the fish, tomato, and cucumber were very one dimensional in flavor and texture. It was unworthy as an entree. 

Mixed roast of pork with bulgar wheat, swiss chard, peach & ginger - the pork was overdone. My dad had this dish and while he enjoyed the flavor profile and the combination of tastes, he agreed that the meat was completely overcooked. 

Chamomile oil cake with fennel & fig sorbet - there was nothing special about the dessert. The fennel & fig sorbet didn't excite the palate. 

Overall, our meal started off on a couple of high notes and then slipped off from there. I think each dish was missing a couple of execution points. The entrees were a major disappointment. Food aside, the atmosphere and service were exceptional.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I've been wanting to try Central Kitchen for months since it comes from the owners of the genuinely awesome flour + water, but I have to admit all this anticipation must have worn out my taste buds a bit since I felt a lot of the dishes were just slightly off the mark. The occasion was my birthday actually, and Jamie W. and I wanted a relatively low-key dining experience but one that would still be memorable. It sort of delivered. It's in the Mission but away from the hubbub of Mission itself in a handsome, post-modern building that made me think it was once an architect's office. Although definitely on the higher end, the vibe is casual, and the noise level a bit too loud for my taste with the sound of convivial diners competing with the blaring music coming from the speakers.

I generally don't notice what the wait staff is wearing, but I thought the dorm-party outfits felt way too informal for the setting. Me a snob? Get your elbows off the table before you say that to me. Anyway, one of the servers dropped off a couple of warm rolls which were nice with the little dab of butter they left us (see photo). We were trying to nibble rather than devour them as we perused the short menu. We decided to start with the $7 Fried Peppers with Caper Aioli and Lemon, which was a nice-sized plate full of piquillo peppers that quickly became an addiction (see photo). For our real appetizers, Jamie decided on the $12 Three Cheeses (none of which I could remember) that came nestled on a flat piece of crisp lavash along with dollops of fennel preserve mixed with dill and walnuts (see photo).

It was shareworthy, at least from my standpoint, and quite tasty if somewhat unadorned. It tasted more appropriate for dessert, and sure enough, it did show up again on the dessert menu. Mine was a more self-centered choice, the $13 Tomato Salad with crushed avocado, ginger and peanut (see photo), a striking melange of red tomato slices and chunks of fried green tomatoes. Quite refreshing and gone in a matter of minutes. Entrees were comparatively speaking, the weakest part of the evening. Jamie ordered the $29 Pork with Apples, Quinoa, Spiced Bread, Cippolini and Sage, which while savory with the pork prepared two ways, was a bit on the bland side (see photo).

Mine suffered a bit from the same state, the $29 Hen with Oysters, Lettuces and Smoked Tomatoes in an emulsion I couldn't quite figure out (see photo). I personally thought the serving size was rather on the paltry side even though the hen was prepared impeccably. We decided to share a dessert, and even though Jamie is not a lemon fan, he indulged me on my birthday and allowed us to have the $10 Lemon Cake with slices of nectarine, yogurt mousse and hazelnut (See photo). A pretty presentation, it amounted to a few bites for each of us. There's definitely a lot of quality ingredients served here. It's just that some of the executions still need a bit more work and testing. OK, OK, I'm willing to be the culinary guinea pig.
 
FOOD - 3.5 stars...very nice ingredients, some well plated, some need more work
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a split decision on this...nice modern decor but rather loud considering the price tag
SERVICE - 3 stars...pretty good but some more polish would be nice
TOTAL - 3 stars...very good but not flat-out great when you think about the pedigree
author: Ed U.

description: The pastas here, since they share the same ownership as Flour&Water, are top notch. The liver mousse as well as the steak here were extremely flavorful and well-executed. The only disappointment was the porchetta for two. They have a limited supply each day, but it didn't feel special at all. The sides that came with the porchetta were basic, uninspired, pickled veggies for the most part, and the porchetta was well-cooked but was still underwhelming in general.
author: Kazu O.

description: The food here was wonderful--too bad the service and the atmosphere didn't live up to it. Our meal was marred by the boisterous, noisy, rude millennials who can't bother to wear anything to a nice meal but a hoodie and don't care if their noise is spoiling the atmosphere of all the nearby diners. Service was slow and indifferent; bill arrived with extra charges. But the tasting menu was fantastic, full of fresh flavors, unusual combinations, wholly satisfying. If it weren't for the service and the noise, this would be a favorite special restaurant. My advice to the very talented chef is to move somewhere where the diners care about the experience of dining and aren't just stuffing their entitled little mouths.
author: Laura F.

description: I had a surprise 40th birthday party for my husband in The Upstairs at Central Kitchen. It was impeccable!! Planning and coordinating with Mac Malone was so easy. The food and wine were amazing. Everyone commented on how great the event space was. They helped pull off an awesome surprise party! I can't say enough good things and absolutely recommend them. Can't wait to come back for dinner!
author: Brea W.

description:
This restaurant converts their patio into their dining room making for a nice open eating area. The service is friendly and welcoming. I love that they take your phone number so you can go next door and grab a drink while waiting for your table. I guess they do that since they don't have a bar in the restaurant to wait at.

I thought the food was just mediocre. Small portions made for more of a tasting menu type experience, but none of the dishes stood out. Plus, they charge $4 for bread and butter that they don't even make in house. 

Meh. We left unsatisfied and still hungry. 3 stars for the service and nice atmosphere.
author: Meredith M.

description: Hold the press.  This place should get all five star reviews for its excellent cuisine and warm, professional service. It's right in line with all of the other spots as far as price goes. Not cheap, but that's to be expected for this level of dining. If you have never been here it's a must try. Enjoy
author: James L.

description:
Loved my meal here!
Everything was delicious.
We started with the Beef Tartare and Yellowfin Crudo.
Tartare was already spread on 4 pieces of bread which made it a little soggy, but the flavors were great (a slight kick, but I am sensitive to spice) and the texture of the meat was just right.
I loved the melding of flavors of the yellowfin along with the Asian pear and fennel puree. Flavors were crisp and bright - very satisfying.
Middle course was the pork agnolotti. Reminded me of my travels and cooking classes in the Piedmont region of Italy! Lovely little pasta pockets in a cream sauce mixed with small cubes of pumpkin.
Main entree was the wagyu bavette steak, served in a cast-iron skillet pan, accompanied with shilling beans and baby carrots atop a savory bagna cauda (another fave from the Piedmont region). There was a pickled acidity to the vegetables, so it was key to mix with the bagna cauda.

Dessert was also fabulous. The chocolate custard was my favorite vs. the carrot cake. It was essentially a pot de creme with the right amount of salt on top, along with a canele of coffee ice cream and toasted almonds. Magic in your mouth! The carrot cake itself was good, but the goat cheese frosting was a bit too sour; the cilantro made for an interesting flavor angle. 

Would be happy to return many times!
author: Tina W.

description:
my friend had her bday party in the private room upstairs.  the room is amazing w/ vaulted ceilings and two big tables.  they allowed my friend to decorate the room, and it was really cute.  

the food and service were all great.  i liked the avocado salad a lot, as well as pumpkin tortellini.  for entrees, we had beef cheeks w/ whipped potatoes on the side, and the desert was a mason jar of chocolate custard, which was soooo good.  the wine was definitely flowing, which made for a tipsy night.
author: Helen T.

description:
Each bite was memorable. King Salmon Crudo, wow what a way to start. Wine selection was good with Hen and Agnolotti. 

Service was below the level of the food by several steps.
author: Rick A.

description:
The edge of the Misson bordering Potrero just got more interesting. We decided last minute to do a walk in even though we knew the reservations were full. After going to the side of the address, we found the large doors locked and that you should actually enter on 20th street. A reclaimed space has been spruced up with reclaimed wood, concrete floors, and many other industrial elements into a sleek new eatery of modern cuisine.

Looking at the wine list: Pineau des charenytes, Scholium Naucratis, Copain, Geverey Chambertin...interesting fantastic and concise wine list. Looking at the menu and knowing the chef's lineage we opted for the 5 course tasting menu:

-Celery granita, Meyer lemon soda
-Mini head cheese, ramp mayo 
-Vegetable Jelly, Sorrel, Salmon belly
-Caraway and oat bread
-Mussels/clams with bone marrow vinaigrette, turnips, horseradish
-Peas, Cheese curds, Rye crumble, grated walnut, walnut oil
-Abalone, ramps, artichoke, egg yolk
-Roasted duck breast, duck crepinette, chard, spring onions
-Fennel Sorbet and yogurt
-Jasmine tea ice crea, almond, grains of paradies

After a handful of dishes we could see David Kinch in the details, but that's not a surprise since the CDC is from Manresa. There seemed like some  Scandanavia in there as well, seeing things like peas and rye crumble. However I was mistaken and I later found the chef cooked at In De Wulf in Belgium under Kobe Desramault and at Mirazur under Mauro Colagreco. Of course both restaurants and their chef/owners are producing smoe of the most exciting progressive food in the world right now, and it shows in the menu here.  I don't know about you but that's more than 5 courses I counted and we weren't going to complain as it was all excellent. 

Service is warm and friendly. With it being the first day open, they flowed rather well at least when we were there.Sitting at the communal table allowed us to talk to a number of folks that came through as we kept getting courses. I think Saison has a kindred spirit nearby now doing high level food in a much more casual setting and lower price point. Excellent debut.
author: Kim N.

description: Now I am not a fancy eater and I usually like hole in the wall places but this place doesn't make it feel so stiff.  Our waiter was very knowledgeable about what we were eating and their drink selection (the most important thing).  This place is definitely a cute date night spot
author: Mary B.

description: Get the freshly baked mini baguette, glass of bubbly and the cheese and salumi platter.... And Bob's your uncle! A perfect brunch, no hassle parking and no lines!
author: Natalie B.

description: Central Kitchen is a wow wow wow.  Have been there twice and both times have loved the food.  The service is impeccable too.  Every dish is delicious.  One of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  You will not be disappointed.  From the moment you walk in, you're treat as a guest.  I've been lucky enough to have eaten at restaurants all over the world.  Central Kitchen is memorable.
author: Paul C.

description:
Before visiting Central Kitchen I thought it was just where people go if they can't get into Flour + Water. I was soo pleasantly surprised with the ambiance, friendly service, and delicious food.

I would define this place as "brunch that I can't make," which is becoming increasingly rare in San Francisco. I also appreciate that the restaurants takes reservations, which cuts down any ridiculous lines. The server was really competent and personable. 

I got the huevos which were really delicious. The french toast was yummy but tasted just like cake. It was waaay too sweet for brunch so I would recommend having it as a dessert if you're set on the idea. I would definitely recommend a side of potatoes. They were really crunchy and yummy. 

I would happily return!
author: Jasmine M.

description:
Went to Central Kitchen last night for the first time.  Cute space, hipster friendly (of which I know I am not), nice to be sitting in the open patio area.

Food was fine. I think San Francisco is filled with these kinds of restaurants.  Local food, no main-stream wine choices, etc.  Feels like they kind of run together.  

Would I go back?  Sure, if i'm in the area.  Again, the food was good.  Just wasn't sure what was special about this restaurant vs the 30 other that are serving similar food.
author: Tobin S.

description:
My husband and I were pretty disappointed with our experience.   We were celebrating his birthday and although it was really early dinner special time for us (because we were going out to an 8 pm show) and not that packed, it was super loud (due to the Pandora/Spotify soundtrack cranked up) and the service was haphazard (our dishes were handed to the table next to ours in front of our eyes) and the server didn't respond to requests.

We weren't very hungry, but order a chicory salad that was ok, small with about 4 croutons, decent Cowgirl creamery cheese, and then these very rubbery grilled pieces of persimmon.  It also had chive pieces.  Neither the chives or persimmons made sense and kind of collided with the other bitter and salty flavors.

Hearing that the pasta was good, we both ordered a pasta.  I am vegetarian, but also avoid rich browned butter and cheese so the only option for me was a Cavatelli with a hot pepper red sauce.  This small bowl appeared about 1/2 hour after the salad with what looked like food from a Star Trek Klingon dinner (I think it was called Klingon Gagh).  The Cavatelli described as "bean like" were ribbed and pretty much looked like a bunch of maggots in a bowl of red sauce.  It was not at all appetizing to look at.  Eating it revealed an uneven gummy mess that stuck to my teeth.  In addition, there were large pieces of garlic and some cracked spice that basically blew out your palate.  I ended up not eating it.

My husband had the chestnut torchio which he said was overcooked and kind of falling apart.  It was supposed to have brussel sprouts and he said he saw about 3 brussel sprout leaves -- so if you don't like brussel sprouts -- I guess this is the dish for you.

The best thing was the very lovely sparkling water and a delicious bottle of 2003 Pichon Longueville (a $300 bottle of wine retail) that we brought for a corkage fee of $25.    Everything is extra (two bread rolls are $6), portions are small, service is brusque.
author: Andrea P.

description: Very much enjoyed their pre fix menu for Valentine's Day 2017. Though it is a pricey restaurant, the quality and ambiance is all worth is as well as the service from hostess, waitress and staff was above & beyond. We will definitely be back and looking forward to it!
author: Bea A.

description: we've been here four times and i don't think we'll be back. the food has gone downhill. bland, unoriginal, tapas-sized portions at rather ridiculous prices. wtf did they do to their signature chocolate custard dessert? it's half the size and they changed the recipe! ugh.
author: Torrpedo T.

description:
We had a function here in October in the upstairs dining room loft.  We were really looking forward to having dinner here.  The venue  was spacious, with 2 large farm tables, sparse in decor but in a good way, clean and open, great neighborhood views  with windows all around. The candles were a great addition to the loft area. I would love to host a gathering at this venue.  

Service was good, server 1 of 3 was great about letting us know about the ingredients in each of our dishes and gave great detail about the wine being poured.  The other server was on the chilly side.  One of the guests had asked about some of the unfinished dishes that were being taken away and if we could take them home. The server replied, "sure, most people don't take them home, but I can save it for you."  Did she say that out loud? Yes, she did. 

I understand the concept about letting food shine on its own, tomatoes should taste like sweet fruit..etc., yes, agreed, but enhancing your ingredients with spices is good too.  Baba ganoush was bland maybe a little more lemon? Cowgirl cheese and preserves, always good.  But 2 tiny pieces for 4 people? Pork Pate was an overly, toasted fennel would have been a good addition . We found that the gem salad was bland, chicken breast, gamy, (poached?) and could have benefitted from something briny, like olives, figs or some citrus.  Best dishes, beet salad, pasta ragu. LIterally 1/4 cup of pasta for each person, some guests didn't get any. Portions were very small.  The best part of the meal was the chocolate custard and the wine pairings. Over all, great venue, good service, amazing wine and dessert, food and portions need attention.
author: Chris O.

description:
Wow. This place was awesome. We had so many dishes to share and every single dish was phenomenal. Raw hamachi, kale chips, beef tartar, asparagus, octopus with pork belly, hen, smoked cod...etc. All were amazing. Well presented. Visually appealing. Even the dessert was wonderful.  We had the guava sorbet and the chocolate mousse. What a delight. 

Just a tad on the pricey side for the portion size but otherwise, it was good. 

Well done.
author: Steve J.

description:
At first we were really excited to try this place having had a good experience at one of their sister restaurants, but overall we had a mixed dining experience:

Wagyu beef was delicious but the duck came out cold. The hummus with pine nuts felt like it missed some flavours. The goat cheese dessert and that was really good. But for the price you pay, you should expect for the food to be better quality. We also ordered two glasses of white wine and the waiter forgot to bring it to us. We had also asked for water and halfway through the main meal, I had to remind the waiter to give us our drinks. Some of the staff were friendly and others were not. The atmosphere in this place is amazing it felt very cozy and I loved the energy in the room. I wouldn't come back here for dinner but I will try brunch!
author: Esty Z.

description:
Lovely outdoor sitting in the courtyard,  friendly staff, but service was a bit slow.  
We went on  Tuesday night so it's not too crazy busy but my tea did not come with my dessert.   Matter of fact it came long after I asked our waitor for it and he said he was preparing it...I almost wonder if they ran out of hot water?  It finally arrived after my dessert was eaten and the plate was taken away.
For $5 just for a cup of tea, not a pot litterally one cup, I suggest you skip the tea and have an apperatif or a cappuccino.  Perhaps it will arrive sooner as it did for the table next to me.
Overall though it's a 3 and a half star experience. I have to check it out due to all the rave, but it's done and over with.  I won't be back anytime soon.  Have other places to try.
Check out Trick Dog next door if you have time to wait for a mixology cocktail. Long wait but it will worth it!
author: Toni L.

description:
I came here for Brunch so I may have run into a different sort of experience...but beside the long wait (we were quoted 25 minutes but it turned to 50!), the food here was solid. They had more than your usual eggs/Benedict choices..

My friend got the Ratatouille and I got a Hamachi Salad..both were AMAZING and exploding in flavor. For $15 a person, we were each pretty satisfied!

The ambiance is rustic but cozy and inviting. Most tables are for parties of 2 or 4, but we did see about two groups of 6 inside who had made prior arrangements.

I'd love to come back for their dinner menu...it looks delish!
author: Veronica S.

description: The food was amazing. All the dishes we ordered were good, but I wished there was more of a selection for vegetarians. The fried green tomatoes were one of my favorite renditions of a classic southern dish. The duck was perfectly cooked and the olive oil chiffon was a nice light dish to finish off the meal. Unfortunately since the charred onions (which were tasty but not very filling) were the only veggie entree, the vegetarian was hungry a little while later. Service was friendly and efficient. If you plan to eat without a reservations, I recommend you try for an early-ish dinner before 7pm as the walk-in seating fills up quickly.
author: Dani D.

description:
About as good as it gets... Fantastic Service, the Bread, menu and water was
on the table B4 I could get my coat off, and the Bread just kept on coming. We shared 4 apps.
and ALL were Excellent, Trout, Roast calamari, Beet Salad and Mackrell (ok...)
we'll be back for the Large Plates. Very friendly, nice space...
author: Peter J.

description: Every single thing we ate was memorable and wonderful.  Burrata and fry bread, yes! The brussel sprouts were amazing with peanut and other flavors sneaking through. The avocado salad melted in your mouth.  The pasta with braised pork actually left me speechless and desiring a bucketful of it to go. And I am not even a dessert person but that chocolate custard was fabulous.  Shared everything, portions were small and we needed more bread (which they could perhaps offer gratis?) Wine recommendation was spot on and wonderful.   I also enjoyed watching the chefs cook all night long!
author: Pinky T.

description:
My 1000th review! It's been tough to choose what amazing SF spot to feature as my 1000th review and Central Kitchen somewhat got "lucky." They deserve 5 stars for sure and are fresh on my mind since I just finished a great meal there. I owe Piccino an amazing review and will write that soon but, for now, here is number 1000... 

Let's start with the atmosphere. The interior space is beautiful - there is a lot of foliage and even a vine creeping up one wall. There is also a fountain including a big, pretty industrial pipe. Parts of the ceiling is made of windows (not skylights per say since bigger areas of glass) and it's beautiful to see the night sky up above. There are also relaxing, large lights strung from the rafters. As a friend noted to me before I went, the music was perfect (which I find restaurants often get wrong) - the likes of the Lumineers and the Rolling Stones. I ended up picking up the dinner tab since I bet my bf that Wild Horses was by someone other than the Rolling Stones... anyway... 

We were tempted by the tasting menu but opted to go a la carte since there were some meaty things on the tasting menu which I wouldn't have loved. We started with the fried pickles with dipping sauce ($6) which were delicious and a generous portion. Next we enjoyed the melons, cucumber, and avocado salad (around $12) with a fig yogurt sauce. This also impressed. Our final appetizer was the raw tuna (around $14) which was also featured on tonight's tasting menu. We shared the halibut with olive main and the fish was grilled to perfection. We ate every last bite (and forkfuls of sauce) of every single dish.

For drinks, we enjoyed 3 glasses of red wine ($11 -  $15) between the two of us. Our waitress knew the wines well and made good suggestions (though I've never heard a wine described as "chewy," this description did seem appropriate for one glass we had). For dessert, we ordered the chocolate mousse (or pudding)  ($10)- it came in a cute jar and had delicious layers including salted almonds, coco nib ice cream, and a chocolate madeleine. We also shared the small french press of Mr. Espresso coffee ($4). As I mentioned earlier, I picked up the tab but I wouldn't have made the wager had I not been willing to pay. The food was great and worth it so it was a perfect meal to treat my great (and myself) to!
author: Meghan P.

description: Friendly staff, service can lag a little sometimes when its slow. The cocktails on tap are fun and the porchetta is one of the best I've had in the city.
author: Ashleigh P.

description:
We were trying to go to Flour + Water, and with the 2.5 hour wait and a packed Trick Dog, wandered into Central Kitchen. No wait!

Service was great, very friendly, but also calm. The space is very cool and open, half indoor / outdoor setup with free flowing air. It's not too loud and easy to carry on a quiet conversation. 

Onto the Food: 

1. MISSION FIGS - blue cheese. coppa di testa on the side. DELICIOUS. I obviously skipped the meat portion, but the creamy preparation of the blue cheese with the fig is wow. 

2. MELON & BURRATA - japanese cucumber. fennel pollen. cute presentation, but missing the punch. A little rock salt / spice / acid would have knocked it out of the park. 

3. SQUASH MALTAGLIATI - smoked crème fraîche. aleppo. sunflower seed. One of the BEST PASTA dishes I have evvvvver had. The fresh pasta was so crisp and the sauce was unbelievably flavorful. I cleaned my plate (which has happened 5x in all of history) and could eat this every day. 

4. V got the KING SALMON - pepper panade. potatoes. boquerones. It was average and he liked my dish much more. Don't be foolish, order the Squash.
author: Dimple B.

description:
Central Kitchen started brunch, so I had to try it! They take reservations, so be sure to make one and save yourself the good hour it'll take you to get through the line.

The decor is fantastic and very reminiscent of Foreign Cinema, if I might add. Open and airy, the space creates an illusion of the outdoors, and is even more inviting on a warm, sunny day. 

I ordered the french toast bread pudding, and it was DEE-LICIOUS. Too bad I finished it with a swiftness! 

Beware: portions are small. I wish I had known that prior to ordering. The french toast breading seemed like a steal for $7, but it definitely was 1/2 a portion. If you're super hungry, it's best to supplement with another item. My friend's ordered some of the more expensive entrees ranging from $13-$17, but interestingly, the portions weren't much bigger. 

P.S. Parking is fairly easy in the area.
author: Mansi A.

description:
I cannot understand why the rating on this place is so mediocre.  Maybe because they share ownership with other nameless, yet hard-to-get-into, yet popular and yummy restaurants?  The only bad thing I can say about this place was the little bit of wait we had to deal with even though we had a reservation that was quite late in the evening.  It wasn't even that big of a deal.  We ordered a bottle of wine and they gladly poured us some glasses while we sat by the indoor waterfall and waited it out.

The food was pretty darn good.  We had already had a previous "first dinner" so four of us shared 2 apps and 2 entrees.  It was perfect.  I highly recommend checking this place out for the food and the decor alone.  The ambience is perfect for a date night out.  It's sure to impress.

What's this I hear about pretzel bread pudding?  It wasn't on our menu this time around :(
author: Kevin J.

description:
We had brunch here which was tasty.  I really liked the baked eggs in faro.  The fried chicken eggs Benedict were good.  Nothing was dramatically  amazing but it was all solid.

Maybe it was just brunch but you could tell their chef/customer has a sweet tooth.  Just about all the morning cocktails were sweet and the peach sticky bun was good but almost too sweet to get down.  Not bad necessarily just not for me.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Interesting place with an interesting menu. I've seen complaints about the service- ours happened to be excellent last night. The menu was very limited and a little to "To cool for School"/esoteric  for my tastes. Don't expect to find the food that's displayed on the menu on Yelp when you get there.

Right next door is the Trick Dog Bar and Grill where everyone seemed to take themselves much less seriously (and had much more fun than we had at dinner:)
author: RJ J.

description:
I went to the restaurant last night. Atmosphere was great but I was disappointed about the waitress was not up to the speed. We have to wait for menu. And then finally we plane the order for food but they only bought a wine for my boyfriend and I had to wait for another 15 min to get my wine.
The food was overall okay but felt over price. . The pork patté was a bit harder. I would describe it was like the meatloaf. 
Now days you can try the similar restaurant around the town. So I would go others.
author: Kiyoko M.

description:
Nice place. I like the space. I would come for coffee or  dessert.
The dinner we had was just sub par.
Not enough seasoning and very bland. Service was just ok. We kept asking for water and refills on wine/beer. 
Very loud so bring your hearing aids. Many other great places in San Francisco to eat. Won't be back.
I wonder if they kitchen test their food??
author: Alison W.

description:
I came in last weekend for some brunch was wasn't just satisfied, I was _blown_ _away_.

I ordered the Fried Chicken Eggs Benedict and the fried chicken managed to offer sublime servings of crunchy fried batter along with superbly cooked, moist chicken, and the juxtaposition of those two along with the solid seasoning came together to create a perfect storm right there on my tongue.

Mixing this delicious fried chicken with the accompanying over-easy eggs and their sauce made for an even more complex mix of flavors, each offering a substantive flavor but not overpowering any of the others. The balance in this dish was phenomenal.

We also ordered a Grilled Peach Sticky Bun, and it offered up chewy-soft dough with a smattering of sweet peach and cinammon and just enough of a creamy ricotta to balance it out. The bacon really served to bring out the other flavors.

The Pork Sugo's garbanzo beans were expertly seasoned, and provided a nice departure from the Southern feel of my Fried Chicken Benedict dish and the Sticky Bun.

The staff is friendly and helpful, and the interior design of the space is very modern and inviting, and our bill from brunch came to less than $40/pp. I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Cameron N.

description:
I came to this place for brunch. Very airy atmosphere with a lot of cross air circulation and plenty of light. The perfect start to a saturday.

Both my friend and I had the same dish: baked eggs. tomato. eggplant. ricotta salata. rosemary toast. I really liked the rich flavors of the dish. the baked eggs could be a bit less cooked, but the balance of the ingredients was impeccable that one needs to come back soon to experience it again.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Booked through an Open Table email touting "Sustainable Seafood Week" claiming restaurants listed  - including Central Kitchen - were serving special seafood dishes featuring sustainable seafood. When we asked the server, she looked befuddled but said the "chefs try to use it on the menu". Hmmm. Maybe don't sign up for promos if you aren't going to do them. 

Food was ok, some dishes very good but others not so much. A lot going on in each dish... sauces! foam! crumbles! sprigs! composée! I'm kind of over the fussy stuff so I would have liked it better if they simplified. Very tiny menu so don't go if you are a picky eater. 

Second room is freezing so bring a parka or ask to be seated in the first room, which might be warmer. Took a triumvirate to discuss if our request to move closer to the open kitchen for warmth would be fulfilled. 

It's funny, I threw a private dinner in their Salumeria two years ago and everything was top-notch. Not sure what happened along the way??
author: Andi S.

description: We adore Central Kitchen. It's our favorite neighborhood spot because of the seasonal menu (lots of great vegetables!), great wine list and friendly staff. The pastas are especially tasty.
author: Liza B.

description:
Had read about Central Kitchen and was excited to finally try it out. Walked in the door - the space is beautiful. But the first thing I noticed was the music was so loud I could hardly converse with friends even before being seated. 

We were quickly seated in a cozy corner table and ordered drinks. The house cocktail I ordered tasted like spoiled orange juice so I sent it back. The waitress apologized but didn't really make me feel like she cared. The appetizers were pretty good. I ordered the porchetta to share - I love pork! It came in a huge slab, barely warm, and wasn't that flavorful. My friend's steak was lukewarm as well. 

The thing that bothered me most though was the volume of the music. During the whole meal I struggled to hear the conversation because the music was so incredibly loud. I left feeling hoarse because of how loud I had to talk. 

It was an okay meal but I definitely won't be going back. And when I go out to eat with friends, part of the magic is being able to have engaging conversation. But I can't do that if I canny even hear what they're saying.
author: David W.

description:
In terms of dinner (I have not gone there for brunch), this place may be best for a special occasion where you are willing to spend a good amount of money on a good amount of food. That said, the food is delicious! 

Their menu is on the smaller side as it is carefully curated. They offer a selection of small bites (pork pate wrapped in prosciutto and served with rustic bread and nectarines - yum!), medium sized plates (pasta dishes, salads) and entree-sized plates. The wine list is extensive and the ambiance is really lovely. Additionally, the wait staff was very knowledgeable, asked if anyone at the table had any food allergies, and easily modified a few dishes to accommodate those asks. Safe to say the flavors of the meals were not at all compromised.

We went pretty early (around 5:45) and it wasn't crowded and provided a nice romantic ambiance where you could hear each other speak.
author: Courtney B.

description:
- ABUNDANT wine list
- TINY menu
- No spirits, just beer and wine
- Server was cute and attentive
- The house butter tastes weird 
- I did not remove my coat as it was fairly cold
- The bar next door looks more fun
- A bit of overpriced
author: Sarah W.

description:
have visited two times. First time was very good - porchetta is delicious. Second time was hit and miss, but mostly miss. More specifically:

- bread and butter is good but that's easy
- 4 glasses of wine: 1 was good, 1 decent, 1 mediocre, 1 was terrible and had to be returned. Waitress (who was nice and offered to replace) mentioned that the manager really didn't like that wine (why put it on the list?). Replacement wine was ok not that great either.
- 2 salads: burrata and mellon is ok; mushroom and figs is not that good.
- 2 pastas: maltagliati is lame. Agnolotti was fantastic.
- desserts: good chocolate thinger (forgot exact name), mediocre carrot cake.

nice ambiance, good service, super pricey. All in all too many misses for a great grade.
author: Fred A.

description: We ate dinner at Central Kitchen on a Friday night, which was the second day after their new remodel. The parking god was smiling on us. I got a parking space almost in front and without circling the block forever. Everything was seasoned perfectly. We were a party of five with one 3 y.o. I asked the host if there were any seat cushions-my flat hardwood chairs was torturing my under padded glutes. The host never got back to me. My daughter had to go to her car and bring me a blanket to sit on. The Cappellacci dei Briganti ($20) was delicious but too small a serving for the price. We all raved over our Butter Lettuce Salad, especially the dressing. Bread is not free ($6) for 4 slices of sourdough. The highlight of our dinner was the wood grilled pork chop for two ($58) which was perfectly grilled and accompanied with Guajillo Au Jus. We were celebrating a birthday and were disappointed with the dessert choices-no cake, bread pudding or Tira Misu? We settled for a bowl of vanilla bean ice cream with peaches and a plate of blue berries & creme with crushed sesame, granola type crusts sprinkled on top (meh). The restrooms are not still under construction so we had to share a unisex bathroom while the remodel is still being done. I would give 4 Stars if the portions were better and the chairs were more comfortable. The highlight of our dinner was the wood grilled pork chop. With drinks, tip, our tab was $213. I doubt if we will return to the Central Kitchen soon.
author: Kailey W.

description:
Loved.  Everything was very fresh.  Nice twist on ingredients.  They managed to surprise us with the preparations.  Great selection of dessert wines. 

Complaints: The mussel and Brussels sprout dish was over dressed.  Tight spaces...we were too close to our neighbors and it's really loud.
author: Amy J.

description:
This review is for the Sunday brunch:

As others have mentioned, it's relatively easy to make brunch reservations at Central Kitchen and now I know why. As far as location (next door to Trick Dog) and decor/design, this place does it right. I loved the indoor/outdoor concept and the space is unique/open/social.

At first glance, I was surprised at the price of the brunch menu items and this is significant because I truly don't mind spending more for quality, ambiance, even trendiness to a certain extent. The brunch portions are reasonably sized, but with that being said, this isn't the place to go if you are looking for a hearty meal. I had the Mission Huevos and thought the dish was excellent, though unquestionably overpriced. 

Our waiter was attentive, but I do have to say that I felt rushed and for that reason I wouldn't come back with a group. Central Kitchen is not the place to go for a leisurely, boozy brunch, but luckily it's the Mission and there's no lack of suitable options nearby.
author: Maya C.

description:
Came here for brunch, Open Table had wide-open reservations which was awesome!  We even moved our reservation 45 mins later, then showed up 30 mins early, and they still seated us. Not many people inside, which we found interesting for a Sunday Brunch. Service was fast, and helpful. We were in and out of there in 1hr. 

Couldn't decide between Fried Eggs with oxtail, spring onion and hollandaise, or Poached Eggs with Polenta, pork belly, trumpets and carrots.  I asked the waitress, and she recommended the Poached eggs.  Low and behold, the table next to us had ordered the Fried eggs. They were small, barely any oxtail on it, and I just sighed with relief that I didn't get it!!!!

My bf and I started off with the sticky bun - so delicious. It was huge, soggy and happy looking. It was very saucy from the icing, and had bits of bacon in it!  We also started off with the fresh oysters - so delicious with the Meyer Lemon and ginger *__*

Then my Poached eggs came....it was so beautiful!  It looked so much more hearty than the fried eggs the table next to me had!!!  The combo of polenta with trumpet mushrooms and arugula, smeared with poached eggs was so wonderful. It was filling and TOTALLY worth the money (unlike fried eggs).  My bf ordered the baked eggs with Chorizo stew - also very delicious. it had a slight kick in it too. 

Would love to try the dinner tasting menu next!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I love going to Central Kitchen for brunch, mostly because of the divine brunch burger. It's the only thing I've ever had, as a matter of fact. The beef is so tender and cooked to perfection, and the fried egg on top has always been delightfully runny and peppery. Honestly one of the best burgers I've had in SF. Period. Pairs great with the Pacifica (aka "make your own mimosas").
author: Jeff S.

description:
Best ambiance, service and food in SF.


Sat outside on a perfect SF Saturday night. Stevie Wonder playing over the speakers. 
Had the strawberry fennel ricotta which was out of this world. The porcetta for 2 was 5 stars - yummy and fun with all the accompaniments. Great wine list.

Perfect night. Definitely go here! Order anything and u will not be disappointed.

Try a drink next door at Trick Dog before.
author: KJ G.

description:
Came here for dinner with my gal pal and it was absolutely HEAVENLY!  We were starving, ate like kings, loved the atmosphere (want to live there), and we high-five'd each other when we were done.  

--ricotta and pickled vegetables:  DELISH.  We almost got another one!
--carrots and satsuma: delish, again!
--romanesco and brussels: delish, my goodness, again!!!
--potato tortelli: really tasty and savory and kind of hard to explain
--three cheeses: awesome
--chocolate custard: run, do not walk
--"gardens of babylon" red by the glass: nom nom nom

I don't have the patience to deal with reservation system at State Bird.  (But I'm sure it's good).  For now, I will stick with Central Kitchen and Range for my go-to's for yummy California Cuisine in an elegant setting.
author: Bobbie J.

description: The food was yummy but it was all served kind of lukewarm. I got the octopus mid-course and the trout as a main. Both were very flavorful but because the octopus had lost a lot of heat, it seemed more chewy than chard. And again, the fish was also really yummy but I lose a lot of the flavor if it's not a nice hot temp.
author: Julia W.

description:
I was very underwhelmed by our experience at Central Kitchen last night.

We had a party of 10 to celebrate a birthday. The reservation was made a week or so in advance and we were told for parties of 8 or more, everyone will need to do the tasting menu @$89/pp. My friend who coordinated the dinner had to speak to someone different than the hostess because of a larger party. He had a lot of trouble getting hold of the person to confirm certain food allergy issues we had within our group. Even on the day of the dinner, he had to call multiple times to confirm the allergy issues will be taken care of. We finally got confirmation...but it was not taken care of.

We were promptly seated at 6pm. The restaurant is cute and cozy. But upon arrival, it was approximately 90 degrees inside. We asked the server if they can turn the heat down or off, she said yes. but nothing happened. Eventually my friend asked again later, and it was finally turned off.

First issue of the night was the two different tasting menus that was given to us. Both menus had the same date printed on, and everything on the menus were the same except for the meat entree. We confirmed with our server and she said one of the menu was yesterdays. I was disappointed because i was looking forward to the duck entree.

Second issue of the night was their extreme lack of attention to details. The one person who had food allergies (nuts and shellfish) was repeatedly offered dishes that contained nuts. After a few dishes, he had to ask the server what's in each dish and reconfirm that there were no nuts. 

The food was mediocre. I thought a few dishes was a bit too salty. The server would explain what each dish was to the first person they serve it to, but then not to the rest of the party. A few of us had to look at the menu to see what dish was being served.

I think this restaurant definitely has potential, but from our experience, it's not worth trying.
author: Terry C.

description: Food is fine but way too overpriced for the amount of food given. For half the price or twice the food I would give a better rating. Given unreasonably high prices (carrot appetizer for $18!!!!!), bread was one of the best parts. I am willing to spend money on nice/fancy restaurants, the value isnt here though. No need to come back any time soon.
author: Farrah L.

description:
What am I missing? Why is this place so hip? I am at a loss. We went there two weeks ago with another couple. I will not be back. 

The food was mediocre at best. Tiny little plates, expensive and nothing to write home about. The cod was fishy and not interesting.  The cheese was not interesting. Duck was ordinary. There was not one interesting plate. We are both crazy about good food. And we are not impressed by food here. 

We sat at the patio. We were sitting right next to each other and we can't hear each other. The music was so loud. We requested the waitress to turn it down. The music got turned down only to go back up again. We requested to be moved to a different table. My wife and I still missed half the conversation in a table of four because of the crazy loudness of music. I can not be the only one complaining about this. Maybe this was specific to that one night or maybe this is an ongoing issue. I am not sure. 

Last thing that tipped the balance for us was the bill was so super high that my wife and I left the restaurant and said to each other "what the heck is going on". We decided to go over the bill as we were walking to our car. We drank two bottles of wine. They charged us for three. They charged us double for one of the two bottles we ordered. I immediately went back to the restaurant and asked them to correct it. And they did. 

The only positive thing I can say (other than nice setting) is that the wine menu is great. I ordered a Premier Cru Burgundy and a Nebbiolo. Both were absolutely fantastic. 

We had a wonderful time because of the company. We were with interesting, fun people. But we will not be back again.
author: bora o.

description:
Love the ambiance and the style of this place. It's like a modern take on an urban cottage yet still rustic. The food and its presentation definitely matched the theme as well.

We ordered:

Duck Rice Croquettes - a bit odd because of the dried meat shavings that were sprinkled on top. The croquette itself was delicious but the garnish gave it a sandy texture and made it look unappetizing. 

Liver Pate - Damn this is the cutest pâté jar I've ever seen. It's like a terrarium but for meat. The radishes and layers of jam, fat, and liver were great. I've had better pate but presentation is just killer.

Seared Tuna - Perfectly cooked fish that almost had a buttery texture. I felt the dish itself was a bit small and veggies included didn't really add or compliment the tuna.

Hen - Chicken was seasoned and cooked really well. The meat was perfectly pink but again I just wanted more food. 

Squid - Again well cooked and plated. But just missing something, Je ne sais quio. Perhaps a sauce, salt, or bigger portions. Ugh!

Ice Cream for dessert - Wasn't on the menu but our server was nice enough to accommodate us. This was our highlight of the meal. A (small) scoop each of basil, fig, coffee, and peach. Each were garnished with either a graham or chocolate cookie.

Service was awesome. Wine and Beer for drinks only but there's a bar right next door. I want to like this place... I really do. It's like finally going on a date with that cute girl you always liked but you're just realizing something is just a little off about her and you don't know what it is. The food left something to be desired. Presentation is amazing but there seemed to be a miss with everything. Don't fret girl, I might come back for Brunch. I want to give you another chance...
author: Charlie L.

description:
First of all the waitress was amazingly knowledgeable. And my meal was good. Amazing sunchoke soup and good Cod. . . nice dessert. And the ricotta cheese appetizer was heaven. I was pretty happy. 

My friend was really hungry and was disappointed when I didn't want to order the PORCHETTA for two. $80. He's a big eater, and it didn't surprise me when he decided to order it for himself. 

It was, in a word: horrible. I've never seen so much fat on a plate. He was confused and kept trying to find the meat in the fat. If we would have shared it we would have both starved. $80?? Granted there were amusing accoutrements/accompaniments to the dish, but if The Emperor Has No Clothes were a dish, this would be it. 

We kept wondering "do some people just eat the fat??" He's too nice and wouldn't say anything. I would have sent it back. He also noticed the pours on the wine were really light. 

This place can be really intimidating: total foodie place. But we eat in some pretty amazing places all over town and all over the world. It was his birthday dinner, so I didn't want to say anything, but when the check came and with tip it was almost $300. . . well I decided to take it to Yelp. 

It confirmed my impression of Central Kitchen after eating there three times now: when it's good it's AMAZING, but when it misses it really misses. Tonight, for us, it really missed.
author: Mark M.

description: Start with the Charred onion soup, get the Duck breast and well... We're waiting for the Wagyu now, but I'm sure it will be Deeeelicious.
author: Ji Young L.

description:
Great ambience, good food, but very limited entree choices 

Cheese platter: highly recommend. Very good lavosh with honey- to die for. The 3 cheeses were not very memorable but tasty

Speck platter: we convinced our server to get us some speck from their charcuterie next door. yummy

The entree choices were VERY limited: only 4. 
Nothing stood out for me which was very disappointing. 
So i just decided to get 2 appetizers 

The desserts were tasty: Apple confit Napolean- yummy. White choc on milk choc with dark cho- delicious
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night.  We had a reservation, so we were seated promptly.  My friend and I decided to split a few items, and so after reviewing the menu, we settled on: the Wagyu beef tartare, the charred brassicas, and the pot roast.  I was a little worried about the portions based on the other reviewers' comments, but I was actually pleasantly surprised.

Everything we had was really tasty.  I think my favorite was the charred brassicas; the dungeness crab broth was a really interesting and nice touch.  The pot roast was cooked to perfection and full of flavor.  And although it's not my favorite dish, I have to admit that I really enjoyed the tartare.

We brought our own bottle of wine (corkage fee is $20), and wound up paying about $60 each, including tax and a 20% tip.  I'd definitely come back!
author: Michael D.

description:
The food here is very good, but given the price and the competition in the area I'm rounding down to 3 stars. We wandered in here after being told it would be a 3 hour wait at flour + water!! Luckily we were seated immediately. Their menu changes constantly so I was bummed that all of the things that sounded great from the yelp reviews were not available.

It also means I cant check the menu to remember everything we got. We got the chicken liver mousse, which was good but sweeter than I expected. We also got an appetizer with yogurt, radishes and I think quinoa. I really enjoyed that and would definitely get it again. The bread was very good but very small. I could have eaten 3 more!

My entree was a pork belly dish. It was good but not very memorable as I cant really recall what was on my plate. One of my friends ordered the cod and it was good but also not anything that memorable. I think the appetizers were more interesting than the entrees. 

While everything was well executed and tasty, I thought that the entrees could have been more interesting. I had trouble picking a dish because the night we went nothing really jumped out at me, but since the menu changes so often it seems like they definitely have other dishes that sound great. I'd be pretty interested to try the salumeria.
author: Lainy C.

description: Awwww man.  Had one of the best meals out I've had in a long time.  We had dinner and chose the chef's tasting menu. The food was amazing and there wasn't one dish that wasn't excellent.  Some standouts were the beef tartare with fried pork tendon, mushroom ravioli, and the absolute highlight was the duck.  Chef Robin managed to serve the best duck I've ever had.  Perfectly tender with fat rendered to just the right level such that each bite had just the right combination of meat with smoky salty fat.  Sooo good.  I really enjoy how the food has evolved over the past months since he's started. Looking forward to many more delicious meals at Central Kitchen.
author: Christopher Y.

description:
Front of the house service was sooooo poor.

I am a big foodie and I had been looking forward to trying this restaurant for a long time. I made reservations two months in advance and my group of 4 got there 10 minutes early. They told us the table wasn't ready but to grab a drink because it will be 15 or so (next door to Trickdog which I love but you can't bring the drink back).

We got a drink, checked back in after finishing it and then they said it would be another 15-20 or so. Since we had already finished our drinks we waited near the host stand. 45 minutes went by.

We were forced to check in multiple times because no one was communicating with us. We asked to speak to the manager but no manager ever came. We were sat 1 hour after we had originally checked in. The fact that nothing was explained or done for us was absurd.

To top it all off the pork option that we got all fat and 7/8 of the plate was basically inedible. 

No apologies from the host, no presence of a manager. So disappointed.
author: Alexa B.

description: Always a solid bet for a good romantic ambiance and decent food. That being said, I've never walked away from CK with a feeling of "WOW that food was so memorable!" So I mostly go here for the ambiance and when I can't get a reservation anywhere in my other top choices in the city. Their chef's menu is very delicious if you are looking for a fun experience and diversity.
author: Wei W.

description: Enjoyed a fantastic and enjoyable meal here celebrating a friend's birthday. We opted for the tasting menu at $75/pp. This ended up including hummus, pork pâté, beef tartare, Josey Baker sourdough, halibut crude, ricotta agnolotti, roasted duck breast, and a dessert (forget what it is called). This tasting menu had a great progression of flavored and seemed to be a really good value for the money. Good wine list. Love the ambiance of this place. Great for a special occasion. Definitely will be back.
author: Patrick F.

description:
Had a great meal last night. Excellent service. Phenomenal food. Opted for the tasting menu ($75). Highly recommend. 

Btw - The Salumeria (shares same space) offers a fun lunch menu. Tombo salad is a winner.
author: craig g.

description:
(See pics) Review #1195. Creative California cuisine and good drinks, somewhat slow service (opening night chaos) but friendly staff to ease the waiting.

Note that the location is hard to find at night since the address and door are on Florida Street but the entrance is actually on 20th Street and is right at the corner. Also quite hard to find parking so plan more time beforehand.

Food wise, while the a la carte menu looked mighty interesting, we decided to take a chance with the grand opening night night tasting menu just to make the Thursday more interesting.

*-*-* Food *-*-*
5 courses of small bites that were California style, meaning fresh ingredients in small bites and in MMM / creative / interesting / risky moves:

Soda mix with celery and almond milk - risky since it was a bit too bubbly and sweet, not quite a palate cleanser.

Vegetable Jelly with salmon bite - risky as the jelly was bland to a bitter finish. The salmon was the savior to bring back the flavor.

Head cheese (grilled pork) on bite size toast - interesting and good starter.

Mussels/clams with bone marrow vinaigrette - interesting concept and while presented quite pretty, the mussels and clams did not taste too fresh.

Peas with cheese - MMM totally amazing broth and very delicious peas that were vibrant green and were perfectly cooked. The broth was really, really good.

Abalone with egg yolk - interesting abalone with decent delicate delicious taste. The egg yolk? not so sure if it's the best ingredient to complement as the egg had a strong rich taste. Also, the green onions were a bit stem-y to chew on though it was pretty and more like a garnish.

Roasted duck breast, as well as minced / pate style style with spring onions - creative and interesting as the 4 slices were good and lighter taste, contrary to common fattier taste. The minced piece was happy fatty greasy. This dish had the best wine pairing.

Fennel Sorbet with yogurt - interesting with very light fennel. Good palate cleanser.

Jasmine tea ice cream with chopped nuts - interesting with strong jasmine what tasted like small tapioca at the bottom and chopped nuts. Good sweetness and not too sugary.

Chocolates - MMMMMMM the best with the liquid center flowing in your mouth.

Parting gift - MMMMM cocoa mini brownies so good like you were eating cocoa beans. So good.

*-*-* Wines *-*-*
No liquor and the wine by the glass were on the inexpensive side:

Rose from Broc Cellars on tap - too sweet and might be good as a dessert wine on its own.

Savennieres (similar to Chenin Blanc) - good as a pre-dinner drink on the light chilled sweet style.

Cold heaven Viognier - very good to drink just on its own with its refreshing crisp taste. Great pairing with food.

Burgenland and Sangiovese - both good food pairing for the duck dish.

*-*-* Service *-*-*
Opening night chaos. Wait time in between courses was about 20 to 30 mins. Wines got a bit too warm to drink but quickly learned to order only when food arrived. Friendly smiles from servers who were trying to keep up with the busy restaurant. Service was progressively friendlier as the crowd got smaller and they were a bit less stressed out. The whole crew was nice and came around talking to the customers. And even it was way past their bedtime and after 3+ hours there, and it was almost 1am, they never rushed us.

*-*-* Ambiance *-*-*
We sat outside at the patio where there were a few nice toasty heat lamps from above blasting. I loved it as it was getting chilly but the cloudless pitch dark sky was clear.
