You can see through the half covered wooden style with the soft glowing light, and with the fountain that has a comical pipe mouth (rather than a cute naked sculpture) and broken pieces of ceramics in the bottom. This waiting area offers a great spot waiting while you sip on your vino. The bathroom was through the ugly bright green hallway that seemed to be out of place. Might be better to cover with wooden / velvet / beads curtains or some other less harsh colors.

Music got much better late at night past midnight when it was switched from slightly pop upbeat music to O V Wright. This was where this patio style was the best to enjoy in, swirling your vino gazing into the crisp air sky and get intoxicated in the moment.

*-*-* Tidbits *-*-*
We were told they plan to start doing retail (house made pasta) at the outside space. No affiliation of the style to F + W (have not eaten there.) This is definitely a local California sustainable style restaurant.
author: T L.

description:
I had a great experience for brunch here - interesting and creative dishes (so not your standard fare of pancakes and scrambled eggs), nice atmosphere, and they take reservations so you don't have do the typical 2 hour wait (ahem, Plow, Zazie, and almost every other brunch place in SF) 

I went with 2 other people and we did everything family style, which was great - I'd highly recommend sharing dishes so you can get some savory and some sweet.  They also rotate different dishes in and out of their menu (or substitute different seasonal ingredients)

Warm Cinnamon Sticky Bun with bacon, dates, and walnuts ($7) - Delicious sticky bun. I wanted to eat all of it, but had to share with my dining companions. Soft, chewy, and not overly sweet. I couldn't really taste the bacon though. This is the most expensive sticky bun I've ever bought, but it was worth it.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mq9l0EKCDyuwvyAC5OmaqQ?select=H0Bm7sOPpF5_YVqv52e_JA#H0Bm7sOPpF5_YVqv52e_JA

Pretzel Bread, Bread Pudding ($8) - This was good; almost dessert like. The portions were a little small and there were 5 or 6 bite sized pieces in the entire plate. I thought it would have crunchy pretzel pieces mixed in, but it didn't.  Good, but typical bread pudding.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mq9l0EKCDyuwvyAC5OmaqQ?select=zoa1nl34BRSQ9I70c-4BcA#zoa1nl34BRSQ9I70c-4BcA

Salmon Crudo - I can't remember how much this was, probably $13 or $14 and I didn't take a picture of this one. This was also good, but nothing to write home about. The salmon was tasty, but I could've done without this plate.

Baked eggs, chorizo, sweet potato hash, cilantro ($14)
I liked this dish - if you order it, get it a side of bread to go with it, because it will compliment it nicely. It was the right amount of spicy from the chorizo, and the eggs were baked so that the inside was runny. It was a tad bit on the oily / watery side, and the sweet potatoes were in cubes (not fried and crispy), but overall, it had great flavor. I don't know if I would necessarily order it again if I came, since I'd like to try other things.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mq9l0EKCDyuwvyAC5OmaqQ?select=gPpTztOMWLPEG8VnogQhfQ#gPpTztOMWLPEG8VnogQhfQ

Poached eggs, polenta and crispy meat ($14) - This was by far everyone's favorite dish at the table. If there's some kind of variation of this dish when you come for brunch, you should get it. I'm not sure if it was fried chicken or pork on the dish, but it was delicious, and perfectly crispy. The eggs and polenta were just right and I've been thinking about this dish ever since eating it this morning. A not-to-miss! I'd definitely get this dish over and over again, and keep coming back here to eat this.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mq9l0EKCDyuwvyAC5OmaqQ?select=1VkBkzEPkGzV5_xR2p-cQw#1VkBkzEPkGzV5_xR2p-cQw

All in all, a great experience: no wait in line (make reservations at least 3-4 weeks in advance), nice atmosphere, and innovative dishes. One of SF's newest brunch places, and I hope it's here to stay. Price for the meal was about $25 per person, excluding tip.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place definitely has potential to be a 4 or 5 star recommendation, but unfortunately not for my first experience.  I will definitely give it another try. 

I went for dinner on an early Thursday evening, and was greeted promptly and taken to my table. My server was pleasant and I ordered a lovely red while I looked over the menu, which is somewhat limited as is the menu for beer and wines by-the-glass. No matter, everything sounded delicious, and the atmosphere was open and relaxing. 

I ordered the corn agnolotti, and it was delivered very quickly and presentation was well done.  One bite in though, and I was a little disappointed. The flavor was a little on the unremarkable side, and a bit salty. It wasn't bad, just not up to either the hype or price. In addition, after my entrée was delivered I did not see my server for at least 20 minutes...a small problem but all the same disappointing as I wanted another glass of wine and a little bread (that they provide on request).

After the aforementioned 20 minutes another server showed up and took over, but without explanation. I ordered my wine as well as dessert: poached figs. The textures and flavors were ambitious, but didn't quite come together.  Like my primary dish, it wasn't bad, just nothing ro get overly excited over. 

I want to love this place, so I'll give it another go soon, hopefully with a stronger recommendation.
author: Lisa F.

description:
We came here for brunch on a Sunday. It was nice to be able able to reserve a spot rather than wait in the typical long lines at the other brunch places around the area. 

The coffee (latte) was smooth and perfect. I had the fried chicken biscuits and gravy. The portions are perfect for me but some might find it on the small side. 

On the whole, if you're looking for some health options for breakfast/brunch, Central Kitchen is a good place if you're in the area.
author: Trang H.

description:
We came here in a group for lunch

We had a later reservation so we were seated pretty quickly. Server promptly gave water (and refilled it well over brunch)

Several people ordered the french toast, which was pretty unique and tasted quite delicious. I got the rabbit terrine, and others got the fried eggs w/braised oxtail, and baked eggs. I think the baked eggs w/chorizo stew and sweet potato was the winner.

My main gripe about Central Kitchen is the price. I get that the food is delicious, but for brunch, I would have expected a bit more, portion-wise. The guy who got the fried eggs, his eggs looked like they were fresh out of a day-old chicken. My rabbit terrine lasted in my stomach for 2 hours before I had to grab ice cream. 

Value wise, I wouldn't come back, but taste wise, the food was good.
author: Shang S.

description: Food was extraordinary, imaginative, fresh and delicious.  Service ranged from not-particularly-knowledgable-about-food/wine-yet-cheerful to bitter, dismissive and lost.  Only one was friendly and engaging; the others were angry and had no concept of service (their job responsibility?) or human connection.  Big management issue. Thank you, chef!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend our last night in town.  My good foodie friend was raving about this place.

Decor:  I love the high ceiling in the main center and dark woods. The fountain in the entry way with the broken plate ware is wonderful and I may have to copy that idea someday in my future home.  I also loved the serving plates.  There was a nice rustic feel to the whole restaurant. 

Service:  Our server was a doll.  She asked if I had food allergies and made a note of it.  She was very helpful with the menu and despite the busy time was very attentive in checking in and apologetic in the time lapse between two of our courses. 

Food:  My favorite dish was my main course.  They offer a tasting menu but since my boyfriend and I are trying to only eat seafood and avoid other meats this was not an option for us.  Their menu is small but they have vegetarian and pescetarianism options. We had oysters to start which were ok but the jalapeno foam over powered the oysters. I wish they used less of the foam. Then we had something with avocado and asparagus?  It was okay in flavor but hard to eat and share.  I had the blackened cod for my main course with the fennel broth and artichoke hearts.  That was top notch.  I loved the blend of flavors. For dessert we had the three different chocolates but they all kind of blended in taste. We paired our food with a pinot noir from Oregon (obvious choice). 

All in all I think this a lovely place for a date or catching up with friends in from out of town who would like a nice dinner.

Heads up:  You should make a reservation, but note they let tables go after 15 minutes so make sure you are on time!
author: Nicole B.

description:
I came here for dinner last week with a new friend, and it as perfect as she eats gluten-free and Central Kitchen was sensitive to this and ensured that she could enjoy her meal - success!  I ate gluten-free with her except for the lovely bread they served and soft butter and touch of salt (I just could not resist!).  

We had:
* Chanterelle soup (looooove mushrooms and this soup was delectable, we totally enjoyed it, would totally recommend)
* Summer squash (loooove summer squash too, also very good)
*  Pork with figs and mushrooms (good taste, a little bit on the dry side but we still enjoyed it)
*  Fromage blanc cheesecake (this was definitely a hit at our table, yummm, totally recommend it too)
*  Lovely wine selection white to red

It's a little bit of a walk to the restaurant from BART, but it's not too bad.  We went to 16th/Mission, walked up to 20th and then walked down 20th to the restaurant.  

Really nice service, and the meal was nicely timed.  Love the restaurant modern, warm decor and semi outdoors seating with lots of heating lamps to accommodate the perfect dining temperature.  

I will definitely be back!  :)
author: Maile N.

description: This is an amazing place with great food.  One of the top restaurants in the city with amazing wine pairings.  Always choose the tasting menu and you will be happy.
author: A J.

description:
Assured.

Spotted written on an easel in front of a bakery elsewhere in the city: "Life is unsure, always eat your dessert first." True statement.

Knew we were in for a treat when our server said the French toast bread pudding (!) was more like a dessert yet was served first. It proved to be one of the best things of the year.

Moving from the rich and incredible start to a cheesy and caramelized potato second. Did not know such crispy and roasted goodness existed.

Homemade olive oil-fused granola with a homemade vanilla yogurt was also a treat. Same with the Mission Huevos (scrambled eggs, avocado and salsa).

Everything was top notch including the still incredible space. Open roof was not open but still had a bit of dining al fresco feel. Prices remain high at $20+ each.

While many things in life are unsure, this is one brunch you can be assured of loving.
author: Jason B.

description:
I've continuously heard great things about Central Kitchen so I was almost hesitant to go as I didn't want it to be over hyped and then leave disappointed. This was not the case at all, every praise I've heard about Central Kitchen rings true. 

The food + the service are both off the charts. The menu changes daily depending on what is fresh and in season. There are a few options for tiny bites and then about 10 appetizers options (5 cold, 5 warms) and then a handful of entrees. They highly encourage sharing here which is right up my alley as I love to order a bunch of things and share with the group. We got two small bites, a majority of the appetizers and two entrees. My two favorites were the squash, parmesan cream and pesto salad and a seafood pasta, they were both unreal. Everything we ate was perfectly prepared and presented in such a pretty way! 

The service was another thing that made them stand out. I've heard they're known for their impeccable service but I was still so impressed. Our main server was super nice, informative and engaging without being over bearing. Everyone who worked there seemed to genuinely enjoy being there. 

Over all it was a fantastic experience and I cannot wait to go back again soon. They definitely earned their five stars.
author: Lizzy U.

description: Ah, Central Kitchen. I was really hoping the new opening would be better. I even got a letter from the owner about it - how it was going to be more accessible; a neighborhood spot. Well, it's not. My husband and I went with out of town guests right when it reopened, and I see no difference. Everything is still precious and pretentious, and very expensive. Beef tartare. Raw albacore. Duck liver mousse. Pork belly with fish sauce. This is high-end, special occasion type food. The dessert we tried was not even tasty! Blueberries in a bowl with poppy seeds and mushy creme fraiche. Tasted like a healthy breakfast, not a dessert. I'm disappointed that the big changes didn't happen. Flour + Water just down the street manages to use simple ingredients to make amazing dishes that anyone can enjoy, any day of the week. Not sure why Central Kitchen is so set on being overly high end. Their lunch offerings at Salumeria are great - too bad they can't make dinner a simpler, more inviting experience.
author: mandy d.

description:
Terrific food, very nice waiter but the service is unbelievably SLOW. That was the LONGEST dinner I have ever had -- nearly two and a half hours and that included getting our dessert to go. The time between courses was simply unacceptable and when we asked the manager what explained the delay he said that fresh, homemade food took time. That's true but plenty of other restaurants in the city have found a way to make fresh, homemade food in far less time. 

Loved the food but won't be returning unless the kitchen management is improved.
author: Trevor H.

description:
I had heard a lot of great things about this spot, but wasn't quite sure if it was up to all the hype people I knew gave it. 

Central Kitchen has become, easily, one of my favourite places to go for brunch in the city. I've had brunch here twice and both times I left satisfied. The cocktails are great...and the meal itself isn't too heavy, which historically has been a problem for me at most brunch places.
author: Sara M.

description:
I really want to hate this place, because I'm not a foodie, nor am I in love with SF, and I have a social message to say about yuppie brunches. But this is not the time nor place.

Because I have an appreciation for fried chicken, and this place actually makes a decent fried chicken plate! Seriously, I've tried like at least 7-8 different "gourmet" fried chicken joints in the city, and Popeye's blows 'em all out of the water. I'm sorry. I mean, Popeye's is better than this place too, but it held its own. And it was even boneless. Which means it got the skin right, which is apparently really hard to do. Of course, the portion is laughably small for the price, but this is brunch in the city, so whatever. 

Thumbs up for the ambiance, and nice that it's located in an area where you can get street parking relatively easily. In conclusion, these 4 stars for the fried chicken might have been the result of super low expectations, but I'd still come back.
author: Brian N.

description:
We had the tasting menu and loved it. I will be back, and next time I'm going to try a la carte for sure.  Excellent special night out place (closing a round of funding, anniversary, promotion, proposal, birthday, etc.).

I'm surprised by the reviews offering up 3 stars or less to Central Kitchen, because my experience last night deserved 5 stars. Are folks trying to sandbag this place? or it could be they had astronomical expectations. After all guys, it hasn't earned a Michelin star yet. (It will likely within a couple of years if they have the staying power, though!) Anyway...

BACKGROUND:
We had reservations for two, one of the first seatings (blue-hair hour at 545PM).
We drove, and found spot off the bat on Florida at the corner of 20th.
I was never that impressed with Flour+Water, I liked it, but didn't understand the hype, still I really love seeing what new things inspire chefs and wanted to check it out after the first couple of weeks since opening (to avoid the kinks in operations).

AMBIANCE:
Love it. Last night was beautiful out so the partial outdoor seating (they have heat lamps) looked enticing, though we were sat in a cozy corner inside, plenty of light. Modern design, clean lights, California style (whether you dressed up or down, it felt comfortable, not affected). 

SERVICE:
Excellent. Here's what I mean: we weren't in 'want' of anything. Everyone was at the ready. We had water when we needed, additional wine, as we needed, etc. Also, they were very accommodating to my friend who had an allergy to one of the ingredients on the tasty menu, they were happy to make a substitution without being uppity about it. Everyone was attentive, kind, and not at all unctuous.

FOOD:
I've uploaded a photo of the tasting menu for May 31, 2012. So take a look there for reference.
The canapes felt like a fun opener where the chef was exploring a few things.
Standout: the lemon granita.
The courses complemented each other nicely. Standouts: the clams and turnips in bone marrow vinaigrette and the halibut with yolk and artichoke puree.

It's pretty expensive, so don't let the neighborhood fool you. This is most definitely a special occasion night out.
author: Trinity M.

description: Was unseasonably cold in California while we were there - I am not sure why but we definitely were feeling it while seated in the restaurant. The food was good, not great. (not as good as people said in other reviews).
author: Annie D.

description:
I have no idea how this place has 31/2 stars - it was by far the best dining experience I have had in San Francisco and I have eaten at a lot of great restaurants in the five years I have lived here.

The service, the food, the wine, and the ambiance were all amazing. The dishes are all very unique, with sauces and flavors that you wouldn't normally think to pair together made for a wonderful dining experience.

The potato tortelli,  hen, and the shirt rib were our favorites. And I recommend finishing it off with the custard. 

I seriously cannot stop talking about this place and cannot wait to go back!
author: Ashley L.

description:
Well, we read very good reviews on this restaurant just down our street ad we wanted to try it!
We booked a table for 2 for 9 a tuesday night thinking it won't be crowded but better book a table in order not to wait!
Table was booked and reservation was confirmed but when we arrived we waited 30 minutes to get our table!!!!
Food was great so i can not put less than 3 stars but it was very desapointed waiting so long for a table and nothing was offered by the restaurant to appologize....
author: Eva R.

description: Favorite restaurant in SF. Have been many times to confirm this - fit for foodies and you won't leave feeling hungry (like Commonwealth). Menu is always changing with the season; it's so quintessentially farm-to-table. I would recommend sharing the small plates, a homemade pasta and entree. Don't forget dessert. Enjoy!
author: Danielle K.

description:
This was my first San Francisco trendy dining experience. (By trendy I mean you have to make a reservation a month in advance.) If I could give half stars I'd go with 3.5 but since I can't I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and round up.

The atmosphere was beautiful, dark wood and floating strands of lights. Service was friendly but strangely inconsistent - we had at least three different servers. It seemed one was just drinks, one food, one food runner? And then the drink guy came back for our dessert order. I wasn't sure what was happening.

The food itself was gorgeously presented. We were splitting each item we ordered and they plated two little portions instead of us having to do it, which I thought was quite thoughtful. The flavors were lovely and fresh. The pork was a little fatty but the cod, pea salad, and pasta were all delish.

I had a view into the open kitchen, which was spotless. The various chefs were carefully plating each dish as if they were works of art. It was fun to watch.

The food is pricey so I wouldn't recommend Central Kitchen if you're ravenous. Expect small, high-quality portions.
author: Jenny V.

description:
Overrated. Poor service. Food was either over cooked or undercooked, but dessert was good. 
Came here on a Saturday night with a 9 pm reservation. However we were asked to wait until 935 to be seated. Any accommodations made to alleviate our discomfort? Not on your life. 
We were seated and waited over 10 mins for bread to be served. I honestly could go on and on about the flaws but I don't want to waste my time. Just avoid--it's overrated!!
author: Lisa B.

description:
I've been here 3 times and have enjoyed the tasting menu, brunch and a casual dinner. 

There isn't a full bar but their wine and beer selection is well curated (there is a bar next door). The food is delicious, good flavors and good sized portions (not too big). 

All in all I'll continue to bring friends here, easy to park in the area and a hideaway from the busy SF streets. 

I'm a fan.
author: David X.

description: I took my boyfriend, a former chef here for his birthday and although it was a little pricey, everything was amazing - the ambiance, service, aromas, and food. We tried the duck liver (probably the best we've ever had, especially in the city), avocado salad, two pastas and mashed potatoes. The only thing we didn't absolutely love/devour were the potatoes which our server took off the bill of her own accord. She also noticed that my boyfriend's wine was full of sediment and offered an apology AND an extra half glass completely proactively. We cannot wait to go back and try everything else on the menu! I can easily say that this was one of the best meals/experiences we've had dining out since I can remember - thanks for an awesome time!
author: Jamie G.

description: Had brunch at this bustling location on a Sunday with a friend. If you don't mind sitting at the bar and you go early enough then you can grab a spot for two. The space is open, airy, and bright. Their brunch specials are on the light side so you can totally grab a sticky bun to share with an entree with a drink. It does get packed so service can be spotty, but overall good.
author: Theresa D.

description:
There was a promising start but overall a disappointing showing here.

We arrived shortly before open and were offered seats at a table (which we'd need to keep an eye on time at for an upcoming 7:30 reservation) or we were welcome to sit at the bar. The bar is where the wine is served but diners face the room, not the staff. We thought 1¾ hours seemed plenty of time so sat.

The space is beautiful. We sat in the courtyard, full of natural light in the early Summer evening. We were finishing a glass of prosecco from next door and ordered a glass of cremant brut rosé while we decided what to eat. Perhaps the early tippling led to the ordering of six dishes but if nothing else we set up for a large slice of the place. We ordered as there distinct courses, but responding "yes" to the server's question about sharing may have led to the dishes coming out one-at-a-time.

First up was a delicious fig-topped liver pâté that set hopes high for the rest of the meal. It was so good, and such a pleasant blend of savory and sweet that I held on to it throughout the meal and had the last bit for dessert. Second in line was a carrot-and-whey dish. The pickled carrots had a pleasant crispness and the whey -- almost like a less-sweet crème fraîche -- was enjoyed as a spread on the Kitchen's great bread. While definitely worth having once, it's not something I'd return to.

Third came a watermelon-and-tomato salad with house-cured pork. The stars of this dish were the watermelon, pickled rind, baby cress, purple basil, and sesame dressing. Sadly, those components made up only a fifth of the dish and the rest was uniformly disappointing.

Fourth came a roast-onion, whipped crescenza, and tomatillo salsa dish. This one was interesting but wasn't a home-run. The onions had a wide range of done-ness. The more tender sections worked well with the delicious cheese and punchy tomatillo.

About this time I asked to taste a pair of reds in preparation for our entrées. After she left them, another server appeared and uttered one of the strangest introduction-apologies I've heard: "I'll be taking over for your server because she is taking her federally-mandated 30-minute break." I can't help but think "your server had to step out but I'll take care of you until she gets back" would have been less jarring. Around this time I noticed it was nearing 7 pm and we'd been warned to be done by 7:15, though no one had since mentioned timing to us. Speaking of timing, the remnants of those two tastes sat on the table for a long time before someone came by to ask which one we wanted.

What came out next was the low point -- a "mixed grill" of pork, every slice bulbous with thick fat: loin, belly, and head-cheese. (I couldn't tell the head-cheese from the belly, so I have to take the server's word on that.) I am fine with fat, and it doesn't normally turn me off, but this was just too close to being served thick slices of lard. The cuts were also nearly indistinguishable in flavor and texture, offering no option for the adipose-phobic. Once slice of belly I served to my G/F had gristle so inedible she had to spit it into her napkin. They took the item of our bill, and it sounded like we weren't the first to be taken aback by the presentation. A warning might be in order.

The final dish was squid a la plancha, a relatively standard presentation with olives and eggplant. While cooked well its flavor and overall impression were just "fine."

My G/f thought all the dishes past the first two were surprisingly bland. She also found the various white wines she tried quite similar (all bone-dry and heavy on minerality) and many not worth the steep glass prices. Some brought to mind far more successful dishes at St Vincent, some just left us scratching our heads. Overall there is little chance we'll come back. Great bread and pâté can't make up for a two-for-six record. Combined with inattentive service this is not the recipe for return visits.

(Cross-posted to Yelp.)
author: Joshua P.

description: I have to say I wasn't super impressed with central kichen.  The 2 stars is of course rated for comparable high-end restaurants.  Compared to say the local burrito spot or chevy's it was great, but of course at $40/entree it should be.  Staff was super nice and the space was nice, but the dishes were not great.  We had the ling cod which felt dry and perhaps under seasoned.  One of the starters was way too salty- like I didnt even want to finish it.  I was looking forward to the place after all the great reviews.  Nice wine list with reasonable wines (again for a restaurant at this price level).  I would give it 2.5 stars if I could, but I don't think I would go back.
author: David G.

description:
On SF Gate's 2014 100 Best Restaurants List.

Note: If you make reservations for Central Kitchen, you'll have to use your credit card to hold your reservation. If you need to cancel, you need to give them at least 48 hours notice if you don't want your credit card charged. 

I have been looking forward to trying the food at Central Kitchen since it opened, but was disappointed in the dishes I had. There were too many components in each dish, and all the flavors did not work well together. I had made reservations for a party of 5 on a Friday night for 8:30pm a few weeks ahead time. We ran a little late, but they held the table for us, and seated us right away. We tried:
 
-Complimentary Bread & Butter: Ok, but not the best bread and butter I've had at a restaurant. Also, our server never asked if we wanted more bread.
-Kale Chips (w/Yogurt, Avocado, $7): I loved the crispy kale chips, but the tartness of the yogurt was overpowering. 
-Crispy Duck Tongues (w/Citrus, Liver Mousse, $7): Good, but very oily, and not even the citrus could cut the oily taste, although it overpowered the other flavors. The liver mousse was too thin/creamy for my taste, and I didn't think the mousse and duck tongue paired well together.
-Three Cheeses (w/Lavosh, Fennel Preserve, Walnut, $14): Good, but nothing special. The lavosh was too dry/crispy and I didn't like it paired with the cheese.
-Beef Tartare ($16): Just ok, not the best beef tartare I've had. I also didn't like the type of bread it was paired with, and would have preferred toast points or toasted baguette slices. Skip!
-Seaweed Pasta Chitarra (w/Mussels, Sea Urchin, Bottarga Bread Crumb, $19): Sadly, just ok. I was looking forward to this dish the most, but it was bland! You couldn't taste the sea urchin at all, and I wouldn't get this again.
-Octopus (w/Pork Belly, Blood Sausage, Pickled Mushroom, Almond, $20): This was everyone's favorite dish. The octopus had an amazing sear on it, and went well with most of the other components of this dish, like the blood sausage. The pork belly was just average, and I didn't think the pickled mushroom or almond was needed.
-Chocolate Custard (w/Candied Almond, Coffee Ice Cream, $10): I loved the creamy chocolate custard, but the coffee ice cream was too strong tasting for me. 

The best part about dining at Central Kitchen was the service- we needed to finish our meal before 10pm, and our server was super accommodating. I loved how efficient the kitchen was- Our dishes came out quickly but we didn't feel rushed through our dinner. However, I didn't like that the lighting in the restaurant was really dim, and that it was pretty loud in there. 

Overall, I wasn't that impressed by the dishes that I tried, and doubt I would come back since the portion sizes were also small for the price. Note that they change their menu here daily, so you have to come quickly if you see a dish you really want to try. Parking in this area is really difficult, and street parking is available but can be difficult to come by.
author: Amy D.

description:
Third time here...based on my first impression -- which was excellent. 
The first time (May 2015), I went with a group of 5 foodie friends and we got every appetizer and small plate on the menu -- see previous review. We avoided the larger, more expensive entree items because we wanted to try many plates and share them all. It was a vibrant Spring menu; lots of interesting compositions, flavors, textures. Everyone had a couple of favorites and we enjoyed all of the plates.
My second outing (August 2015) was with a "vegetarian" friend -- she eats chicken -- which makes her not a vegetarian in my book, but ... Anyway, that was a less inspiring meal because many of the plates were not available to us due to inclusion of meat. The only fowl they have is duck, which she didn't want to try. 
Finally, just this past week, I made a reservation for my parents and myself. We walked about 2 miles before arriving, which caused us to take a break halfway, grab a glass of wine and a snack -- poor planning since maybe we weren't as hungry as we should have been. We got 2 apps -- duck liver pate {{{Excellent}}} and sunchoke hummus {{{watery and bizarre}}}. We ended with three cold plates to share: a beet salad {{{delicious but not incredible}}} an albacore with pepper puree {{{I enjoyed, but parents didn't}}}  and a kabochka squash and apple salad {{{middle of the road}}}.
I'm a little disappointed that my subsequent visits never lived up to the excellence I enjoyed my first time. Maybe it was the Fall menu, maybe it was more in line with everyone else's experience of this place: Should be great, wants to be great, but isn't really as amazing as it should be. 
All that said, the service was excellent, the wine list is good and if it wasn't so damned loud, it was be enjoyable all around. I still recommend Central Kitchen but I'm just not certain that I'm going back any time soon. Too many other places in SF to try.
author: Yasi S.

description:
Meh.

I tried.  I really wanted to love Central Kitchen, but I honestly don't get the hype.

The staff--minus the front desk--is top notch and the food is well prepared.  But overall that is not enough considering these prices.

The menu is extremely limited and pretentious.  3 entrees to choose from only, and the portions are minuscule for the price.

Overall it's one of those San Francisco Foodie places that people want to say they have been to, but if they were honest, they leave with their wallets as empty as their stomachs.
author: Chip R.

description:
I ran 17 miles yesterday and I was hungry. Not a good place to come for that and certainly not reasonably priced at $14 for eggs, a few flakes of kale, and really small slivers of toast.

My vegetarian boyfriend got the 3-cheese lavosh plate. It was literally a few chunks of cheese and crackers for like $14. That is not a meal. I'm calling bulls$&%# on this place. 

I was interested in the fun combinations of food and this place is around the corner so we tried it...we won't be coming back. In fact, the atmosphere of extremely wealthy pretentious patrons made us want to pack up and move out of a city that calls this place a great new and hip restaurant. Sorry, I must be cranky because I'm still hungry.
author: Kate C.

description:
I don't review very often, but I was blown away by Central Kitchen --- some of the most delicious food I have ever enjoyed (sounds like an exaggeration...but I'm serious!).  I had the salmon which was very good but a safe bet... in hindsight, I wish I had been more adventurous and ordered the roasted duck breast (my friend ordered the duck and let me try it... unreal!) or the hen roulade (also tried my friend's hen and found it to be perfectly cooked).  The fried green tomatoes were very good but the liver mousse was unbelievably delicious!  Also, be sure to enjoy the stone fruit salad --- burrata with a mix of seasonal fruit and veggies. 
If you're looking for a special restaurant to celebrate a significant milestone, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Central Kitchen!
author: Stephen W.

description: This restaurant is into integrity. Can't decide if the chef / food or service was more impeccable and welcome - so call it a draw and a win win win. Whenever possible, I am only going to restaurants that care about the quality of their ingredients - i.e. clean sourcing, organic, seasonal, etc. Back to being impressed - the servers and chef incredibly and graciously accomodating to my request for dietary adjustments to dishes, that still soared above and beyond. Star dish: charred brussel sprouts. Star preparation city wide for this pop veg that deserves this honor. Please keep it on your menu and I will gladly return. CK: Please consider a spin off into the Inner Sunset that desperately needs something of this caliber, level of hospitality and soul!. Thanks for a memorable meal and experience. Yes, Woohoo!
author: Cathy C.

description:
We had our latest dinner club and while our group was small this time we had an amazing experience here.  The decor was very cool and our waitress was awesome in explaining the dishes which made us want to order everything she talked about.

I forget all of the things we ordered since they change their menu so frequently but I know that the peppers as a starter were really delicious and then hen was great too.  I don't think you can go wrong with anything here.

For dessert we had the lemon cake and the chocolate financier both of which were great.

Highly recommend this spot!
author: Blake B.

description:
Reasonable service. Austere environs. Forgettable food.

One server made it obvious she was pained to answer our questions.

The cheese plate was good.

The duck confit skin was not crispy.

The cod was tasty but the greens were severely under seasoned.
author: Adam G.

description: Dined at CC the other night after a year or more of not going. I enjoyed my meal and wine and the service was solid. Ingredients were fresh and seasonal and preparations were reasonably creative.
author: Sandy G.

description:
Food = 4
Service = 3

I'm giving Central Kitchen a 4 because I'm really hoping to either read how the restaurant does in the coming months or I'd like to come back in 3-6 months to see if any change has occurred. If you've been following the reviews/background info about this place at all then you know that they are still new and working some kinks out...

All of the service staff were lovely, not a single note of pretension, there was a few instances of confusion (from the very get go, having three people at the hostess stand repeatedly not seeming to know their role). Bread arrived at our table at the same time(seconds before) as our first bite (pallet cleanser) appeared. Strong leadership would really turn things around here, someone who could fine tune everything.

My group had the tasting menu, it was good. We started with a blueberry soda with fennel and im not sure what else (wasnt on the menu), it was a little bit more like a smoothy, difficult to drink, but tasted nice. This was followed by an interesting corn soup. Corn season just arrived so i was really excited to try it. Served in a small wine/shot glass, same style for the blueberry soda, and tasted good, it was warm corn juice with pistachio rimming the glass. Creative but the flavors were traditional and not too exciting. The bottle selection is very affordable with a lot of nice bottles in the $30-50 range. We had the proseco which went well with the first few courses, subtle, complimented all of the food and its refreshing.


The next two courses were good and probably fantastic for my friends but really fell short for me because I'm vegetarian and the only difference on my plate was the absence of protein .. I was eating a well made sauce with maybe some tasty artichoke or arugula. Please vamp up your veggie options!!!! My last four courses were great: a charred avocado with a sweet sauce(??), bean radish and squash plate , Strawberry sorbet was tasty and the deconstructed cheese cake  and figs were stunning. We had a fantastic, you must try!, bottle of rose from Red Wood Valley (Mendocino) , unique, smooth, and refreshing. I just checked the wine list to jot down the name to purchase later but it's not there :( For some silly reason we all ordered the port which is far too heavy for cheesecake or sorbet, should've gone with the bottle of moscato, ow well.

Enjoy! And like I said earlier I think they still have some kinks to knock out.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Didn't blow me away. 

I had the matsutake with apple and celery root, but it wasn't excellent.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I remember the dishes needing more texture, personally. But this is the direction that food is going. We asked for bread, which fortunately was good. But the ingredients they use are all top notch, and everything was cooked well. 

Wine and service were great.
author: Derrick V.

description: Bloguettes San Francisco workshop was held at The Upstairs at Central Kitchen, their event space, and we couldn't have been more pleased! It was a pleasure to work with the Central Kitchen staff while planning. They were so accommodating to ours needs as we were traveling from out of state. The venue is absolutely gorgeous with all the open windows and natural light. Looking forward to visiting Central Kitchen again when we return to the city.
author: Bloguettes B.

description: The raw Hamachi with avocado, fennel and rhubarb is BOMB!
author: Antonio A.

description: Our first time here to celebrate a belated birthday dinner and it was a success!  Started the evening next door for a cocktail at Trick Dog and headed over, warmly greeted and sat.  Some of the tables are ridiculously close together, so much so that it was hard not to hear/eavesdrop on neighbors, even when you are really trying to cancel out the 1/2 hour conversation about food allergies at the table next to you, you can't avoid it!  Meanwhile, our service was very kind and helpful.  We started with a fantastic house made pasta and pork dish and a side of the bread with delectable emulsified Cowgirl Creamery Red Hawk dip and pork laro/butter spread.  Wow!  Entree was duck breast with duck confit and perfectly done brussels sprouts, one of the best duck dishes I've had (and I've tried many).  Will keep our eye on menu changes so we can return to try other things.
author: e w.

description:
Don't a struggle with parking in this part of the Mission discourage you from trying Central Kitchen. The food is unique and the technique in the kitchen is solid. I think they excel when it comes to plating for sure, each dish being it's own abstract piece of art you can't bare to destroy with a fork...but you have to!

If I had any complaint at all, is that the portions aren't particularly large, then again, I think I (and most of America) should get used to eating the quantities most restaurants (Central Kitchen included) are moving towards. 

You can see photos of the food we ordered on our food and travel site here:

http://eatsporkjew.com/food-2/top-ten-dating-analogies-sn-francisco/

We also published them with a Top 8 San Francisco Dating Analogies of 2014, which we think is pretty funny. 

But seriously, check out Central Kitchen....the food is perplexing in a good way, and so pretty you'll want to hang it on the wall!
author: Philip H.

description: My foodie wife and I had Sunday brunch and both of us thought this was the best meal we had enjoyed in a very long time.  The service was great, the atmosphere comfortable, clean and modern.  Highlights of our meal were the beet salad, kale bread pudding, and potatoes.  Next time we're saving room for the sticky bun with bacon which looked divine...
author: David B.

description:
Brunch is my favorite in the city. They do things with eggs I did not know were possible, and the menu is constantly being updated. Baked eggs, poached eggs, fried eggs, always with something surprising and delicious. Seriously, give it a try, if for no other reason than that the line at Universal is long.

Dinner is consistently fantastic and wine pairings are reasonably priced.
author: Ian S.

description:
Love! The decor was cute, eclectic and well designed. The outside seating reminded me of something in a woodlands wedding with the long wooden table, dangling lightbulbs and the adorable candle holders on the table. 

Also, love the music selection. 

My only disappointment was serving size. Regardless, my palate was hugely satisfied with the interesting flavours that were brought to the table. Will definitely be back
author: Lea N.

description:
Central Kitchen may have just become my favorite brunch spot.  While we've wandered by dozens of times since its opening, we only just made reservations this Sunday morning and were pleasantly surprised at how delicious the food was.

Entrees included the Baked Eggs and Fried Chicken Benedict, as well as a starter of Salumi.  While we already had a significant amount of food, we also had the side of Crispy Potatoes.  

Sparking water is complimentary, a nice touch.
author: Rafael R.

description:
Fantastic food! Hipster Californian cuisine in its best! Creative, innovative, disruptive:
- kampachi with kumquat, fennel, poppy seed & chili
- seaweed pasta chitarra with mussels, chili & sea urchin bottarga
- octopus with pork belly, blood sausage, pickled mushroom & almond
Roll over French dinosaurs -- San Fran micro-cookery startups are eating the world :-).
author: Sergei B.

description: Went for brunch. Cool layout. very tasty food. Great scrambled eggs. Awesome concept. Cheerful service.
author: Brennan S.

description:
I tried to keep an open mind- not worth the price. 

We visited on a Saturday evening- the service was excellent. 

Unfortunately the chef has about 2 tricks he employs in most of his tasting menu dishes, compressed fruits and vegetables (yawn) and egg yolks (!)
3 of our 5 tasting courses were served with a raw yolk- not very new or hip. 
The rest of the menu was slightly bland, fatty duck, undercooked sea bass completely overwhelmed by olive tapenade.  The best dish was the smoked salmon - and really how hard is that?!

I'm usually fine with hipster destinations, but this place sacrifices propriety for hipness. 

Our waitress was wearing a backless leotard, not appropriate for serving food, no offense.   The music was so loud we couldn't  hear our server tell us what we were eating ... And honestly, who even listens to modest mouse anymore?

My biggest complaint is literally sitting on top of the other guests... The tables are so close together that if a server is helping the table next to yours, her entire ass is over your table and food- this was compounded by the fact that (did I mention) SHE WAS IN A BACKLESS LEOTARD! 

Donate 400.00 to the SF food bank instead- it's a better use of your money.
author: C J.

description:
If I'd met CK on OKC, the best thing I could say about him would be that he was "really, really nice". Then, my roommate would ask whether or not I planned to see him again, and I'd have to decline... because despite the MANY niceties of Central Kitchen - the laid-back-professional-prompt service, the lovely rustic-industrial space, the scintillating wine list and elegant (if a bit opaque) menu, the pretty plating and well-timed courses - I just didn't feel it. 

Our appetizers - fried trotter tots and hen croquettes - were. . . nice, but also totally indistinguishable from one another. My duck and his halibut were . . . nice. . . looking, but not particularly nice-tasting. Not bad-tasting, per se, but at $25+ a pop, a pretty penny to pay for something p-r-e-t-t-y . . . nice (but not VERY nice). I can't really say anything further about it at all.  

A factual postscript: dessert was "nice" too, permutations of chocolate varietals and textures. Thanks for a nice time, Central Kitchen. . . but maybe we're not a great match.
author: Liz C.

description:
Items selected:

French Press
Bacon Mission Fig Sticky Bun with Walnuts
Green Eggs and Ham, Summer Squash, Bread, Pickled Chanterelle
French Toast, Berries, Vanilla

Largely unaware of Central Kitchen until my server at Flour + Water brought it to my attention I quickly made Sunday Brunch reservations via smartphone while dining at Commonwealth; admittedly the brunch menu did not excite me as much as the options at dinner but with limited time and extensive dining plans between that time and my departure I figured any restaurant touting to be "of, by and for the neighborhood" couldn't be a bad choice and if brunch were successful a future dinner could definitely be planned.  A modestly sized industrial space with an attached market and wood plus concrete aplenty plus a small well culled menu service was thorough but somewhat stretched as the restaurant filled quite quickly on opening but with coffee via individual French Press and water refills timely I was never left for want as I progressed at a nice pace from pastry to savory to 'dessert.'  Energetic but not at all 'loud,' and seemingly as accessible for families as for the standard Mission Hipster my meal began with the signature Sticky Bun and while I tend to think the bacon-everything story is played out there is no doubt the smoky salinity helped to balance the sweetness of the figs and caramel while, taking a different approach, the green eggs and ham opted to use the cured pork and house pickled mushrooms as a backdrop to vibrant basil hollandaise and tender, sweet squash.  Rounding out a great meal the last plate to arrive resembled a single piece of bread resting in a shallow pool of vanilla cream and garnished with fresh berries but in reality the dish was more like creamy custard baked till just set - a flan with a light yeastiness and a touch more texture that I'd have gladly eaten at least a few more of...
author: Michael U.

description:
I always have a hard time in rating based on a five star system.  We grabbed a few drinks at Trick Dog before making our way to the restaurant for our table.. Our waiter was Steve. Did a nice a job he covered all the basics. If this was our first time, were there any allergies he should be made aware of. invited us to use our hands.. Nice touch. I'm aware that for the most part these things are required by upper management.  I had a few questions on the beers and he offered me a taste.. To help him save time of going over the 'complexity' of flavors and notes of beers. As well of me to know .. Which is what he should do.  My pallet isn't the same as his.  Each dish was brought out to us in a really good fashion. We didn't have to wait to long for the next course.. Empty plates and glasses were quickly picked up. I loved the fact that the bread had a small amount of dried flowers sprinkled on the butter.  It's the little things that make the biggest impact.   The only thing I noted about the experience was when the plates are being dropped off, perhaps (and I'm only saying this because I work at a five star restaurant) I'm actually guilty of it too.. When dropping off a dish I feel servers in general go over to much of the ingredients on the plate. 

We had a great time.  The dessert on the pri-fix definitely gave us the caffeine jolt necessary to not feel sluggish.

Kudos Steven/Stephen
author: Chris L.

description:
The Manfriend says: "CK put the butt in halibut."

My experience here quickly dwindled from a 4 star experience to a 1 star "where is my damn check, I need a drink at Trick Dog now" experience. 

I thought I'd picked a winner when we started with the pâté, a rich, creamy concoction with hints of citrus, radish, and some sungold tomato slices on top. I should have just ordered 3 jars of this and walked away happy. At this point, 4 stars. 

Then they brought out the lemongrass clam broth with maitake mushrooms, quail egg, and small crispy chicken thigh bits. It was good, if a bit on the salty side. The huge bowl only highlighted the tiny quantity of broth, and made the stuff harder to spoon up, as it only filled about 1/10th of the bottom. Still hungry, we waited for our halibut to arrive. 

And waited.
 
And waited. 

Our waiter didn't check on us during this time, either to offer an explanation for the delay, or to suggest say, bread, or any other appetizer that might curb our appetites. A waitress from another section came by and refilled our water, but my date and I mostly sat there, staring at eachother's hungry faces (mine, burgeoning on homicidal by the end) and our empty table for 40 minutes. Meanwhile, the couple next to us received course after course, including the same entree that we ordered, in quick succession following their previous course. I still have no idea what caused the delay.

And at long last, the waiter brought us our halibut, briskly said "sorry for the delay, can I get you anything else?" and hurried off. This would have been great 15 minutes ago, when I was debating whether or not to just flip over the table, run out the door, and go down the street to El Farolito instead. 

I wish I could say that the wait paid off. It did not. The halibut was the blandest piece of fish I've ever eaten. I've had unseasoned halibut sashimi with more flavor than this. Although the texture was smooth, that was about all it had going for it. No searing, no flavor, no salt. I detected a slight citrus note, perhaps from the olive oil it was prepared in. 

This dish felt like paying for a trip to Jamaica and instead somehow winding up at the Holiday Inn in Kansas City - disappointing, boring, and wrought with that feeling of "why has Jesus forsaken me?" I didn't know an overpriced ($27), Post-it pad sized piece of flavorless fish on a bed of oversalted beans could ever fuel such rage in a person, but it did. 

At this point, I was so hungry that I couldn't even send it back. I just ate the fish, frowned, and apologized to my guy for taking him here. 

Then I went home and ate a second dinner, because I wanted to eat something that didn't make me angry.

Loved the first dish (4 stars), the broth was good, and the rest (service, value, entree), was 1 star = 1.5 to 2 stars overall.
author: Selina K.

description: Came here last Tuesday for dinner. Was late for my reservation but they were so accommodating! Ordered the liver mousse, braised lamb neck with charred octopus and the hen with tonnato and spicy peppers. Everything was beyond good. The liver mousse is probably the most underrated thing on the menu. Trust me and order it! Had the chocolate dessert which is literally orgasmic.
author: Samantha K.

description: This gorgeous restaurant has been calling my name forever. It makes almost every "best of" list in San Francisco. I had a hard time getting a reservation on a weeknight for a long time, but my friend and I finally got in. Much to our surprise the restaurant was mostly empty. The food was good. We shared a cheese platter appetizer, a pasta dish, and the hen confit. For dessert we had the sorbet. Everything was good, but didn't quite live up to the hype. I felt that it was overpriced. The venue is gorgeous though. Perfect for a romantic date night!
author: Kari G.

description:
I like this place a lot.  
Don't expect Flour + Water -- it's a different concept.  We had AMAZING food, and the space is beautiful.
author: Jaina S.

description:
I have been dying to do the tasting menu at Central Kitchen.  I am the biggest fan of flour and water, and have been talking about Central Kitchen for a year now.  I made reservations for my boyfriend and I to go to dinner for his birthday.  But the day before I chickened out after reading all the poor reviews on yelp, and went to Flour and Water for their tasting menu instead.  Sorry, enough about that onto Central Kitchen.  Hesitant to shell out $95 a person for a possibly bad meal, I decided that we should go for brunch instead.  That way we could keep our bill under the $100 investment for the both of us.  

We made reservations via open table.  We got there and was seated immediately.  The restaurant is a great environment for brunch with sunlight pouring in through the ceiling.  When seated we were offered a winter mimosa.  We decided to share one, and it was delightful.  I believe that it had pomegranate juice.  Divine!  We also shared a pot of french press coffee.  We were surprised that their house coffee was Mr. Espresso, we definitely expected Four Barrel, Blue Bottle or Sightglass.  I guess that is what happens when you live in San Francisco.  Coffee snobs unite!  

My boyfriend is pescatarian, and there weren't many options for him that were meatless.  He ordered a chickpea and poached egg casserole.   The flavors were amazing and it was really filling.  I ordered the eggs benedict with pork belly.  There was a delicious layer of spinach which really gave the eggs benedict a fresh veggie taste that can be needed when there is too much meat.  Don't get me wrong, I love meat but sometimes with the hollandaise sauce the brunch menu item can be too rich.  I would order that Eggs Benedict with just the spinach is was so flavorful.  

My only complaint is that the menu items don't come with toast or potatoes, so we had to order them separately as sides.  That being said, the toast was amazing, think The Mill on Divis amazing, and the potatoes were perfect.  

If this brunch is any indicator of how good dinner is, we will be coming back soon for the tasting menu.  I've read the mediocre reviews, but we did not have that experience on the Sunday we were patrons.
author: Victoria O.

description: Let the kitchen decide and the food was spectacular. Plus a welcoming ambience and good service. If this place was closer to my apartment I wouldn't need a kitchen.
author: John P.

description:
I really liked the atmosphere, and the waiter was happy to provide recommendations on wine and food (though his recommendations sounded a little rehearsed). We ordered a chickpea salad, a pork entree, a chicken entree and a chocolate wafer dessert. 

Overall, it was a good experience, but I don't think I'll be returning. At that price point in that neighborhood, I really just prefer Flour + Water.
author: Samantha H.

description: The food was excellent and pushes the place to 5 stars; very fresh, very distinctive, very delicious.
author: Fred C.

description:
I went to Central Kitchen a while back with a few girlfriends. We really enjoyed our time there. The food was tasty and extremely fresh. 

For a vegetarian, I was a little nervous that they wouldn't have too many options, but surprisingly, there were three appetizers that were vegetarian. One appetizer - the cheese plate, was by far the surprise as each cheese offered was unique. My main entree was tasty (especially with the fresh grilled vegetables) but I was hoping for a little more creativity (and for it to be a little more filling). I think had I not been in a large group (or ordered appetizers), I may have been hungry after the experience. 

They were able to pair each dish with amazing wines, and overall it was a good experience. I wanted to give my review 3.5 stars - but Yelp wouldn't allow for a half. So I rounded down to a 3.
author: Vrinda S.

description:
Had a reservation at 130pm but they were backed up for 30 min. Okay...

Of course, they ran out of Fried Chicken Eggs Benedict so we resorted to our second choice, Fried Eggs with duck which the majority ordered. 

My dish did not have fried eggs, my other friend had her eggs fried so inconsistent on CK's part. The duck was scant, hard and chewy - at least CK was consistent on that. lol

The price we paid for was on the high end for small portions which was disappointing. At least we didn't walk out bloated but I was still hungry.. even though our group 
shared a starter and sides.  Just disappointing.

Last, service was attentive and good.
author: Ken C.

description: nice looking place but overpriced & I was not too impressed with the food. Food favor is so subjective - I realize that.  I am a picky eater and I like clean and tasty food & I have to say I was not impressed with my meal at Central Kitchen. The hummus was not great (runny and someone at the table said it tasted like peanut butter) and the crackers it came with tasted like cardboard. The wine was overly priced for what it was and my cod was basically not tasty in the least. I had a gruff attitude when I saw the limited menu and I should have left but decided to stay in the hopes I could be swayed and end up loving the food because the rest of my group was fine with the choices there and the place was cool looking, but no go, I won't be back!
author: Jessie Jean C.

description:
I remembered reading somewhere on Huffington that the same guy who owns flour+water was going to be starting a new venture called Central Kitchen so I was excited about scoring reservations for dinner Monday night.

 Despite it's open, rustic space tastefully lit with pendant filament bulbs CK seems to be missing an element of homeliness. (I noticed that the hostess kept running back to the kitchen every 5 minutes instead of making sure that every guest was welcomed upon arrival)

The Hamachi I ordered for my starter was beautifully prepared. The flavors were clean and the quality of fish surprisingly high. I've always said that good protein should be showcased, not hidden under sauces garnishes.

If my Cod appetizer had been as impressive, I probably would have bumped the rating up another star. Unfortunately my fish was painfully overcooked. Despite the fact that the restaurant was half empty, it had taken quite a while for my entree to arrive and I didn't have the patience to wait for my dish to be refired. (This dish I didn't mind so much to be oversauced and overgarnished)

Wanting desperately to end the night on a culinary high note, I ended my meal with the Lavender infused Honey Custard and Currants. Conceptually, the dish was exciting; however, once again it fell a little short on execution. The custard was on the denser side and the bruleed honey was a little too thickly set resulting in a unpleasantly difficult bite. 

I admit, my expectations may have been a bit high walking into the experience because of all the carryover hype from CK's big brother and I truly wanted to fall in love with CK. Sadly, as with the rest of my experience, the thought turned out better than reality.
author: Kevin T.

description:
The ambiance is cozy, Californian which is the best part. The food comes in a close second to the setting... but there isn't much of the food---and if you order the deviled eggs and there are 4 of you... the server won't tell you to get another order because they will only bring 3! Stingy and silent?!...we might have ordered another order but we weren't even given the chance! Fine dining? 

The wine we had was delicious but the server didn't recommend or help out in the selection of it. Highly recommend the squid and the hen... everything else was meh....oh and they left our happy plates on the table FOREVER... f.o.r.e.v.e.r. 

There are plenty of restaurants in the city but I wouldn't recommend this one.
author: Hez B.

description:
I'm talking Sunday brunch here.  I love this spot, the location and the atmosphere.  It feels good to sit down in there and converse.  We were there right on time, as the doors opened.  Everyone got cappuccinos.  Mine was good...I think Atlas Cafe or the Coffee bar's versions are better, but they are specialty shops.  On with the food.  

This place is the type of place you take pictures of your food.  It is prepared beautifully and is also aesthetically pleasing to boot.   I ordered the eggs benedict & fried chicken. Ok yes, that to me was a weird combo.  There was also a nice piece of thinly sliced ham on the plate.  I actually ate everything except the fried chicken, which I saved for a midnight snack.   Of course, I did sample it and it was great.  I just didn't need that much food at that time.  

Leo got desert for brunch, which would make any kid happy.  It was the french toast bread pudding with strawberries and it was great, though he would only share a bite with me.  Everyone else loved their food... the fried egg plate and the frittata were hits. 

Yum, yum, yum!
author: Francis B.

description:
We used to love Central Kitchen but the last few visits have let us down. Service is still warm, knowledgeable, attentive; Sadly the food has slipped from epicurean-a true delight to the senses-to overly "cognitive / interesting" "cliche." (e.g., the chick pea halibut brandade was embarrassing awful).

I'm not saying they don't have exceptional talent,  and we wish them well. But maybe they are trying too hard or have lost their way. In any event It's unlikely we'll be back for a while.  

Special features:Fit for Foodies,Good for Groups,Great for Outdoor Dining,Great for Brunch,Romantic,Notable Wine List,Neighborhood Gem,Hot Spot,Special Occasion,Kid-Friendly
author: Steven B.

description:
Had a wonderful evening at this venue. The service was superb, and the food had me and my belly doing a happy dance throughout the entire meal. 

My date and I shared the pork agnolotti and king salmon. The former were pillows of divine pleasure (seriously!) and the king salmon dish would've been just as good without the salmon. I don't usually like eating cooked salmon, but this salmon was delish (cooked perfectly w/ crispy skin). I told the server that if we were at home, we'd be licking the plates clean. Since we were in a public place, we did the second best thing and requested bread to sop up all the sauce. This is a MUST! The bread at Central Kitchen (and Flour:Water) is some of the best bread I've ever had in my entire life!
author: Universal Citizen S.

description:
I really wanted to love this place. Love the space, love the "deli"/take out part but was really rather disappointed in the food. First off, not that many choices. Luckily I am not a vegetarian as you are really screwed, unfortunately my husband is. 

There were four of us dining and I felt that the 3 appetizers we got all sort of looked a bit the same color wise. I got the rabbit charcuterie - eh, it was ok. I think my friend who got the pork trotters got the best dish. For my entree I had the pork and there wasn't as much of a vibrancy of flavors as I had hoped for. I guess I was just disappointed.

Dessert, however, was awesome. Chocolately deliciousness.

Maybe try brunch? Maybe just go earlier and get something on the deli side and sit in the lovely space and save your money for Flour+Water.
author: holly B.

description:
The menu changes all the time here, so there's no sense in telling you what I ate.

Seems like most people knock this place for the same things:

1) Cost to proportion ratio
2) Reservations not being honored

I didn't have a problem with either of these things. I found it a bit unusual that they plate everything as if it was pushed off to the side and that some of the dishes were served at room temperature, but everything tasted fresh and the dishes were all clever. Everything left me wanting more and okay, okay, maybe that IS because of the portion size (things are fine for two, but you can't split a dish more than that), but I'd like to think that part of it was because everything was so tasty. For me the review is for the food.

It's a better "deal" if you bring a bottle of your own wine and order one of theirs so they knock off the corkage.

I'd go back for the tasting menu someday and the staff was appropriately friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Brandon K.

description:
After hearing my boyfriend read article after article about Central Kitchen, we gave into the hype and came to try it out. We arrived at opening at 5:30 and we were able to get a place at the bar area. There are 6 seats along the walkway to the kitchen that are counter or bar seats. It was pleasant to sit there. Given the cost of the meal, a table would have been better, but we did not make a reservation- so our fate was the counter. 
Over the course of our dining we were well taken care of- but we didnt seem to have one main server- it was as if we had many, which was fine. 
We had no idea what to expect other than what the fabulous marketing team had put out there. My BF is not a foodie and he felt a little scared of not knowing all the menu ingredients. However, when the food came to the table course after course, he actually said he wanted to take a picture of it. I must say- beautiful presentation and a big step for someone not so into dining to feel the need to whip out a camera!
The rolls they give you are warm fresh bakes poppy seed with fresh churned butter. Amazing. The menu changes daily. We had the asparagus & avocado with dill, egg & green farro. This was delicious. Light and fresh and so delicious. Next, roasted carrots with duck, smoked date, almond & coffee. This made me nearly fall off my chair. Unbelievably delicious. My entrée was seared bass with whipped potato, fennel, artichoke & olive tapenade. While this was a nice light dish the olive gave it most the flavor and I found it boring after the two first courses.  BF entrée was a pork chop. The entrée portions were of perfect size. Dessert was White Chocolate. Milk Chocolate. Dark Chocolate. It was decent- not an orgasmic dessert I've had other places. 
I found the space to be warm and ambient. It was a medium noise level and perfect for a nice date night. Ample parking within a few blocks walking.
author: Aly V.

description:
I wish we could give 1/2 stars on yelp.... I would give this place a 3.5
I thought that the atmosphere was lovely, service was fabulous.
I'm not sure I can say that I loved this place, however.  The food was indeed very interesting and tasty.  Loved the kale and cheese plate, but a few other dishes we're just ok (even though they were very pretty to look at).
Not sure I can agree that blood sausage and octopus belong on the same dish.
Also, i typically like my food either hot, warm or cold...a couple of dishes i felt were at room temp which was weird.
Will i go back here again?  Maybe.  I think it's just one of those things that you should at least try once.
author: S G.

description:
Although our food was awesome, we had a horrible waiter. He seemed annoyed, rushed and perhaps a little drunk. He didn't make eye contact with me until I informed him I had found a sharp piece of plastic in my  dish. The floor manager (a cute, young girl with a bob cut) must have been aware our waiter was a douche because she checked in with us a few times. Although she wasn't our server she explained the menu and gave us some great recommendations. I would have walked out it if weren't for her. Although the food was delicious (minus finding plastic) and the hostess and floor manager were great, that one waiter's negative energy really ruined the experience for me. I won't be returning. 

If you aren't sensitive to poor customer service, check it out and try the peas with chorizo dish. It was a 5 star dish!
author: Moe D.

description: Fantastic restaurant. The food was out of this world--unbelievably savory and complex flavors. Make sure to save room for dessert. The chocolate custard with coffee ice cream is the best thing you'll ever eat. Order it even if you're not hungry so you can take it home and make love to it. I wish I had more stomachs.
author: Jason G.

description:
I had heard a few good things about this place so I made a reservation well in advance for 7:45. 

The outside is very bland, but upon stepping in, the decor is really nice, high ceilings, trendy, and actually, a lot of light for what you would perceive is being in an old warehouse. 

We were seated right away, but the table was a) cold, I was right under a fan b) very close to other tables c) Under a loud speaker and d) kinda far away from my date, so with the loud music, just felt like conversation might be difficult. So, we moved to the barish seating, where you are higher up and can overlook everyone and sit a bit closer. The seats have backs on them at this bar area, which I really like. Also, then you can make friends with those sitting next to you. This I also really like! 

Skipped the tasting menu, since with two people, you can have a bottle of wine and enough food to fill you up and actually try more food for the same price. 

Things ordered:

Pinot Noir- lovely blend, I wish I could remember the name, and I can't pull it up to reference it. (It was in the 50 dollar range)

fried padron peppers with lemon- these were very tasty, similar to the ones at Delfina. 

beef tartare with fermented kohlrabi, smoked curds & plancha bread- this was delicious. I am basically a steak tartare connoisseur and have tried it at maaaany places here in San Francisco. This one won't disappoint. Not too salty, very well seasoned, with some zip. I loved it. And the portion is actually pretty big, 3 people could easily share this and maybe even 4 for a small taste each. 

seared rock cod with sourdough & garlic scape-clam broth. - meh. Pretty, good tomatoes. Seemed too fancy for the fish. 

hen with squash, green tomato relish, avocado & potato- Was it reallly the hen?? This was good. I was unsure if the avocado fit. Seemed like an odd texture in there. I was also pretty full around this time, so I didn't finish the entire thing. 

Other notes:

Skipped dessert
Service was attentive without being overbearing. Really enjoyed our waiter, accent from North Carolina. 
Checked out the bar without having a drink (weird), looked fun and active and a good spot for a pre or post dinner cocktail. 
I thought the portions were a good size.
author: Danielle V.

description: This place is awesome, really blew me away. I had the steak and it was awesome. We also tried the beets and tuna, all delicious. Plus, night cap at Trick Dog. Make it happen!
author: Charles T.

description:
First off - Emily who helped us throughout the night was nice....the reason for my 2 star rating has to do with their lack of professionalism, inadequate level of service, and poor attention to detail...starting from the beginning:

1) We had a party of ten and for parties over eight, you need to book your reservation through their events coordinator. The process to do this was cumbersome and required many calls and not many timely responses.  My party had a few special requests (two with food allergies and one vegetarian) and the events coordinator never responded to my "emails" (yes, more than one). On the day of our reservation, I needed to call her to make sure she received my emails and confirm they could accommodate my requests.

2)  At the restaurant, some of the tasting menus were from today but some were from the previous day (a different menu).

3) As I mentioned, a couple of people in my party had food allergies -- one person is allergic to nuts and throughout the night the servers kept serving him dishes with nuts. It was almost comical as the chef came out and assured him it would not happen again....wrong....it happened again....this is unacceptable.

4) Overall, service during the night was on the slower side.....I understand the courses are paced but it took about 30 minutes for our first tasting menu item to come out.

5) When the bill came they mistakenly took $300 off the bill (there was confusion on their side if a deposit was left or not). I informed them I did not leave a deposit and they added $300 back onto the bill. I have no issues with the money but it just seemed they consistently lacked an attention to detail throughout the night.

In the end, I asked myself - would this happen at a restaurant like Gary Danko? Probably not - although you are basically paying the same price for an uninspiring experience. The tasting menu itself was ok (probably worth at least 3 stars) and desserts were really good. However, in this case the food could not mask their inadequate level of service, professionalism and attention to detail. If you are going to charge fine dining prices ---- please provide a fine dining experience. Thanks!
author: Joe M.

description:
Bleh. Not Flour + Water. Not even close. This is just one of many restaurants in SF cooking competent but uninspired dishes. Maybe I'm a victim of my own high expectations, but I just didn't find it special. 

The food was fine, but there are easier tables to get, with better food on them, at a lower price. -- I'm hesitant to say that last part because I don't want to sound like one of those people who eats out twice a year and then writes aggrieved reviews motivated primarily by sticker shock; that's not me. But if you're going to spend $100 on food and wine, you can do a lot better.
author: Chris P.

description:
Down in the missionary positioned neighborhood....sorry. I crack myself up sometimes.  There's this corner that has a bar, a restaurant and a salumeria all pretty much attached.  Dimly lit area, so if the area wasn't so hip, you'd feel like, where are these places?  At least Central Kitchen has a sign hanging.  

The space is simple.  Even barn like.  But the food (NOTE THE PORTION SIZE, be warned...if you're really hungry and on a budget, don't eat here) was truly awesome and even inspiring.  So that being said, we were definitely fan of the food and it seems they've worked out a lot of the service complaints in the other reviews.  

We were seated after only a brief short wait, as there were quite a few parties ahead of us. And when we weren't thrilled with the two top right in the front of the restaurant with lots of heavy traffic that even another couple turned down before us, they apologized and offered us to move when another table was getting up.  So A for effort, but we stayed and were totally amazed and food focused for the rest of the evening.  The manager and the waiter were notified immediately of our dislike and were really kind to acknowledge it.  That was good enough in my book.  So as a picky and often impatient New York, we just enjoyed and dropped the attitude.      

The bread and butter was honestly the perfect way to start out the meal.  The butter came at the desired room temp state with a warm caraway seeded roll.  Then we had the following: 

1st  Course: Beef tartare with celery root, fennel, sunflower & flax seeds (This portion was actually the biggest of them all for the evening).  Definitely the best rendition of a tartare I've ever had in my life.   Not the classic French prep though, so this made it all that much better. 

2nd Course: Mushrooms with parsnip, crackling & red hawk cheese.  The cheese was in foam form and the rest of the dish just worked.  We wanted to lick the plate.  For us, the dish embodied some of our favorite flavors and favorite foods.  Even an inside joke too.  Portion size was ok, not too much food, but as "salad" course I guess it was ok. 

3rd Course: Cod with roasted radishes, chard, black garlic & red wine.  Fish was cooked to perfection...great crispy skin and flesh was moist.  The red wine reduction was a welcomed highlight.  The portion of this dish was really small for the price.  

We opted to go without wine or drinks, but they have a decent wine list and a full bar too.  All in all, the wife and I were still happy to have eaten here and really enjoyed the service.  Definitely a great first dinner here in San Fran!
author: Caesar R.

description: Not sure what the other reviews are referring to because our dinner was seasoned perfectly, but maybe it's because I prefer less heavy food? The porcini pasta was fresh and delicious. Generally I prepare for disappointment regarding pasta but this was great ;   Mushrooms perfectly cooked and pasta just al dente topped with bread crumbs. The green spicy sauce accompanying the king salmon was great as was the baby lettuce salad with buttermilk dressing and pickled strawberries. Wine selection is well curated and waitstaff was friendly and thoughtful.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
Came to Central Kitchen for our anniversary dinner last Sunday night.
Appitisers were good, small plates...
Both of our mains ( duck and lamb, WERE SO OVER SALTED AS TO BE INEDIBLE.
They did replace them, and the food was ok.
Wine list is good, and the dessert was good. 
The place has a nice ambience, but way overpriced for what it is.
author: Ken M.

description: Tied with universal cafe for my favorite breakfast in the city. every pastry ooey gooey and delicious, had one egg bean meat cassoulet that was earth schattering. lovely interior.
author: Christy D.

description: One of the greatest dining experiences in the history of mankind!  Incredible diversity, and an incredible devotion to "the sauce."  Each dish had its own unique tasty, zesty sauce along with incredible accompaniments.  A chef that clearly takes delight in every single customer and every serving.  Kept working to make the meal even better, including little surprises.  Outstanding in-the-kitchen/near-the-kitchen environment, fantastic service.  A staff that knows it's got a winning formula and is dedicated to keeping their well-deserved reputation and clientele in tact with each and every interaction.
