Try the tasting menu (chef's choice) or do lots of small/medium plates.  Come hungry, come all.
author: Rob R.

description:
I wanted this restaurant to be so much better. After having the tasting menu last Wed, Feb 13, my fiance and I were extremely underwhelmed by the food we were served. While there was nothing wrong with any of the dishes, there was nothing really memorable about them either. A dish that includes fresh uni, mussels and crab, is pretty difficult to mess up, in my opinion. What we were served was quite mediocre. 

In addition to the lackluster food, the music choice was extremely odd--I think at one point we were listening to the Sturm und Drang of Godspeed You Black Emperor while eating quail--this came off more comically than anything. 

Great space, friendly warm wait staff....sub par food. I'm hoping they get it together soon, there is a lot of potential.
author: Steven W.

description: This a restaurant were everything is executed to perfection. We were a party of 4: 3 chefs and myself. We ordered all of the small appetizers, 3 appetizers, 2 or 3 main courses and all 4 of the desserts. We all 4 loved it!!! Definitely recommend everyone who enjoys great food in a cute unpretentious place but yet very cool  to visit and enjoy of a great dinner. Service was very good; very knowledgable of their wines, menu and really friendly. Have i mentioned all of their ingredients are organic? I mean.. What else can you ask for!
author: Ailin P.

description:
Central Kitchen has been on my list for a while and they did not disappoint! Every dish I tried was perfectly balanced, beautifully plated and creative. I look forward to returning and trying their tasting menu as well as brunch. 
The staff works as a team and everyone working there seemed just as happy to be there as I was, which to me is something that makes a restaurant truly great.
author: Kai J.

description:
Loved the atmosphere.  

I could probably end the review there.  But I guess I'll give a little more info...

When the two of us arrived, I was impressed with the atmosphere, decore, design, lighting, etc. of the restaurant. Our resos were at 9:30, we were sat around 9:45pm, I'll let that go, they were busy for a Thursday night.  Our server was very friendly, attentive and pleasant.  Sure she recommended ordering way too much food (which we ordered less than 3/4's of what she recommended and were still too full to eat everything), but oh well.  The tasting menu looked amazing, and we were hungry, but not out of control hungry.  So we opted to go a la carte.

So let me preface by saying that I'm a big fan of their other restaurant Flour + Water. Only been once, but had a great experience and the food was delicious.  Unfortunately the story for this place for me, was that the food here was incredibly bland. Everything we had was bland and not memorable at all. To the point that I don't remember what we even ordered.  Except for the Beef tartare with radish greens, smoked curds & green garlic, which was pretty good.  I know that sounds like a copout of trying to get out of including details in a review, but it's not. After each dish arrived, it was followed by being underwhelmed.  I can't even remember what we ordered. And my memory faded on this literally the day after we went there.

When we walked in I immediately wanted to love it. Had heard good things too. But when we got up to leave, was extremely underwhelmed.  I hope they improve upon the food, because for the atmosphere alone, I'd be willing to give it another shot.

Additional Tip:  They only offer beer and wine. So no, you can't get a specialty cocktail with a floater of beer resting in a wine carafe with a shot of tequila on the side.  Sorry.

Additional Additional Tip: NEVER attempt to walk into Trick Dog after dinner, that is next door and has a back entrance that you can get to through a shared hallway that leads to a bathroom.  You HAVE to go in the front entrance to Trick Dog. Otherwise a smallish rude little server named Brian (not his real name), who I nicknamed "The Guard," will step in front of you and block you from doing so, even if he has to sprint from across the room to block. You won't even be allowed to do this immediately upon spending $150+ on dinner for two and getting up from your seat.  I don't like "The Guard." 

Ok, good talk, that's all I have for now. You only live twice!
author: John R.

description: The service was amazing .. Food not so much. Very dull other then the lamb, which was outstanding. The bill will take you by surprise as well, if your order the tasting
author: David B.

description:
Came here for lunch this past Sunday. 

Love the blocks of firewood outside. Love the succulent planters that decorate the beautiful space.

Then came the drinks which were on point.

And then the flop came with the food. It wasn't terrible, but after reading so many articles on them lately, we expected so much more. 

Order: (pretty much everything off the brunch menu)
+ warm sticky bun, bacon, medjool date, walnut
+ fried eggs, braised lamb, coal  roasted rutabaga, hollandaise
+ baked egg, chorizo stew, sweet potato, pepita & cilantro relish
+ pain de mie french oast, lavendaer salt, currants, fromage blanc
+ poached eggs, polenta, pork belly, trumpets, carrot, red eye jus
+ crispy potatoes, malt vinegar, sunchoke, parmigiano
+ sage chicken sausage, maple brown butte
+ smoked bacon
+ sourdough toast, cultured butter

Perks:
- the chorizo stew was my fave out of all the entrees

Jerks:
- not a fan of goat cheese they put on my french toast
- my pork belly dish has poached eggs that were way overcooked..the egg yolk was almost completely and had the consistency of a hard boiled egg
- chicken sausage was super bland

Bill total came out to $140 for the 4 of us...which would have been ok if the food was better.

TIP: they have outside seating for when we get nice weather :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
What we experienced trying to eat here last night, emphasis on the "trying", we left... Dim lights, wanky music,Marina type patrons,ridiculously tiny micro portions walking by the table,suuuper steep prices for those micro portions(the guy next to me had 3/4 of his entire plate of food on his first forkful !) . Not one item on the menu that  was vegetarian. Not ONE. 
  Summary; do not go here if you are- Hungry ,vegetarian and/or not pretentious.
author: Leann W.

description:
Review is for brunch:

That bacon sticky bun might be the most divine thing I've ever tasted. Nothing else matters.

Bonus: good service, super sweet location and space.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Brunch review:
AMAZING!!!!! WHAT A GEM! There was 4 of us and we each ordered something different so we can share.

We had our eye on the fried chicken eggs benedict because it looked amazing at a neighboring table.  Unfortunately they ran out.

I did the soft scramble with eggplant ,chard, and goat cheese: SOOO GOOD I LOVE
gf got the baked eggs with avo toast: AGAIN SOOO GOOD
The other two dishes were the fried egg sandwich and the pork and beans.  Both excellent but I loved the 1st two dishes more.
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
Simply amazing. The attention to detail on every plate that came out was fantastic. Some dishes like the sumac chips with elderberry had unique and subtle flavors whereas the dessert of chocolate custard and coffee icecream was bold and sweet but not overpowering. 

Service was great too. Knowledgeable about everything on the menu. I even had a crumb on my table and the waiter nonchalantly brushed it up on his way past.
author: Reid C.

description: Creative cuisine, smaller portions, very good service. Music can be loud.
author: Jaydee B.

description:
Above average for a high-end California style restaurant in SF, but I feel like it's a little over-hyped.

It's a beautifully designed restaurant, but on the expensive side with small portions.

The Stone Fruit and Cucumber Salad was excellent.

I really enjoyed the salmon and the hen with squash.

Great wine menu-I love Robert Sinskey's Rose.

Our server was very friendly and professional. We had great service.
author: Katherine M.

description: We enjoyed the food very much but wished to have had more attentive and friendly service from Neda considering the quality and price of the meal. She hardly checked in at all with us throughout, and failed to give us a chance to order wine before the end of the meal. We'd have stayed for dessert, but were made to wait so long that we decided it would be less frustrating to go elsewhere.
author: A.E. M.

description:
Three stars for noise level coupled with very loud music. Five stars for the food, which was spectacular!

Went last night and had the liver mousse and grilled squid. Entree was slow cooked halibut with the most amazingly fresh tomato purée.  Also tasted the pork belly with faro wrapped chard. Each bite was a morsel of extreme delight!  

I highly recommend this gem!
author: LeAndra M.

description:
It's trendy. Can't you tell by the overly simplistic name, probably-refurbished wood and succulents against the walls, and casually-clad staff that, all in all, ironically make this restaurant out to be a tad bit pretentious? But never mind that, the food is good! The dishes show that the chef has amazing technique because each dish I tried was very well-executed.

Liver mousse was very smooth without any gaminess and was topped with kumquat and thinly sliced picked radish that cut right through the fat.

Raw Beausoleil oysters seemed a little overdressed at first (I usually take them with just a spritz of lemon), but they were fresh and left a nice long finish.

Lemongrass soup tasted kind of Asian-y, which I didn't like very much, but to someone who isn't biased (read: Asian), the flavors between the lemongrass, cilantro and oysters were balanced and overall good.

Seared cod was so impeccably done, it almost seemed impossible! How is it that you can sear fish without compromising the fish's texture? It was like eating sashimi, but it was cooked. Pureed potatoes had the consistency of toothpaste and turned me off a little, but I didn't mind so much once they were in my mouth.

Dessert was orange & beet sherbert, and not worth mentioning, except for the fact that it wasn't too sweet and I like it like that.

Wine of choice was Bakerlane syrah from Sonoma. At first I was hesitant to pair a syrah against what I consider "lighter" fare, but the server's eyes lit up when I made my choice and told me not to worry. That's always comforting. To my surprise it went beautifully with everything, and it reminded me of laying on the grass and wearing flowers in my hair. And just like every summer fling, it came and went leaving good memories. No wonder they serve it by the bottle only, because that syrah's lifespan must be only 2 hours after opening.

Ended the meal with their port wine--can't remember the name anymore. It was a good port, not to syrup-y nor sweet.

Good meal and I don't believe it was THAT unreasonably priced.
author: Trinity G.

description:
Their brunch menu is small, not necessarily a good or bad thing. The burger I had was awesome though. 

However, what I am giving a low rating for, follows.
We showed up at 1:10 PM and they close at 2 PM on Sundays. We asked for a table/ to put our name down and whoever was hosting gave us this look that read "we don't want your business" and response like "I don't know if we are going to be able to" even though it was 45 minutes before it was closing. It was not that busy and the space is pretty large, so it seemed like the host was just more over her busy morning dealing with brunchers, rather than the restaurant actually being too busy. After I explained that we had been meaning to eat there a lot lately, and I was moving away from the city finally agreed to out our name down and said "she'd try her hardest" but in the least sincere way possible, more so just speaking to get us to leave.. We ended up getting a table but none of it was done with a smile. My friends and I all felt like we were giving our money to people who didn't want it.
author: Brooke W.

description:
Came here for Sunday Brunch (make reservations!). Located in the Mission District, it's definitely away from all the tourists and is more of a locals spot.  

Awesome decor: two rooms adjoining with the actual kitchen overlooking the dining area which make it even more intimate.  

Brunch menu (which I believe changes daily)  had a variety of options, we chose to start the 1/2 dozen oysters, the french toast, and the bacon & medjool date sticky bun (w/ walnut). OMG, can I just say the sticky bun is seriously the best tasting sticky bun I've had. Just enough Bacon not to make it too salty to balance out the sweetness of the sticky bun. We loved it so much we ordered a 2nd one to have for after our meal! The french toast was pretty good too but if you had to pick between the two, go with the sticky bun!

For our main course, we ordered several different egg options. The best one of the bunch was the fried eggs with blood sausage, eggplant, black ride, and creme fraiche.  Quite delish and reminded me a filipino dish that I love, Dinuguan (for those of you who know what that is).  

Service was friendly and pretty quick for Sunday brunch. No complaints here. 

Definitely recommend and am coming back here again.
author: Phillip D.

description:
With its pedigree, I think I expected more from Central Kitchen.  Also, it didn't help that we had to wait quite a while before we we were seated so by then, we were not as hungry anymore (because we kept filling up on drinks next door at the bar).

First we discovered as soon as we were seated was that they only serve wine and beer, no liquor.  And also, not even diet coke.  Just the full-sugar kind.  Strange.

The three cheese plate served on top of crispy lavosh bread was quite good, especially the toppings of fennel and dill.  But my favorite dish here was the liver mousse with pickled spring onions that's served in a jar.  Decadent and creamy. 

The herb and ricotta dumplings with asparagus was also not bad ... the dumplings literally melt in your mouth.  The roasted carrots with hen, almond and coffee was ok.

We also had an a la carte of one of the tasting menu items that sounded amazing (octopus, chorizo and pork belly) but I think it sounded better than it tasted (not bad at all but our expectations of that combo were sky high).

Most disappointing were the raw oysters with ginger and grapefruit foam.  The foam was way overpowering and left a bad taste in our mouths.  For the rest of them, we literally rinsed out the oysters with water and preferred them plain.

Not a bad place but I guess we were hoping to have that same wow factor experience that some of had when we first tried Flour + Water's pizza and pasta, which we didn't quite get here.
author: F. P.

description: Typical San Francisco restaurant . Small portions, a little over priced and I attentive service. Dodd was good, but you def paged for it and waited for it. It's true, most people end up here when they are waiting for flour +water. My suggestion is to just keep waiting and if you dint name sure you finish your cocktails from trick dog before your table is ready cause you can't bring them with you...
author: Leslie S.

description:
TERRIBLE!

This is one of those trendy places that thinks they're doing you a favor by letting you dine at their establishment. We had a 6:30 pm reservation, arrived on time, the restaurant was empty - and the hostess made us wait for a table.  I finally asked if I could sit down because I was tired.  It then took 15 minutes for a server to come by.  I left.  Don't go here.
author: David L.

description:
Got the liver mousse - what liver you ask? The best kind. 
Duck Rillete- phenomenal 
Melon and Cucumber salad- ugh drool, so good. 

Main dishes: 
Hen- drop dead awesome, so tender
Duck- ehhhhhh not again

End of story.  

Oh, not quite. Chocolate custard. Heaven in a mason jar.
author: Casie M.

description:
Pretentiousness 5 stars 
Food 3 stars
Value 1 star

Nice decor, but the combination of elbow-to-elbow seating and lots of concrete made it quite loud.

The food was pleasant and varied but the uber-small servings actually made me laugh. There is 'delicate' and then there is 'pretentiously small'. To have these 'servings' then be rather expensive makes for atrocious value. 

We both felt a bit queasy afterwards, which smoshed this farther down toward "Zero Stars/middle of Oklahoma sad truck stop restaurant" terrain.
author: K W.

description:
If you like small portions of mediocre food at really high prices, then you'll LOVE Central Kitchen.

+1 star for the nice woman who turned out to be a server and who kindly guided me to the entrance when I was trying to access the restaurant by pushing my way through what looked like a door but was actually an exterior wall.
author: matt c.

description:
This is a wonderful place to taste great food.  Just remember to eat before you get here, or have reservations to eat at another restaurant afterwards because the portions here are elfin small.  Micro.  Petite.  Wee.  Minuscule.  Really, the portions are about a third undersized to be considered even small.  The main courses come out looking like appetizers or tapas.  The appetizer portions, well, get out your magnifying glass.

Yes, the roasted hen was delicious, as was my goil's halibut.  The service was efficient.  The wine list was good.  

But at this very pricy level, another three or four bites of the main course might have made it so my stomach didn't growl with hunger on the way out.  Wish there was a pizza place around the corner so I could grab a slice or two to round out my meal at Central Kitchen.

As for the space, it's kind of like eating in a live-work loft.  It's all trendy brick, glass, metal, and wood.  Hipster industrial chic.

And the music was WAY TOO LOUD and ruined what should have been a nice, romantic evening because I could not hear my goil very well and had to ask her to repeat herself.  Really, Elton John blasted and booming over a meal for two that cost $180 just doesn't really make for a romantic evening out.

Great food, I'm willing to pay for it, there just needs to be more of it.
author: Paul S.

description: Everything is special and fresh to perfection.  Bit on the small side of portions especially the entrees.  Three of us had six plates three appetizers one mid  and two entrees.  Wygou beef was delicious. I will come again after I mortgage my house.
author: Mike S.

description:
Nice ambiance and decoration in a quiet area of San Francisco. 

Really good food. The fact that the menu selection is short makes it easier to choose and you also feel like all the products are fresh.

Definitely go for the chocolate mousse for the dessert. You WON'T regret it!

To sum it up: good for a fancy date and/or group dinner. I'd go back.
author: Julien N.

description:
I think we were expecting a little more since we are fans of flour+water.  We came on a weekday for a date night with my wife.  We arrived early for our 5:30 reservation since we had a show to catch later that night.  We were welcomed and informed that doors would open in a few so we strolled down to check out salumeria which was a very cute spot (probably great for some lunchtime sandwiches and snacks!).

Once we were seated, we were greeted by very friendly waitresses with a quick explanation of the menu (a la carte/tasting menu).  The ambiance is very relaxed and casual with tons of natural light.  We decided to go with the tasting menu since it was our first time and were quickly served the first few 'bites.'  They bites were a nice start highlighted by the fried rabbit rillette and the refreshing plum soda.  The courses came out the kitchen quite quickly as we were one of the first guests. 

The middle of the tasting was solid but not spectacular.  A melon soup with speck, basil, and olives was refreshing and familiar.  Tomato with bread sauce and squash blossoms was also ok but the oven roasted tomatoes (or slow cooked?) were just too sweet and masked anything and everything.

The meal was highlighted by a perfectly cooked halibut accompanied by very tasty baby squids a la plancha served with a vinaigrette made from the leftover squid juices.  I think this dish showed some of the subtlety of flavor and refinement that I was hoping to see at CK.  This highlight was followed by a somewhat dull quail course with chanterells.  I felt that the dish was very one note in both taste and texture.  Everything was crispy and a bit dried out on the plate, as if some components had been sitting under a heat lamp on the pass for too long.  Although I always put more onus on taste, the presentation was also a bit sad in terms of color since everything was the same color on the plate.

Dessert was bit uninspired as well.

Overall, we enjoyed the friendly service and ambiance, although the street front is under quite a bit of construction right now.  The food was solid, but at $89 per person for the tasting, I wouldn't compare it favorably to places like Commonwealth or Sons & Daughters and hence the 3 star review.  I would definitely be open to returning to try some of the staples on the a la carte menu and give CK another try.
author: Chris T.

description:
CK has their share of cancellations and they end up losing (too much) money. So heads up - they charge $30 a person if you make a reservation and make any changes.

They have yet to charge anyone for this yet, per one of the owners. 
They are attempting to do something good for the hood. Brownie points all around.
author: Jane W.

description: We held our holiday party at this restaurant and had a great time.  The food was very tasty.  The liver mousse and ricotta spread were so yummy.  I loved the chickory salad with the nettles and the beet salad. The pasta dish was delectable.  The hen was very moist. I also loved the dessert.   The upstairs room had a cool look to it and felt energetic.   I highly recommend this for a party.
author: Myoung K.

description:
Since our friends were not yet here, we joined them next door at Trick Dog for a drink. My date notified the hostess that we would be back with the entire party. 
Well I think we probably returned in ~15min, and our table was not available immediately. Ugh I felt bad, because my date had said a number of times already how hungry he was. His last meal was late morning, since this was technically our first date, I didn't know him well enough to know if he gets grumpy when hungry... Unfortunately I am like that. But he was super chill. The guys ordered a bottle Pinot while we waited. And luckily we did not wait too long. 
We sat in the front dining area. It felt like we were in an enclosed patio because the high ceiling had a skylight above us. The decor was bright and modern yet country-ish. Light wood dining tables and chairs. The ambiance seemed fresh and new, reminds me of places in SoCal. 
Well the moment we sat down my date says that we are ordering one of everything. It seemed like we did.  We all ordered an app and main entree each, but we shared everything, which I love! My date orderd another bottle of wine; this time a Bordeaux, which I thought was much better than the Pinot. 
So I ordered the hamachi or yellow tail sashimi; doubt that's what the dish is called, but that's basically what it is, and it was delicious! I got to try the fried green tomatoes, a cheese platter, and fruit salad... All were pretty tasty. My main entree was octopus, but there was something else in it... Shredded beef or carnitas? I don't know because by this point I've had several cocktails.  Whatever was in it was yummy. I got to taste the pasta, salmon and hen dishes... No complaints, they were all yummy too:)
Service was friendly and attentive. We skipped on dessert. They all liked my idea... That wine is my dessert... So we were off to our next spot... Amelie for dessert:)
author: Myra M.

description: A modern, simple, ambiance with clean refine flavors. A delightful brunch! A short list menu but each plate has its own clear personality. High kudos yo their drinks!!! I would comeback for a lay back celebration.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I'm not sure why some folks here gave bad reviews on the portion amounts, perhaps its because I ordered the 8 course tasting menu, but by the end of the last few dishes I waddled out with a ridiculously full stomach (and a big grin).

The service was impeccable.  The food was INCREDIBLE, and the aesthetic of the restaurant is refreshingly casual for fine dining.
author: DJ P.

description: Excellent service!! I always ask a lot of questions and the server would go ask if he didn't have the answer. The food was really good, it was fresh, but I was a bit lost in some of the flavor combinations. I missed something crunchy in the trout dish. The coconut dessert was delicious. I recommend it.
author: Mattin N.

description:
Design: Bright and airy, with the popular "brand-spankin new rustic look" with lots of wood and simple lines.  A bit of an odd space where there's the indoor patio room next to the main dining room of the same size with a counter/bar on one end overlooking the dining room with the kitchen across.  Eh?

Music: Groovy retro indie rock...?  The Cars greatest hits were playing...

Food: Really delicious.  I'm not a big fan of Flour & Water, but the combinations at Central Kitchen were unique and really tasty.  The ham slices bundled up with Chabot cheddar, bread pieces, and greens was the unexpected favorite.  Looked weird but super good.  Grilled calamari were perfectly cooked meaty chunks and great flavors.  The duck entree was good.  (This was several glasses of wine in so don't remember it much. Speaking of which glasses are the same price as bottles about, so it's fine to pair with the food.)  Cheese plate was served on crispy cracker with honey and pistachios like a crunchy cheesy baklava.

Service:  Really nice, fun and casual.
author: Melanie C.

description:
You know what pisses me off?  Spending $170/person for dinner (!) and still being hungry and needing to eat again later.  But that's what happened last night when my friend and I got the tasting menu + wine pairing.  I had only glanced at the menu - I thought the $79 tasting menu *included* the wine, but the wine was an extra $50.  With tax&tip, ended up being $170/person.  

I'll admit the wine pours were generous (more than I could drink since I was driving) so the $50 there didn't feel that bad.

In terms of the food, I shouldn't be hungry after $80 of food!  The portions were *tiny*.  The food was hit or miss.  The slow baked halibut was one of the most amazing dishes I've ever had.  But some of the dishes tried too hard - the clams with horseradish (yuck) for one.   They do get +1 for accommodating the fact that I'm a pescetarian with the tasting menu (my friend got the standard tasting menu).   And did I mention the tiny portions?

-1 for playing the music way too loud.  And -1 for beer + wine only, no liquor.

I want to like this place, I really do.  I want to want to go back.  But last night's $170 dinner left me feeling kind of ripped off.
author: Katie M.

description:
Central Kitchen is located off of Mission st., tucked into a quiet residential area so it felt like I was going to a secret restaurant, which I really liked. The restaurant itself looks like an artists loft with high ceilings and exposed wooden beams which I also really liked. 

We'll start with the appetizer - we ordered the wagyu tar tar which is a good portion to split between two people. The wagyu tar tar was amazing and I could've made a meal just out of this appetizer. It tasted like Korean BBQ mixed with bruchetta. For our main course we split the porchetta which was not good. The porchetta was basically a hunk of pork meat with about a 60/40 meat to fat ratio. I appreciate that Central Kitchen has their own butchers onsite but this was literally a slab or pork meat on a plate so it wasn't visually pleasing either. I would skip this option. For dessert we ordered the chocolate custard which was amazing and ended our meal with a french press which was also good. 

Overall great environment, service and food for the most part. I wonder how this review would've looked had we not ordered the porchetta. I would definitely recommend people check this place out though. Enjoy
author: Ken C.

description:
Searching for "Hip restaurants in Mission, San Francisco" returned an article by Oregonline and it puts Central Kitchen on my radar. Seeing the other hip restaurants all but booked with no tables until 9, it was a slim picking among the top 10 hip restaurants in the Mission. I have been to too many Mission restaurants and at this point I need something that is beyond good or acceptable. I want extraordinary. Flour + Water is excellent. Central Kitchen, in my opinion, different, good and in line with my more French leaning taste vs. Italian taste. They are sister restaurants, therefore, they serve "water with gas" aka sparkling water. Organic radishes with lard and sea salt, genius. It is what I'd eat in a Parisian cafe. Bread is amazing of course, chicken liver with kumquat jelly, inventive and totally hit (my) spot. Then there is the rabbit with vegetables and the sea bass with crispy skin, both are delicious. I had the cheese plate to share which was good but could use a hint of dry nuts. I had lots of sparkling water and a glass of red Spanish wine to wash down my chicken liver mouse in a jar. This dish reminds me of Le Comptoir du Relais, one my favorite Parisian restaurants in Saint-Michel. My go to restaurant whenever I'm in Paris, where I could sit outside after a summer storm hits the streets of Paris, light up a ciggi (yes that's what I'd do in Paris, they do allow cigarettes outside in the sidewalk tables but no longer inside - nasty habit I know) and enjoy my 3 PM first proper meal (discount the fact I've already had my morning cappuccino). CK is not meant to be Parisian or Italian, it's meant to be Californian new cuisine. But it's fabulous, as good as it gets really.  It's hard to go anywhere else in this part of the continent without comparing the ever growing list of fabulous Californian restaurants in San Francisco, it's also increasingly difficult for me to want to go anywhere else to eat but in the Mission. Alan Richman from GQ termed it as one of the most outstanding restaurants in 2013. That says something since I sort of worship Alan Richman. It deserves one Michelin star. From food to service. Would I be back? Yes! In fact, I was barely 3 blocks away yesterday on 23rd and Florida for an art exhibit and it's very close to Verdi cub. 

I'd have to bring folks of highfalutin taste here. It's not pedestrian. I can go for pedestrian, but sometimes, I need a little slice of heaven to remind myself that life is as good as it gets when the food is this good.
author: Victoria E.

description:
I like what this place is doing. The dishes are very creative with a lot of thought behind the concept. Very well balanced dishes. Not overly simple and not too complicated with California touch with the local ingredients. I would suggest this place to a foody. The ambiance, I thought was nice.. A bit dark but who need a bunch of light. 

I want to come back and do the pre-fix.. Another day. 

Down side.. No cabs, really none.
author: Penelope S.

description:
yes its dark in here.  people were trying to read the menu with the light from their phones.  

let me preface what im about to say with the fact that i think this place is a tad understaffed.  i dont know if it was because it was monday.  but there was one server for the area we were in i think.  maybe two?  and then the lady who was the hostess also did some serving. our server was sweating up a storm

we arrived at 7:40 for our 8:15 reservation.  ok we were early but not horrendously so and they were not super busy.  we waited until about 8:05 to sit down.  not like they were full.  understaffed? maybe .... 

the tasting menu is only available for the whole party.  bummer wouldve been nice to try some of those dishes.  some of them werent available on the a la carte menu

we started with warm bread.  i loved the beet salad:  roasted beets with fromage blanc, pear & rye crumble.  the flavors and textures were complex and interesting. the liver mousse with spiced wine, pomegranate & mustard tasted like chinese food to me.  not sure why.  and then the.king trumpet mushrooms with parsnip & chicken crackling. lots of parsnip and mushroom.  wished there was more chicken crackling

for mains we shared the hen confit with smoked dates, roasted carrots, almond & coffee, which was yummy but then i began to wish there were less carrots.  it was way carrotty.  the wagyu bavette with barley, chanterelle & salsify was delicious but the black cod with brandade, spring onions & chorizo was kind of a disappointment.  it was bland and definitely lacking

the dessert menu was limited and actually wasnt descriptive enough for me to want to try anything
author: claudia y.

description:
I was anxious to try this and was very disappointed...

Unfriendly staff and boring ambiance, but that's not nearly as important as the food.

Small portions,tremendously overpriced. Really nothing to write home about apart from pretentious ingredients (hen cooked served with oyster foam sauce, apple fritters with bacon,etc). Waste of time and money - I won't be going back.
author: alessandra d.

description:
If you were looking for a reason to move to the gap between Potrero Hill and the Mission, look no further than the new spot: Central Kitchen.

A new, patio-driven spot on Florida and 20th by the folks that brought us Flour + Water, replete with retractable roof.

The place is small but all the openness gives the impression of a much larger spot.

No liquor, but a nice yet short and extremely interesting list of wines, plus a signature cocktail provides some great. Libations to loosen you up and whet your palate prior to the small yet delicious plates of food.
author: Kevin N.

description:
We made a reservation to try Central Kitchen before we read any of the reviews...I thought I would share my experience in hopes it helps balance out some of the other less positive reviews.

Place is nice, great location, and parking availability is reasonable compared to other areas of the city. Only gripe here is the music was really, unnecessarily loud. The crowd noise I can deal with but the restaurant didn't need to add theirs on top of everything.

Food is right up there, and while I too wished some of the portions were just a bit bigger, I didn't leave hungry. Some may consider this place pricey but it's on par with other places like Bar Tartine or Bar Bambino. The pork trotters were excellent, crispy and very flavorful. The rabbit was delicious as was the halibut small plate starter. The food could have been just a tad hotter...but not bad enough for me to send plates back. Didn't have any dessert but stared down the table next to us' lemon cake dessert....mmm!!

Our server (Stuart) was pretty good, attentive but not bothersome. Friendly, as with all the different staff that brought us everything from drinks, to starters, and the main courses. Each time a plate was placed in front of you, it would be accompanied by a full explanation of the dish and the make-up of it. Excellent touch!!!

I would definitely recommend giving this place a try. Don't go with any expectations and judge for yourself.
author: Jack D.

description:
Atmosphere - 4 of 5
Service - 5 of 5
Food - 3 of 5

I prefer flower+water to this restaurant. Maybe it's my affinity for pasta?
author: Marc K.

description: Beautiful food. Delicious and subtle flavors with some really nice touches. We had the tasting menu and were very impressed by the exciting combos. The meal just kept getting better as it went on. No gripes. No suggestions. A cracking feed.
author: Chris H.

description:
Average here is 3.5 stars, and that seems about right. 

First off, they have more tables than are listed in Open Table, so call if you don't see anything at the time you want. Left a voicemail and got a call back the next day. Had a minor heart attack the day after that when someone else called saying no tables were available at the time I requested, then apologized when I said I already had one reserved, or so I thought. Yikes!

Was relieved to show up and find that indeed, my reservation did exist. 

Wanted to do a special meal with a friend, and this place seemed quiet from the street, but inside it's very noisy. Service was timed correctly, and unintrusive, but also slightly inexpert. Warm bread and locally churned butter, wow. 

All the food on the tasting menu was good, and perhaps my expectations were too high. Portions were small, and I was left wanting more. Two of the wines were underwhelming. 

It ended up being a perfectly nice evening, but maybe a little bit overpriced for what it was.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Central Kitchen is very much a welcomed newcomer into the SF dining scene.  It is worth checking out, and with its solid dining experience, I'm sure you'll want to return again and again, as the menu changes with the seasons.

Ambiance: A hidden gem (without a sign outside), Central Kitchen is like a friendly, neighborhood restaurant that you feel lucky to have found.  The Salumeria is so charming that you feel like you've been transported to Old World Italy.  The dining room is mostly wood and concrete imparting a simple, down-to-earth feel.  The tables were located beneath heat lamps which kept us  warm and cozy.  The noise level was consistent and a little lively with music.  We were able to carry on conversations with friends, even though the restaurant was full.

Service: The wait staff was very friendly, knowledgeable and very accommodating.  I was even able to order an entree (lamb with nettles) off the tasting menu and get a good-sized portion.

Food: While the selection is limited (4 entrees), the execution is near perfect. There are also plenty of appetizers to share and complement the entrees. This restaurant really lets the food's flavors shine through without over saucing.  They use fresh, organic, seasonal ingredients with a creative twist.  Favorite dishes included the lamb with nettles, duck confit croquette (off menu), beets, mushrooms, and apple confit, spice cake and vanilla ice cream. The wine list (by the glass) was well crafted, having international, very food friendly wines (slightly higher acidity and lower alcohol).

Overall: The food is outstanding and the flavors really come through.The waitstaff are friendly without being disruptive.  The casual room is very comfortable and well balanced with some rustic and modern elements. As for the price, the cost per item is reasonable for fine/casual dining. Central Kitchen is a definite keeper.
author: Eric Y.

description: We had a wonderful dinner here for our wedding anniversary, where we "let the kitchen choose" - and choose they did! It was delightful. Wonderful food, great and interesting wine pairings, and lovely service that was thoughtful but not intrusive.  We had a great time and loved celebrating with you - thank you!
author: Lis W.

description: Meh. Not awesome. We had the chef's tasting menu and one dish was really good. The rest of the meal was just ok and service was totally average. I was so excited to try it. One highlight was the super sweet host who greeted us when we arrived. She was awesome.
author: Roberta J.

description:
Rating: 4/5 stars

AMBIENCE:  The half indoor, half outdoor restaurant  with an open roof and visible kitchen is a tiny mecca in the Mission.  They definitely need to do something about the volume and the selection of the music they play though (They played "Tequila" by The Champs at one point in the evening .... I was confused).

SERVICE:  It's only been open for a short time, so they still have some kinks to work out with the timing, but our waitress was very cheerful and helpful.

FOOD:  The menu and wine list are small.  Thomas McNaughton is either working out the menu or he changes it up on a regular basis because several of the dishes that were mentioned on yelp weren't there when we went last night.  The wine list could use a little more depth and a few more aged wines.
 
My boyfriend and I started off the evening by being served an asparagus panna cotta concoction that was overly salty and impossible to finish.  We were worried to say the least.  Then they brought us freshly churned butter and bread ... and continued to bring us as much as we could eat over the course of the evening.

We split the poached artichokes with white beans and salted true cod.  It was beautifully presented and perfectly cooked.  We were surprised that such heavy ingredients could be so light and simple.  

For our mains, I ordered the duck with barley and leeks and my boyfriend ordered the veal with cabbage, horseradish and mushrooms.  Both dishes were stellar. I have never had such delicious leeks or amazingly unsalty duck.  The veal was out of this world and the horseradish didn't overpower any of the ingredients.

For dessert we went with the honey chiboust and the chocolate financier.  The chiboust was, by far,  the superior dish.  It had that perfect combination of sweet, salty, and tartness.

PRICE:  For two glasses of wine, a starter, two mains and two desserts the bill (before tip) came out to $140.  

FINAL NOTE:  I think this place is going to get a lot of negative reviews because people are expecting big, bold flavors, enormous portion sizes and a lower price point  and Thomas McNaughton is providing understated, clean, perfectly cooked californian cuisine.  Central Kitchen is like a soft, intimate whisper ... when most other restaurants in SF are loud conversations.
author: Lara O.

description:
Went with my wife for an extremely rare dinner without the kids.  I'm somewhere between 2 and 3 stars.

The staff are very friendly, but I'd still knock the service rating.  We had a 6 pm reservation and the restaurant was half full.  But it took forever for our appetizers to come out.  And when we did get our main courses, they were both luke warm.  Not sure if that was intentional or not, but I'm guessing no.

We started with the poached artichokes and raw halibut.  Artichokes were great, but I'd skip the halibut.  No flavor and the sauce didn't do much to enhance the fish.

Both mains were good.  We had the duck breast and spit roasted pork.  Our only complaint was the temperature of the food.  Also, portion sizes are not very big so order accordingly.
author: Chris T.

description:
Am a big fan of Flour and Water so was eagerly anticipating the opening of CK.  The week it opened, I took two of my friends from out of town for the tasting menu and it didn't disappoint.


I'm not always the most adventurous eater in the world so the way I judge a good restaurant is this:  would I trust the  kitchen to prepare foods I would never normally eat?   (e.g.  I might not order tripe from a food truck but I would absolutely order it at Bar Tartine) In this regard CK was superb. Everything we had including the head cheese (which I learned is more closely related to head than to cheese) was great. This is my new go-to restaurant for out-of-town guests.
author: ethan a.

description:
Had a very solid meal at Central Kitchen. Service was excellent, food came out promptly and was perfectly prepared. The entree portion was smaller than I expected (and I prefer European size portions). The food was creative and heavy on foams and deconstructions but was accessible with a focus on fresh local flavours.

Our server suggested we order 4-5 dishes but with 3 smaller dishes and one entree size we were completely happy. The menu is set up very similar to AQ with three dishes at 12-14, three at a couple dollars more and then three entrees at 24-28

We had the salad greens with egg yolk. As my spouse says eggs make everything better. This was a very addictive dish with a green herbaceous sauce. It was mix of cooked and raw greens, deceptively simple yet very satisfying.

The next dish was the artichoke hearts and salt cod with white beans. Again the sauce which was a foam really brought the dish together even if I find foam unappealing looking. The creamy texture was contrasted by the salt in the fish and artichoke hearts. I would get this dish again.

The next dish was the sardines with avocado. The spouse really liked this dish but I thought the texture was to similar in all the ingredients.

The final dish was a duck served confit and seared with greens and barley. The duck was cooked just right, the fat render and the meat tender but not over cooked. The portion of meat was small though even for western fine dining. It was served with lots of grains and greens which only highlighted the smaller portion of meat.

At the beginning of the meal we were served an amuse although it was larger than amuse usually is, a mix of a lime sorbet in a seltzer. 

For dessert we got the chocolate financier with chocolate sorbet & a honey comb crisp which at 10 dollars was small, rather bland and not a financier in any sense of the ones we eat in France.

They gave us a small box of cookies with the cheque. 

The atmosphere is pretty causal with the wait staff in denim but the service was professional. 

I've never been that impressed by Flour + Water finding it not very different than many common Italian restaurants in Europe but Central Kitchen shows more of the chef's personal style mixed with his love of good ingredients.

I'm planning on going back for the tasting menu. The table next to us was having the tasting menu and it looked quite good.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: We had a good time with good eats. Portions are small. The food is good and sometimes great.  I like the atmosphere and cozy pampering. Go for the spoiling.
author: Jenny F.

description: We shared several dishes and all were fantastically delish. Highly recommend CK. Don't understand the lower scores. Will go back for sure.
author: Hamila K.

description: Go for the 'Let the chef decide' menu for $70.   Well worth it, and just sit back, eat and enjoy.   The entire staff looks after you, and all were knowledgeable and inspired by the kitchen's creations.    One of the members of our party was Gluten-free, and they took great care even with the fixed-menu option.   The place was small, with an adjoining bar and private dining room.   The creations have a French Laundry feel but closer to home and for less $.   I see from the other reviews they were expecting a faster pace.  For us, we had good wine, good friends, spirited conversation and the pace was perfect.   I lost track of the number of courses, but each was amazing and cleaned plates were returned to the kitchen.  Well done.
author: Greg P.

description:
Dinner on Thurs March 27th.  730pm. 

The food was fine, in fact, more than fine. But for the price, it better be. 

However the service was abysmal.   

We ordered 3 appetizers, we got two.  The third one arrived 15 mins later, about the time one would expect the entrees to arrive. 
We ordered bread.  Nothing happened. 
We got a bottle of wine, they poured it but never came back to refresh glasses. Not a big deal but it just goes to show. 

The entrees were very late.  We were about ready to leave. Finally got the bread after we asked for it again. 
Asked for a second bottle of wine.  15 mins later.. still no wine. 
Yes. We complained to the front staff about the whole thing.   Its not like they cared that much frankly. 

If they had at least offered an excuse like "we're short staffed" or at least were a little concerned with their apology, I could understand.  And no, we werent dicks about complaining.  We were very nice. 

We skipped dessert and left. 

Ill never go back.
author: B M.

description:
do not go to Trick Dog first for drinks...or you'll be disappointed the entire meal and yearning for another drink from Trick Dog.

Rabbit pate - That was good...small but good... but tasted like chicken salad.

Red Clam ceviche - delicious!! lots of lime... but...missing.. ANYTHING TO EAT IT WITH.  we ate it with the bread the pate came with. 

beef tartare - yummy....scary with the raw egg yolk..but pretty flavorful. That could have been my favorite.

reminder here that it's wine and beer only at Central Kitchen... do not go to Trick Dog and have the Lion Heart...don't do it...

Entree was Halibut - wow... $27 for a bland piece of halibut that could have fit inside an altoid case.   thank God my girlfriend was skinny...and i ate alot of tartare... we would have starved. 

Experience - 4 stars because i loved catching up with an old friend.  Service - 3 stars
Food- 3 stars - overrated...
author: Mihae F.

description:
Well, there goes the neighbourhood.

If you were hoping for somewhere to get an affordable dinner anywhere near 20th and Harrison you can give up. This place is not going to help the locals, I doubt anyone within 4 blocks of the place can afford to eat here. 

Good food, but high prices.

And here's the thing, the food is OUTSTANDING. For an opening night, things seems relaxed, the pacing of the courses was right and the servers where there when you needed them. 

But, the plates need some work, the servings are definitely on the small side, and you risk going hungry unless you pile on the courses. They have also thrown the requisite communal table into the mix, which is great if I'm at a cafe and just having a snack, But the "same prices, different seating deal" bugs me. Check when you make your reservation.

The place has that modern open, feel, lots of wood and concrete that is the trend these days, so it can be hard to have a conversation, but, even in the patio, it was warm and comfortable.

So, 
-1 star for the small plates, and the communal table
-1 star for the prices

When you go there, Don't settle for average.
Expect great things, Insist on great things.

Poached hen. young potatoes. créme fråiche. dill and scallions: $24
Glass of wine : $9
Healthy SF: $2
Tax+tip: $11
Total: $45

Dinner for 2 with no starter or Dessert: $90
Entree, Main, and 2 glasses of wine will run you $85/pp
The tasting menu will run you $160/pp

(And that doesn't include the taxi to get there, because there is sod all
parking in the area, or the extra cocktails you will consume at the bar
next door while waiting for a table)

[Oh, and a note to 'Kevin N', This place is a long way from the Potrero Hill, and the roof is not retractable, did you actually go there? Or just dial in that review? ]
author: Geoff H.

description:
Table for two on a bustling Friday night. It was loud, hard to hear the soft spoken servers (all of them) and it didn't feel like the staff were happy to be there.

Both of us got the tasting menu; which was 90 a piece. 

The food, overall, was fairly good. The issues I had; while enjoying most of the items during first course I encountered a piece of shell in my oyster. I brought it to the attention of the staff, who were quick to offer me another one (which I declined) and an extra dessert course (which we did have and was the best of the three desserts).

For ninety dollars a person I expected a lot more from the food. Many of the components in the dishes were lacking seasoning and overall (for the price), it was disappointing. I've spent equal to or a little less at other places for tasting menus that far surpassed this place. 

I would definitely give it a second chance, but it won't be until I've sampled the many restaurants SF has to offer first. 

I was really hoping this would have been a truly positive experience and a great way to have a "fancy" dinner to end 2013.
author: Martin D.

description: Gorgeous building and cool atmosphere but bland flavors. Extremely unimpressed with the 'Let the Kitchen Decide' option. Was looking forward to a mind-blowing 6 course meal and left with an upset stomach. Courses weren't cohesive & lacked that 'wow!' factor you'd expect from such a high end restaurant. Pick another place to drop this much money.
author: Kay G.

description: Worth the hype! I went with a couple of girlfriends and we all immensely enjoyed our meals. We went with what our waiter told us were the popular pics - Fried Chicken Benedict, CK Brunch Burger, and the Medjool Date Sticky Bun to share. All were perfect size portions - somewhat large, but not an overwhelming amount. They also had a great brunch wine list and drink menu - recommend checking it out.
author: Tara T.

description:
Central Kitchen hits on the idea of refined food in a casual setting. For example, the roasted hen with dill, young potatoes, crème fraîche and scallions was one of the best dishes of the year. I didn't even like dill until this dish! Some other dishes generally hit (beets w/ raspberries and red walnuts), though components in some dishes seem experimental, which may vary depending on your tastes.

The wine list also has several high-quality producers. The breadth is wider than I expected from reading other Yelp reviews (e.g., selections from Sicily, Greece, Corsica, etc.). However, for a restaurant emphasizing No. California terroir with respect to food, a few additional selections from California producers would be in keeping with this theme.

The space itself is great. Looking forward to seeing how they evolve.
author: Brett V.

description: A relatively new restaurant to the SF restaurant scene. Serving fresh Californian cuisine. I like the casual setting and open space. My friend and I shared 4 dishes, a cheese plate, fresh tomato salad, butternut squash and hen and sea bass. All the dishes were quite delicious and the presentation was lovely. Somehow, in one or two dishes, the ingredients on the plate didn't quite sing together. It felt a like those ingredients just happened to be on the same plate. However, overall it is a really cool restaurant and I want to try some other dishes.
author: Ally W.

description:
We went there for a birthday dinner and hadn't disclosed that to the staff.  By them overhearing our conversation, picked up on the fact that it was a birthday and decorated the plate when they brought our desert.  I will say that the staff were very attentive and friendly.

Loved the decor and can see how it would be great on a sunny afternoon.  When the fog rolls in, they need to close that massive door, it was quite cold in the dining room.  I think we would have been better off in the courtyard with the heaters.

The music got to be distracting. Yes, sure we get it that it's cool to do throwback classic rock, but make it good, solid choices, not the most obscure albums of all time.

As for the food, it was tasty and pretty creative.  We liked everything that we were served.  The problem is it's treated a little too precious, being plated with tweezers, etc.  As my friend said, "I want to love it, but nothing is blowing me away."  When you consider all the great restaurants in SF, I'd say try this place, but know that it's pricey and probably won't go on the must-go-back list.
author: M F.

description:
A beautiful room with wonderful lighting.   The open kitchen,near which I was sitting, kind of reminds me of Cotogna.  The menu and aspirations seem reminiscent of Commonwealth.  By that I mean the food style seems to be small, complex plates, some of which work wonderfully.   I had the tasting menu, so with a glass of wine, tax, tip, and surcharge for healthy San Francisco the tab was over $100.  

Dinner began with a group of what amount to canapes:
Smoked salmon with creme fraiche and dill. Nice
Crispy pork trotter with fava bean. yum
Buttermilk granita with meyer lemon juice. Lovely

From here the course size increased progressively:
Shellfish with turnips and bonemarrow vinaigrette. Yum

Very al dente peas with fresh curd, walnut and rye crumble that brought the dish together.  Surprisingly good.

Olive oil baked halibut, with artichokes, nettles and an egg yolk.  The small serving of halibut was so nice on its own that the egg yolk, while OK, seemed superfluous.  I would have preferred more of the fish, which was perfectly complemented by the nettles and artichoke, without the yolk (the chef probably knows best here).

Spring lamb with white onion.  The lamb was very nice.  So much so that the portion seemed just the slightest bit undersized for the penultimate main course.  
I finished my meal with the cheese plate rather than the sweets for dietary reasons.  The cheese plate was very well put together and I enjoyed it.

Despite my quibbles about portion size, I left satisfied. 

Since this is yelp, one must say something to annoy or at least gain the attention of the restauranteur.  Here is my only suggestion:  I think they should provide a fork as well as a knife with the cheese plate to make it easier to manage.  

By the way, the service staff is friendly, helpful, and a great group.
author: David D.

description:
Ended up here when Flour and Water was packed. We went down the block to this place and got a seat at their big table in just a few a minutes.

The menu is somewhat limited, but the choices offer a good variety and the prices are... as expected, somewhat pricey. 

We did the tasting menu and everything was fantastic. Well thought out, carefully crafted, and served in a decorative manner. 

The bottom line is that if you live in or near the city and are enthusiastic about delicious food (I don't like the term "foodie") this is definitely a spot to try. We know that the city is full awesome places to eat, and this place is one them.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Okay, so...I've never been a believer in expensive meals.  $150 a person?  no way, right?  That's what the tasting menu, and wine, and tip will end up costing you here.  I love food as my gut suggests, but...$90 to start?  No way.  

...so Central Kitchen has, in one 'tasting menu' meal, changed my life.

This ridiculous umpteen-course extravaganza was highlighted by duck, salmon, and a fruit dessert with plums so sweet and fresh...I felt like it was the first time I tasted a plum in decades.  The preparation that went into each dish, the originality, the service, the presentation...it made for a magical experience, and one I cannot recommend highly enough.  

If you are in San Fran and want an upscale dinner that might just change your life, please go here and do the tasting menu.  We just walked in around 6pm and got a table, so its possible.  

They also offer a more price-friendly menu, of course, but I've only been the one time.
author: E O.

description:
In making reservations for last night, we had a very positive experience with the hostess and were very much looking forward to trying the restaurant.  Really enjoyed the atmosphere and food, but was incredibly disappointed with the service.

Our waiter seemed disinterested in helping to describe menu items and when he did describe a couple dishes, there was a complete lack of knowledge and enthusiasm for the food.  The same held true when asking about wine recommendations.  There was a lack of professionalism and aloofness that surprised me from a restaurant of this caliber.  

Upon paying the bill, he actually came by and took the tip and proceeded to stand by the cash register area counting it.  I would expect that a nice dining establishment would train waiters to leave the check fold on the table until the patrons had left.  When picking up his tip, he didn't so much as say, "Thank you" or any other type of acknowledgement.  

Until the restaurant has a more seasoned professional wait staff, I'd be hesitant to return.
author: Lee M.

description:
Shaken, not stirred!

Ever wonder what it would be like to attend a dinner in a rock star's kitchen? Try Central Kitchen for a swirl. Thomas McNaughton shakes the sheik off SF's restaurant scene with exquisite cuisine set to a rock n roll flavor. 

My thoughts...
Possibly the most creative dishes I've experienced in SF...I've dined at great places like Coi, Boulevard, Michael Mina, Fringalie, etc..still, presentations at Central Kitchen are more mentally engaging than anything I have come across in SF. 

I couldn't begin to describe the whole experience, but words like foam, mint, marrow, fennel, rock, champagne, barley, loud, laid back, the mission, not the mission, courtyard, friendly, boundaries, siblings, surprising, unpretentious, come to mind.

I have only dined at Flour and Water, chef  McNaughton's other restaurant down the street, a few times and many of these dinners were private seatings hosted by chef Mcnaughton in their dough room; totally not as stuffy as it may sound - he's very cool - very down to earth.  However, my sense from experiencing that, and now Central Kitchen, is that Central Kitchen is the restaurant that may possibly be the best representation of the personality that I have seen from him. There is something about Central Kitchen that is superbly meticulous, yet untamed and extroverted; possibly unscripted all together. I felt like I was at a buddy's house, after a later wilder night, and he just happens to be a master chef serving up fine dining, with a substantial wine list. No fuss. No tude. Just talent and an open invitation. But, he gets to pick the music. 

Tip: try both Floor and Water and Central Kitchen. It's interesting to compare them.
author: Dahvie J.

description:
I'm surprised this place doesn't do better on Yelp.
This was our second trip for dinner. First time was a while ago and I vaguely remember liking it. This time was really very enjoyable.
Decor: Pleasantly modern, if a bit cold. 
Service: Pretty competent and very friendly. A few glitches but it's not the kind of place that screams "impeccable service" so I wasn't bothered.
Menu: super-short (that's a good thing for me). Seasonal, changes daily. Nothing too weird or off-putting.
Dishes on our tasting menu:
Beet salad - very nice but I've had better.
Pine nut hummus - tasty and novel
Chicken liver mousse spread - A bit heavy on the palette but delicious
Squid-ink pasta with Octopus and seaweed - Wowza. One of the most unique pasta dishes I've had and a perfectly-balanced taste of the sea.
Pork Agnolotti with squash - delicious
Roast guinea hen with brussels sprouts and sausage - fantastic fall poultry dish. Meltingly tender breast meat, intensely-flavored rillettes, nice sauce.
Dessert: Caramel pot au creme with coffee ice cream - delicious but nothing you haven't tasted before.
Wines: Didn't have any on this visit, so I can't comment
Value: About what you'd expect for this level of cooking.
Overall this was a delicious meal and a really interesting dining experience. It's suited to foodies and that's pretty much everyone these days. Try it.
author: Al M.

description:
We all thought the food and drinks were good, but not anything great that we'd want to go back for.  Selection of beers was good.  Food was tasteful and pretty well done.  Walked away feeling content, full, a little bit poorer but not any experience I raved about to all my friends.

Though, the lavender dessert was awesome. great way to end the night.
author: Sandy K.

description:
We live around the corner and have been looking forward to this place opening but I am sad to report that I was not at all impressed with Central Kitchen :(

The Service
The servers were all pleasant but as a team they had a few foibles.  
No fewer than 4 servers visited our table before we placed our order.  The first asked us if we wanted still or bubbly water. The second followed shortly there after to ask us if we wanted still or bubbly water.  #3 inquired if we'd like a drink.  Then #1 came back with the water.  Followed by a fourth new face that delivered wine (but wasn't sure which glass went to who).  This all was kind of confusing and we weren't really sure who our waiter was after all of this so it was kind of hard to settle in, let alone get a rapport going.   

The Wine
Based on the price of the bottles and food, I was pleasantly surprised to see several glasses of wine priced under $10.   That said, the pour sizes seemed inconsistent and on the small side.   Also, just on the odd side, over the course of the night both of my dining companion's glasses of wine were delivered to the table already poured,  while for my glasses I was poured tasting sips at the table (as if ordering a bottle) followed by the regular pour.  This was just weird / inconsistent.  

The Food
Overall I enjoyed the creativity, quality of ingredients and the ideas on this menu.  We tried 2 starters: ham and smoker sturgeon, which were both tasty.  Followed by Salmon and Veal for the mains.  The mains sounded good on paper, were presented beautifully on the plate, and had great texture... just one thing missing: flavor.  Even amongst the multitude of sauces served with each, the flavor just wasn't there for us. 

I like the concept of what is going on here, but my lasting impression is that the execution and service didn't match the price point.  Hope I'm not being too harsh after they have only just recently opened, but figured I should give an honest account of my experience.
author: Dan F.

description: The only problem with Central Kitchen is you wonder why you eat anywhere else.  It is simply that perfect.  I feel sorry for all the other chefs out there.  Central Kitchen sets the bar very, very high.  I've been here half a dozen times and the food, people, and environment are pitch perfect.
author: Michelle A.

description: Positives: very nice platings, interesting flavors and menu combinations, and a beautiful atmosphere. Negatives: good but not *delicious* courses (e.g. flavorful but overcooked pork), and being prodded by waitstaff (to the point our dessert menu arrives before the last entree--honest mistake but emblematic of the sloppiness and attitude). It was a fine meal, but the problem is that this place's prices are maybe two to three times the value I'd attach to the experience. In other words, their prices put them in a particular category of restaurant to which their offering doesn't rise (hence my overall rating being relative to restaurants in that category). I don't think I'll be back unless I hear it's very different.
author: Paul B.

description:
Great food, ambience, construction and felt like I got what I paid for. Rare find of all qualities. Edgy restaurant with slight hipster overtones....but none of the attitude. Get the duck entree, very creative , bursting with dark fruit. Pair with a Pinot or Syrah. 

Downside. A little pricey and we sat at our table for 10+ minutes before a waiter came anywhere close to our table. Very strange to be honest. There were more staff than customers there at that early hour. No one was there. Ask for a waiter once you get there, don't be disappointed.
author: R. B.

description:
My meal was imaginative and very tasty.  I ordered the hen as a main dish.  It was amazing! The services was top notch too.  

Hope to return soon.
author: Jeff S.

description:
My husband and I had the pleasure of dinning here a few weeks ago. The space is absolutely beautiful and romantic, the service was friendly and attentive, and the food was amazing!!! We loved every thoughtfully prepared dish. We ate 
too many things on the menu to pinpoint one. We had the tasting plus a few additional items. Bring a friend enjoy a lovely evening! Don't come here looking for an excuse I complain, that will ruin any meal.
author: Sarah a.

description:
Want a kick-ass sandwich? There is almost no way to go wrong here. A must-try: roasted brussel sprouts with prosciutto!

To Central Kitchen: You guys really need to tell your story on r3lish:
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/relish-bite-sized-video-stories/id844759887?mt=8

This's where I would want to hear from you.
author: Michael L.

description: We held a private dinner here at the Salumeria for my wife and I's wedding dinner. They were able to create a 4 course chef's menu, with homemade pasta, two appetizers, a main course, and a homemade desert. There wasnt anything on the menu that wasnt fantastic. The chef even came out to greet us, and sign a cookbook for my mom. In working with the NTRG event staff, I cannot say enough about their professionalism. We had two pregnant women in the party, and they were able to accommodate many of our personal requests regarding the menu and the overall experience. We even had a misunderstanding with the floral arrangements, and they made sure to rectify it without issue. I would not hesitate to book a private event with them in the future. Great good, great staff, and AWESOME venue!
author: Justin R.

description: Delicious food, awesome service, beautiful space! I'm shocked by some of the reviews below.. I have nothing but good things to say about central kitchen after my dinner there last night (Thursday). We got the Josey bread and sunchoke hummus to start, followed by the carrot "salad" and tombo tuna, then the cauliflower pasta, THEN the tuna and the Bavette entrees. My group of 4 likes to eat :D we enjoyed all of it! What really made me love this place was the service though. Our waiter was attentive & put up with my mom's picky demands. He was a great sport about it! For Thursday's dessert menu they had 2 types of ice cream and 2 types of custard/mousses but my mom wanted a cake (we were celebrating my bday). Our waiter surprised us with 4 mini cakes the chef was able hto put together for us - so personalized and above and beyond any expectations we all had. Very amazing! We left happy & full.
author: Avery M.

description: I came here because it was recommend by a friend and wow I am glad we came. The service was ultra friendly, the dishes came out at perfect timing and the wine selection was absolutely fantastic. It was pricy, but relatively comparative to the other restaurants on the same level. Bill was about $240 for two people and a bottle of wine. I would definitely recommend this place and will come back again.
author: Robert R.

description:
Don't let anyone be late to your reservation or they'll make you wait over an hour for a table without notifying you, even when most of your party showed up on time.  Food is good but expensive for what you get.  Also it's ridiculous that being in sf, the wine list has no reasonably priced wines.

Lastly, they destroyed our cake (we saw the cake prior to cutting and it was fine but when she brought it out, half of the toppings shifted to one side) with no apology and charged $6/person cake cutting fee regardless whether or not everyone wanted cake.
author: Jess H.

description:
Central Kitchen was a pleasant surprise, one of the best meals I had in a long while.  For my entrée I ordered the cod with beets and barley (cooked perfectly) which was delicious, but I must say, the appetizers were AMAZING!  

We order several appetizers:  crispy duck & fermented chili, duck liver mousse, radishes with cultured butter & sea salt (refreshing and light), hamachi in a citrus vinaigrette (very fresh), roasted carrots with hen confit, smoke date, almond & coffee (unusual ingredients, but delicious).  True, there were only four entrées on the menu, but there were at least twelve appetizers.  I'm happy to order a few of those! 

Parking was easy, but there was no signage at the main entrance, and no marked address, so may be slightly difficult to find, especially at night.   

Great dining experience, this is my first 5 star rating for the year.  I will definitely be back.
author: E F.

description: impeccable food in a deceptively casual setting.  Hen roulade was perfectly moist and tender, seaweed chittara had a nice crunch from the bottarga crumbs, could have used a bit more seaweed umami flavor and been a bit more al dente, but these are minor quibbles. Peach dessert w/ crescenza and honeycomb candy was amazing.  Even the 16 oz dry aged ribeye was outstanding. sets a high bar for neighborhood restaurants.
author: H S.

description: Went with my girlfriend for dinner on a Friday night. We didn't have a reservation but were quickly seated at their counter which is actually one of the best places to sit and view the kitchen.  We tried the "let the kitchen decide" tasting menu. Some of the dishes were very good, while others, although creative, were not particularly special in flavor. We also tried the porcheta which was a huge serving and tasty, but I didn't care much for accompaniments as each was predominantly pickled. We will be back again to further explore the menu. 3.5 stars.
author: Terry K.

description:
This place is awesome if you like to wait 2.5 hours to be seated and served tiny portions of overpriced food.  

I don't usually write negative reviews, and I feel that I'm a pretty reasonable customer.  However, our wait combined with the meager amounts of underwhelming, exorbitant food prompted me to sit down and write.  I should have just eaten the pizza at the bar where we hung out waiting for a table. I would be so much richer now.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Enjoyed a business prix fixe dinner in their upper room which allowed for great opportunities to mingle given the dining tables are bar height.  Great selection of anti pasto to kick things off followed by an heirloom tomato salad with some sort of mild spicy pepper, which was not too hot.  They also served a seasonal melon dish with fresh burrata cheese...now this stole the show for me.  The cantaloupe and watermelon were super sweet and the cheese was nice and soft with the right amount of saltiness - it was a winner.  The third course was a pork agnolotti - think little ravioli pillows in a sauce of chile, corn and basil - most of the group raved about this dish.  The main course arrived with roasted fingerling tomatoes in a salsa verde, summer squash with an interesting sweet cheese sauce and shredded hen breast with some fresh apple wood sausage.  The hen breast was nice and crispy with a slight sweet n salty touch.  Chocolate custard was served for desert but by that time I had had my fill.  If you're into food creativity the by all means look up Central Kitchen.  I know that when I return to San Fran I will need to reserve a night for a second dining experience.
author: Jim M.

description:
The Sturgeon: AMAZING.
The asparagus amuse bouche: Delirious!
The caraway seed roll with butter: amazeballs
The spring onions with bacon: wonderfully molecular gastronomious!
The salmon: WHAAA???? So good. 
SAKE: YES. (Junmai from Nagano).

What was up with that amuse bouche?  Crazy good.

V. elegant restrained space.  Outstanding lighting.  Outdoor seating.  Though 2 seats at the end of the bar were best seats in the house.

Clientle from SF Magazine.

Sunset hours best.  Reminds me of painterly lighting from Range in the best hours.  But more delicious than Range and Commonwealth. 

F**k Commonwealth.  Just go here.
author: Allonsy A.

description: They had good liver mousse which I enjoyed on bread. What did I have else... Fish collar! That was so tasty, too. Other friends enjoyed food, too.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Dear Central Kitchen,

Thank you for seating our somewhat large group right away on Sunday night. We had a reservation-mix-up with your sister restaurant down the block, Flour + Water, and were unfortunately unable to eat there. (Side note: WTF, Flour + Water?! Your hostess is unnecessarily aggressive and unbelievably rude -- frankly, I can't believe that snotty B has a service industry job. What a sour puss!)  

Anyway, we had a very enjoyable dinner here and would definitely comeback. Both the hostess and server were friendly and accommodating. I really liked the space and atmosphere of the restaurant. 

Our meal was delicious: we got the pedron peppers, chicken liver mousse and figs to start. For our entrees some of us had the corn angolotti, someone got the pork, another the squid. Everything was delicious -- the only somewhat negative remark was that the portion of squid was rather small and not entree sized.

We had a couple of bottles of wine -- all of which were terrific. 

So why not 5 stars? Your (sorry, but I have to say it) lame dessert menu. It's so one note and pretty disappointing -- custard? sorbet? pudding? We would love it if you guys would add something like a cake, cookie, pie, crumble, brownie, bread pudding, etc. I'm not picky, just give me something warm and comforting.  Maybe next time...

Thanks again!
author: Anna S.

description: Here so far 45 minutes and no bread that we ordered. Hour and a half in had couple of appetizers and still waiting for entrees. So far bread great, food OK. Waiting for entree. Duck good. Get the service or back of house up and I would be happy.
author: Russ F.

description: I really enjoyed taking my girlfriend here for her birthday. waiter was very accomodating and helpful. food was unique, fresh, and tasty. Each dish was definitely a surprise. Not mind blowingly delicious but pretty good and Ill be back for sure. also enjoyed the music a lot!
author: Max H.

description: Food-gasm!  Every bite was better than the next.  Flavor explosions!  Started sharing with this creamy liver mousse then this tender sautéed squid yummyness and lastly this pork plate with wild rice omg.  Dessert was this Chocolate custard coffee icecream sea salt paired with a sweet, smokey dessert wine that sent us into a splendid food coma.  Can't wait to go back and try more plates.  Service was friendly and knowledgable about the menu.  they timed it so we were able to enjoy each plate without immediately bringing out the next.  Our server was excellent.  Wish I could remember her name :(.
author: Kim D.

description: I'm not sure what it says about a place when the best thing you ate there was the butter, but the butter here is top notch. My main dish was way too salty (although the poached egg was perfection) and our service was super slow, but overall things were ok...except the butter. The butter was phenomenal. I'd like to try their brunch. I'm not sure if that's because there might be toast and, presumably, more butter, but I also think they make a good poached egg...which would be terrific on buttered toast. So, yeah, I liked the butter.
author: Renee D.

description:
I had high expectations of this place but they fell short. The atmosphere, dinning area and ambiance are great and I would say that this is one of its saving graces. 

We were greeted by a wonderful hostess with an engaging and warm smile and the waiter was pleasant but really did not provide any recommendations on the menu or wine list.

We had the rabbit terrine and the tomato/buffalo cheese custard- great presentation but not much on the flavor.  Everyone around us was being served bread and butter - we had to ask for it.Our entrees - the salmon and pork dish fell short on presentation and flavor. Just meh.

Overall, it was OK experience. We will not be rushing back too soon - given all the other great restaurants in the hood.The food fell short and we felt like we had been fleeced. Given the price point- we expected to be WOWed!
Good luck
author: M G.

description: Highly recommend the corn agnolotti and hen roulade! Wine was a little overpriced, but the food made up for it.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Excellent service!

Three cheese starter: You have to try it with right wine pairing, so ask their wine staff.  A must-try item.
