Smoked Sturgeon: Their creative version of fish & chips with no batter involved.  Sturgeon was smoked perfectly.  Sturgeon was super soft, even though sturgeon is usually "meat-ier" than other fishes.
author: A Y.

description:
We have been here twice for brunch and both times were equally disappointing. 

Let's start with the two stars:

The charcuterie is great, no surprise, Central Kichen is related to Salumaria.  The brunch is okay. It's nothing special and you can get a similar meal at just about any brunch spot in the city.  

Now for the three blank stars:

For some reason on the two different visits several months apart from one another our reservations were not honored.   First visit they were 25 minutes late with seating us and we only had four people.  Today, they were 35 minutes late and only had a four top. Every time I approached to inquire about our table I got a different story.  No need to elaborate, I'm sure we've all been there.

First visit it took about 20 minutes just to put in a drink order. Second visit we didn't get the last entrée until it was room temp because it was passed over on the expo line.

In short, service is below subpar. It isn't just one person that is off but seems to be a collective disfunction among the group probably due to mismanagement.  Sorry but two negative experiences means no return. Honestly,  there are way better places in  San Francisco.
author: Kevin M.

description: had one of my top 5 brunch meals in san francisco so far. so so so good!
author: Tatum T.

description: Overpriced food with too many sweet sauces.  Played loud awful Christmas carols.  They need a good jazz band to justify the price.  Best dishes were the carrots, brussel sprouts and swordfish.
author: Ellen K.

description:
Dined for the first time here last Tuesday night--will go back soon and strongly recommend it!  
We had the tasting menu, with both an alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverage pairing, and all was great.  The liver mousse was so delicious, I got one to go!  Even the chocolate dessert, a dessert type I don't normally like, was impressive.  The server and general manager were also engaging, friendly, patient, and quite knowledgeable.  Ambience was also impressive, with a relatively quiet noise level, and a great soundtrack of Best of Blondie and U2 during the course of our meal.
author: Marvin D.

description: Food was still great, but major ding when you spend $300 on a meal for 2 and you find yourself sitting in the bathroom with no toilet paper and you have to ask for wine when all the glasses are empty and your main course is sitting on the table. Details matter.
author: Katie M.

description:
I looked forward to going here because of my natural attraction to it's neighbor Trick Dog.  Though they aren't related in anyway I was hoping that it would match their strength behind the bar with their kitchen.  The food certainly did not disappoint. Naturally I tried a pasta dish because of their ties with Flour and Water which I adore. It was on point for sure.  We also had a very good blood sausage and octopus dish that was the star of the night for us as far as entrees went.  Simple yet delicious. If you're hesitant about blood sausage this dish would be a great starting point for you.  The best thing was by far the Kale Chips.  One of the best things I have ever eaten. We could have had 10 orders if we weren't eating everything else. The cheese plate was a small disappointment as I always hope for more unique cheese in restaurants but it wasn't anything I couldn't find at a nice market on my own.  The flat thin cracker it's served on was really nice though.  

The restaurant itself is very cool and easy on the eyes.  The service was a small disappointment as they weren't as outwardly excited as many of my favorite restaurants go.  One of the things I really like about eating out is when the service staff is as passionate about the food as the people who are making and eating it.  Places like Ramen Shop, State Bird, Canlis (Seattle), Flour & Water, Trick Dog excel at this kind of service and it shows.  The service here was pretty simple and basic. They weren't bad as far as timing and promptness but extra smiles, passion for food, and personality goes a long way for me.  I like being greeted when checking in and not having to grab their attention. Especially when the place was not very busy at the time we arrived. 

Overall if you want a good meal in a nice restaurant Central Kitchen does the job. Just don't expect much from the staff as far as personality goes.
author: Joco F.

description:
I absolutely hate restaurants like this. Hate you say? That's such a strong word. Hate, I say. As in I was lining up to have a lovely Sunday until Central Kitchen got in the way. What, pray tell, did Central Kitchen do wrong, you say? Three things:

First, the food is annoyingly precious. I had poached eggs over polenta with carrots, and some pork belly. It was Ok, I guess. Decent flavors but nothing earth shattering. I get that they are trying to do some new spins on old standbys. By which I mean they are trying really, really hard. Lighten up a bit. It's brunch. And it's San Francisco, not New York. 

Second, the portions are tiny. My twee little breakfast melange had two pieces of pork belly so small they could have only been taken from a pig born within the past week. They were accompanied by two eggs, something like fifteen grains of polenta, three carrots, and two slices of mushroom.  (Not two mushrooms, two slices of mushroom.) I literally don't understand the theory behind this. Are you trying to get people to eat slow by serving them something that will be done in four bites? Do you think that good things only come in exceedingly small packages? Did you run out of bigger plates? Seriously. The ingredients are not that expensive. And it's really easy to fill up the plate with things like carrots and polenta that don't cost anything. Also they do the incredibly annoying thing of splitting off items that would normally come with a meal (like potatoes) and making them a side dish that you have to pay $5 for, and then even that portion is small. Potatoes. Cost. Nothing. Fill up the plate. Let my people eat! The bottom line is that I left the restaurant hungry after being there for 2 hours and dropping $33. That is not OK. Oh, also, they charge $5 for green tea. Lame.

Third, the service sucked. It literally took like 45 minutes for us to get our food after ordering. And you could see that everyone else in the restaurant was having the same experience. Lots of people playing with their silverware, looking around, wondering why they didn't go somewhere good and fast for brunch.      
 
The ambience is really nice though. Also the poached eggs were properly poached, runny without being goopy. So, points for that :)
author: Daniel S.

description: I agree with everyone here. I just did the tasting menu last night. While I really wanted to like this place and while I liked the ambiance, Trick Dog next door, the lovely private dining room..  the food just wasn't as good we expected it is going to be. It was wonderfully served, but all four of us at the table agreed that there was only one dish that was unique and stood out, the yellowtail. Everything else was okay, but nothing exciting. In my opinion the duck breast was cooked too rare, so much on the rare side that we could not cut it with the regular knives (and we were not offered steak knives with it.) So I have to give 3 stars as sadly we did not feel that this dinner was worth the money.
author: M.S.E V.

description:
Loved this place.  Foodie-quality food and modern urban atmosphere.  

Yes, portions are more European-sized, but I think most restaurant portions are too big.  And SF beach season is just around the corner, after all. I found an appetizer and an entree to be plenty of food to make me feel full without being stuffed.  And I like to eat.

Service was attentive without being rushed.  If I wanted to get my entree while I was still chewing the last bite of my appetizer, I'd go to Olive Garden.

I don't get all of the criticism.  I look forward to going again.
author: Craig V.

description:
I've been thinking it's me, not you Chef McNaughton. For the most part the food media seems to love you, diners in SF or the Bay Area seem to love you (or at least they are willing to wait hours at F+W or make reservations weeks in advance for CK), and food critics seem to love you.

The food was either stuck on one flavor or texture note or seemed to celebrate not the main ingredient but to be distracted by the attempt at clever side notes.  As one reviewer mentioned, the dishes were an interesting collection of ingredients, but as a whole not one brought a dish together.  The dishes were well executed technically, but were like well-executed rough drafts.  Like the sign on the way to the restroom, "Excuse our mess, as we complete the construction of the buildings.". (Or something close to that.)

For example, "beets, raspberry, red walnut, cocoa nib." The raspberry would have provided a nice acid complement to the sweetness of the beets, a nice nod to summer and opening of the palate. Instead it overwhelmed.

"King salmon, eggplant, olive, mustard seed." The perfectly cooked, perfectly fresh salmon was high jacked by the smokiness of the grilled eggplant (both the purée underneath and the thick sliced garnishes). 

If this is the direction you want the conversation of California cuisine to go, the voice is not loud enough, not daring enough, not original enough.  The cooking seems to be along for the ride, on the road to locally sourced and sustainably farmed. There is great competition on this road, and a foam here, gelee there, of a fresh local sustainable ingredient is not enough.

I've been to F+W twice and CK once, to be fair. So it must be me, I simply don't get it.
author: Michael C.

description: Ordered "soft scrambled egss"  got hard pellets of overcooked eggs.  Toast with cheese - very good.  Potatoes - tasty but soggy.  Coffee - average. Service fair.
author: Jeffrey O.

description: Food was very good, inventive and fresh, but there was not a whole lot of it, especially for the price. We wanted to order a bottle of red wine, but struggled to find one that tasted good to us (especially at the price we paid). Good ambiance, really wish it hadn't been lacking.
author: Abby H.

description: I had to make a reservation a month out to finally try Central Kitchen on a Saturday night and it was well worth it! Great, friendly service with excellent recommendations. The space is really cool - I didn't realize it was actually connected to the Salumeria and Trick Dog (which you can access through an adjoining door instead of out on the street). It has a very open and modern feeling - the front room feels like a private walled-in patio somewhere far from SF. We got the fried pickles as a snack and they were really tasty. The stonefruit app was delicious too. I got the vegetarian dumplings with corn and ricotta which were amazing. Would definitely go back!
author: Gina C.

description:
I love Flour and Water, and I love Paxton's Gate, so I want to love Central Kitchen.
But after two dinners here, I just don't.

Overall, the food is really hit or miss, and out of a dozen different plates I've tried I'd say maybe 2 or 3 were hits.
With that being said, it's really pricey here and the portions are small.
I don't mind paying for really pricey small portions sometimes, god only knows the mission rent is just sky rocketing, but for that I want AT LEAST a 50% yum ratio.  

The place is beautiful and staff is amazing! If you do end up here my best advice is to try the small plates.  I remember the small plates generally being pretty good.

Good luck!
author: YJ P.

description: We ordered EVERYTHING on the menu- front and back. Tasting + A La Carte Menu, let's just say we were 5 hungry people. They must have thought we were food monsters. We regretted it after the first 5 dishes, nevertheless food was excellent, server Ivan was super friendly, the Chef even made some unique dishes for us, combining both the A La Carte and Tasting menu ingredients. Love the ambiance, rustic, open kitchen- my kind of establishment. Overall, a win for all of us.
author: Ennie L.

description: Love this little place in the mission! Perfect place for a Sunday brunch ! Def try the eggs Benedict with a side of potatoes : ) Service was good & fun atmosphere.
author: Sapna P.

description: I've had dinner here 3 times.  The food is okay, not incredible.  I like the space, so have taken out of town friends here.  Someone commented on how the crowd is not representative of San Francisco and I agree.  The service can be good to cloyingly attentive.
author: michelle s.

description: I love the food, but I tried to make a reservation for my friend's birthday party for 8 (on a Monday night no-less) and they expected a $1,000 minimum ($125 per person) in a private room if I had more than 6 people!  I've already been there 3 times and loved it but now I'll never go again...  Need to change that policy guys!
author: John F.

description: My cousins and I liked all we ate and split everything three ways. The only thing we didn't finish was the "crispy kale" appetizer, which was really kale tempura. It was so filling that we didn't think we'd have room for everything else. Note on the prices: We bypassed the $95 per person tasting menu and shared four appetizers, two entrees, no dessert, and a $54 bottle of wine, the lowest priced wine available. Our bill before tip was $156. We might have had dessert but all three options were sweet with salt added and we're all pretty done with that trend! The portions are fairly small but we didn't mind. We had an early reservation, 6:00, because I had just arrived from the Eastern time zone that day, and were seated immediately in the almost empty room. It was hopping by the time we left, though.
author: Babette G.

description:
Came here as a substitute for State Bird Provisions and was not disappointed. 
We started the evening next door at the cocktail bar, which served some great (if not a bit punchy) drinks. 
For food, we opted for the tasting menu and wine pairing, mainly because everything on the menu looked great and so wanted to try as much as possible. If available, Id definitely recommend it. 
IT ended up being one of the better meals Ive had in California. Carefully balanced flavors and just the right amount of food.
author: Rupert R.

description: We loved our dinner here. We both had the "let the kitchen choose" with wine pairings and everything was delicious. I especially remember the pate, the prime rib ravioli,the chocolate pudding/icecream/brownie/etc dessert. So good. Erin was our server and she was fabulous; charming and interesting and beautiful and full of great details about the food and wine. I would come back here in a heartbeat for any other special event. It's kind of pricey for the kitchen's choice, but totally worth it for the mystery and fun. Highly recommended!
author: Sophie K.

description: The space is stunning, industrial chic.   We had the tasting menu and it was extremely multi-faceted, with pitch-perfect wine pairings.   The service is attentive and extremely engaging.  By far the best dishes were the sea bass and squid with squid ink sauce and other trimmings.  Can't find anything to quibble over.
author: Mike N.

description: Small plates where just OK, the large plates where just awful. The service was good & attentive. But the food, which is a main reason why we go out, was not even in the same park as the service. My main dish was the fish, served on a bed of beans. If they gave me a plate of the beans, I would have given 3 stars instead of 2...
author: A. B.

description:
Lovely room and good service, but while the menu sounds great, the ingredients are high quality, and the dishes looked great on the table, nothing actually tasted good.

Each dish contained an ingredient that overpowered everything else, resulting in a strangely bland combination of ingredients that should have worked well together.  Examples:

Salad with rabbit tasted like fried something, anything-- the rabbit was lost in the shredding and refrying, and the salad was lost completely.

Celery root soup with pickled vegetables and an oyster... tasted like vinegary under-pickled pickles, not celery root.

The duck breast itself was delicious, but nothing else on its plate worked: sweet and much too vinegary applesauces did not help, walnut puree was gritty and unseasoned.

I was looking forward to enjoying the meal, but it was one miss after another.  You'd have a much better meal at Universal Cafe, Slow Club, Heirloom Cafe, or one of the Local's.
author: Jeff S.

description: Really cute indoor/outdoor patio!  I'd come here again just to bask in the sun on a warm day.  The brunch food and service are both awesome too.  Reservations were not hard to get, and the restaurant was not overly crowded for brunch.
author: K V.

description: Excellent and creatively prepared food in a beautiful space and with really, really wonderful service.  Casual yet absolutely professional wait staff.
author: Robert M.

description: We were able to get a spot at the bar without a reservation (or waiting!) on Saturday night around 7pm. The service was very, very friendly, and without pretense. The food was delicious, and they even made us a special vegetarian entree (since there were no vegetarian entrees on the menu). The small plates (many of which were vegetarian) were excellent. Great ambiance. The only thing I would change is that the music was really loud (and didn't seem to quite fit the vibe they had going with the decor). But overall I would highly recommend this spot!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Nice atmosphere but very underwhelming food. I had the mixed pork and asparagus.  Lets just say I could have picked up some sausage and ham from Safeway for 10 people for the same price and would have tasted better!
author: Mona P.

description: Pretty but ultimately unfulfilling, such is the fate of all places that prioritize style over substance.
author: Leon K.

description:
First off, I actually really love this place.  I have been here 6 times (once for a big group on my birthday) and each meal was amazing.  The servers are friendly and seem to really love their job.
Why the three stars then?  I was just there last night, and again, the food was delicious and innovative, however, the music was over the top loud.  I felt like I was at a club, having to shout to people on the other side of the table.  I asked the hostess if she could turn it down a bit.  if anything, it got louder.  By the end of the night, I could not wait to get out of there.  I mentioned it again to the other hostess who said she would tell the manager, but again, no change.  It felt like they really did not care what the customer wanted, they were enjoying it loud, so too bad.
This really put me off.  Although I love this place, I will not be going back for a while nor recommend.  Too bad since it was rising to one of my favorites.
author: jim S.

description: You need to visit this restaurant.  The menu is intensely progressive, serving items that I guarantee you have never heard of.  That being said, flavors are well balanced and service is top notch.
author: Nick W.

description: Had a fantastic meal here. Went to dinner with a friend and shared the chickpea app, beef tartare, porcini pasta and duck entree. The chocolate mousse dessert was amazing. Our server was super knowledgeable. Would highly recommend it!!!
author: Katie S.

description: I liked it here.  Everything was tasty, the cheeses were served with crisp lavosh and honey.  The chicken was perfectly cooked.  The chocolate mousse was yummy.  Our server was knowledgable and helpful. I just don't see myself going all the way across town (it's next to trick dog and actually shares the bathroom) to have another meal. If I'm nearby and there's no wait then I'd happily dine here again.
author: Poppy C.

description: Central Kitchen reflects the best of northern California food: limited menu, perfect ingredients and a kitchen confident to let the ingredients shine. From perfectly done beets to fresh local hen with cauliflower, the chefs paired flavors perfectly. Definitely worth a visit and a top 10 SF visit - Boulevard, 5th Floor and Chez Panisse are the others.
author: p B.

description: Exceptional! It is challenging to stand out in this city, where culinary delights are everywhere. This one achieves it- we will go back frequently...
author: Craig L.

description:
Overall Rating: 1 Star (don't charge me this much money for failed experiments in the kitchen)
Room: 4 stars (clean and spare - bordering on boring)
Service: 2 stars (we had a very nice server but plates sat 20 minutes after we finished our meal)
Food: 2 stars (sometimes interesting experiments that ultimately fail - confused combinations, boring, salty, odd)

Bottom Line: Go for Salumeria and enjoy the space.
author: Scott M.

description: Amazing! I'm really impressed with Central Kitchen, and I'm not easily impressed! Went for dinner and I loved everything, from the kale chips to the unbelievable seaweed pasta chitarra and the pork dish with beets. Really, really good!!!!
author: Carolina A.

description: Ooh, really nice. The space was charming. The food was great. Service good too. What more is there to say except "We'll be back."
author: Kate G.

description: Holy cow, we are still at the restaurant but I just had to put my comment for this place. It is freaking amazing. When they first came out with the beef tartare and asparagus, I thought I was in heaven. Then they hit me with the octopus with pork belly and blood sausage, man, this took me straight to lala land, and their hen, seriously, I wish I could lick the plate. It was that good, now on to dessert, I wonder what they are coming up with.
author: Andrew A.

description: Central Kitchen nailed it last night.  The Food.  Wow.   Flavors were amazing and inventive.  Pacing of the 8 courses throughout the tasting menu was spot on.  Service was flawless.  Shout out to Hillary.  Keep polishing your craft, you are a pro.  My favorite meal out in over a year.  Do yourself a favor and get the tasting menu.
author: John D.

description:
Been here twice and amazing both times.   Great staff, great service and AMAZING food.  
Can't wait to go back again.
author: Kaveh D.

description: Amazing service, stellar food, breathtaking venue. The setting fits the bill - while it's not difficult to get in via OpenTable (though it's an earlier time slot), it's easy to stay a while and enjoy the atmosphere once things get busy. The waiters are all professional and don't push, and their food is phenomenal. Don't be afraid to try something new - you're sure to enjoy it. While the price tag is a little high, it's hard to complain after such a pleasurable experience here.
author: Meaghan C.

description:
We were a group of 6 for a 9pm reservation on a friday for my friend's bday and we ended up waiting 40 minutes for our table... not a good start to the evening. The hostess seemed unsure of what to do when we continued to check-in for an update, she just kept saying, the table has their bill, we're just waiting for them to pay/get up. There's not a bar, so I guess that's a problem that they couldn't offer to buy them their last drink at the bar instead of hogging the table for 40 minutes longer.

We were all a bit annoyed by this point - the hostess had finally offered to get us drinks about 30 minutes into our wait, we were hoping they'd be comped, but they weren't. Once we were seated, the staff really turned the night around from there. We had several different people come up to the table to take our order, bring us food, etc, and each one acknowledged the long wait, apologized and said that they'd be bringing us some stuff free of charge to make up for it. In the end, it did, but I think their hostess needs a bit more training in how to handle these situations.

Overall, the food was pretty good. All of us are fairly adventurous eaters, having dined at SF's finest and I never turn my nose up at something that sounds odd. I tasted everything, even things that aren't really my cup of tea and overall, everything was good. A lot of the small plates, were good, but wouldn't have my craving anything enough to come back for more. We did get a big sample since they brought us some free dishes. We tried:
-roasted beets
-terrine/pate
-radishes
-mushrooms
-fish tartar - I can't remember what kind this was, I did not try as I'm pregnant

All was very earthy, fresh and tasted good, but again, nothing that was to die for.

I think we all really enjoyed our entrees though - 2 of us got the duck and the other 4 got the pork. I didn't love the accompaniments of the duck, but the duck itself was really good - I'm usually more of a confit person than a duck breast person, but this was delicious, and the biggest portion of duck I've had, 2 full pieces.

The other area we'd give them high notes on was the desserts. We were sort of debating what to get - first we knew they knew it was my friends bday so it's always the debate of if you order dessert or hope that they bring you something. We ended up ordering one of each of their 3 desserts. I only tried the chocolate one (very good) and the apple crisp one -- sooo good!! But between the 6 of us, we finished all 3.

In total, we each spent $75 inc tip and drinks for the meal, which I felt was pretty good. They didn't comp the first round of drinks that we had while waiting for the table which we were hoping for, but they did make up for the bad start with the extras throughout the night. Overall, a fun place to try, especially if you're open to tasting unique combinations as the menu isn't very large. We didn't really love any of the starters, but mains and dessert were really good.
author: Lauren M.

description: I went with a few other friends and we all ordered a few different plates so that we could try everything. The food itself was well prepared and tasted great. The service was actually really great as well. They had some red wine on tap that was actually pretty amazing. I gave this restaurant 2 stars because while the food was great it was very overpriced (even for nicer dining) for what you got. There are several other restaurants in the city with just as great food but larger portions. I am glad we tried it once but not sure I'd go back.
author: Angelle S.

description:
Central Kitchen clearly put a lot of effort into ambiance: the waiting area featured lighted water splashing over cracked porcelain and the "outdoor" seating area comprised a reconstituted barn with heated floors. Too bad the chef's drunk friends had taken over the communal table, save two tantalizing seats that were never offered to us during our two hour wait. In fact we were offered nothing during our wait - not updates, not refills from the bottle of prosecco we ordered, not bread. So we just sat on the edge of the fountain, like ducks on a porcelain bottomed pond watching the drunk friends of the chef stumble out to smoke, bumping into customers and muttering, "What the fuck, man?" to no one in particular. To be fair, I don't think any of the waiters were pleased about this. The hostess, on the other hand, probably didn't notice, busy as she was avoiding her hosting duties. (Also, she told us the wait would be at least two hours even though there was an available reservation on Open Table for an hour and forty-five. Even with the reservation, however, it took us more than two hours to be seated, so good on her for accuracy there.)

I imagine, at this point, you may consider my review of the tasting menu biased. You are free to take my review with a grain of salt (this is a pun currently funny only to me and probably anyone else who ate at the restaurant on Friday 5/18). The pad of butter was practically the sole survivor of the salt shaker food massacre that was occurring in the kitchen. I exaggerate, but only slightly. The soup wouldn't have been considered too salty out of the context of the salt parade, and the halibut was a gem of a dish featuring a poached egg (salted) unlike one I've ever tasted. But mostly I just remember salt. The coda was a chicken dish straight out of the Alice Waters recipe rejects pile. I think I just fell asleep thinking about it. The wines were not to my taste, across the board. This could be good or bad, depending on your taste, but I am generally not a picky wine drinker. I just don't happen to like highly acidic wines, one of which was loving described to us as "softer" battery acid. I'd roll my dice with the wine list rather than opt for the pairing if I could do-over. The deserts were delicious, and the wait staff attentive, funny, and well-informed.

So I'm probably just bitter that I blew a ton of cash on a hit-and-miss meal while watching (and probably subsidizing!) some drunk jerks eating like kings and pissing everyone off. Great place to bring a date.
author: Erica B.

description: I was very excited to eat at Central Kitchen. I had heard many good things about the restaurant and made a reservation for 9:30pm on a Saturday. First note, that Central Kitchen requires a credit card to reserve a table through OpenTable. We arrived and were seated almost immediately. The decor was great and the restaurant was full of people enjoying a Saturday night out. However, the meal was downhill from there. The timing of the dishes was completely off, waiting over 20 minutes between courses after we were finished with our dish. Nothing stood out among the meal and the best of the four dishes we ordered was the hen entree. The trotters, tuna salad, and seared squid were all underwhelming. For a place with such hype, an expensive menu, and an out-of-the-way location, I can surely say I won't be coming back.
author: Rebecca D.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in SF.  Granted, I'm nowhere close to having tried all of them, but this place has amazing, interesting food, and super welcoming and knowledgeable staff.  I've been twice for dinner (did tasting menu both times) and once for brunch, all fabulous.  It's definitely pricey, but you get what you pay for.  If you do brunch, get the sticky bun :).  Tasting menu was not only delicious and creative, but also the perfect amount of food.
author: Lisa H.

description: Excellent ambiance, superb service, admirable menu only lacking in (pre-dinner) cocktail options.  I'm most certainly going back, bringing others, and recommending it to friends and you fine strangers.
author: Judy V.

description: Very pricey and and loud music but sophisticated, tasty and original dishes.  In other words, I have no criticism whatsoever about the food, but it is very expensive - $32-35 for an entree isn't unusual but $18 for a side of carrots, $17 for grilled greens, $24 for spaghetti seems excessive.  Also, they play loud rock music, which can be great in a bar, is a distraction from fine dining with friends.
author: John S.

description: Wonderful experience!  Great ingredients, but what was really impressive was the techniques used...you could taste them.  To provide an idea of how great the food, service and atmosphere is...I have already recommended it as a Destination Date spot.  A 2 hour flight and hotel overnight with the Central Kitchen as THE activity for the date ;)
author: Bryan B.

description: It all depends on who you are. If you're 25 to 30ish and single, this place absolutely rocks. Over 40, you'd think the place was too loud. Hard to deny the pluses: interesting industrial space design, well-spaced tables, and killer wine list filled with local hipster faves and geeky imports. Food is creative and a few dishes actually work. Not the first place I'd pick on a night in the city but if dragged I'd gladly come along.
author: Alex B.

description:
The music was unbearably loud. We asked them to turn it down twice. They turned it up! 

The portions were tiny. You best eat BEFORE you go. IF you go. Prices were high for what you got. Entree same size as 1st course.

Cold breeze blowing all night as front door is open to the outdoor area. VERY disappointed.
author: carla r.

description:
We sat in the indoor/outdoor section with wonderful lighting.  We opted for the tasting menu, without the accompanying alcohol.  Chef Thomas McNaughton was out and about the dining room, which made the experience very intimate.  I tend to snoop into "open" kitchens... and this time, I received an invite by Sous Chef Nick to come inside to tour the kitchen.  He even took me upstairs to the area where the butchers work!   


The highlights were the following two dishes:

*goat curds and whey. beets. rye. green rhubarb
*olive oil baked halibut. artichokes. nettles. egg yolk

In general, all dishes were quite delicate, had great texture, and of course, taste!   The tasting menu was priced very affordable, given the food provided.  The wine selection was good, as well as the beer selection.  Any restaurant that hosts Telegraph beer is a happy place, IMHO!   

In sum, I found Central Kitchen to be an intimate restaurant with great food and service.
author: Mai N.

description:
Went there with the lad for Sunday Brunch. He ordered Pork Belly Benedict -- it was bit dry for me. I ordered Olive Oil fried eggs with a sauce..forget its name, but anyways, it was flavoured with anchovies. I loved it. The coffee was just so so. Friendly servers. Would go again for sure but not too crazy for it. 

Going to try the dinner there soon. I'll write another review for that.
author: Cate M. Z.

description: LOVED this place. Great atmosphere....energetic & hip, but not too noisy, the place has high ceilings and is in a location where you feel you are slipping into a neighborhood hot spot. The bar area attached was happening & full of people, even early on a Saturday evening. The food was interesting & super tasty. I had the duck confit appy & the hen that night baed on our servers recommendation & she was spot-on. Super fun place to go with 4-6 people.
author: Jen S.

description:
Central Kitchen was very good, and I think has the potential to be outstanding with a few adjustments here and there. I'll definitely go back, maybe in a year to see how it's changed. 

AMBIANCE + SERVICE: We had a 8:45 reservation for four, and were seated immediately. The space is really beautiful -- lots of beautiful, warm, indirect lighting, modern style, with a few industrial touches. The table and chairs were hefty but comfortable. The plates are pottery. The service was also excellent, with only a few delays here and there. 

FOOD: We tried the tasting menu. Overall, a good choice. 

- The canapes were interesting. The only one worth remarking on was the first one, which was a sort of citrus/champagne mix with almond milk and some sort of granita. It was really, really, really delicious. The others ranged from good to weird. 
- The clams and turnips were good, but not great. One person at our table remarked that they tasted like a McDonalds hamburger. Which they did, in an odd way. 
- The peas and curds with mint and rye crumble was awesome. Such an inventive way to serve that combo of food. It was like a delicious hearty soup or something. Wonderful. 
- Slow-baked halibut with egg yolk. The egg yolk was almost sous vide, it was really good. And the halibut was wonderful -- perfectly cooked. And my anti-fish boyfriend got a slow-cooked ham instead, which was nice. 
- Roasted veal, porcinis, and pine: This was good, though not amazing. The porcinis were the most flavorful thing on the plate, and were delicately cooked. My veal was a bit overdone. 
- The yogurt sorbet/blackberries/almonds was really delicious. The perfect sort of substantial palate-cleansing dessert after a somewhat heavy main dish. 
- The cherry/buckwheat ice cream was fine. Nothing special. The buckwheat pellets seemed almost like pet food -- a bit of an odd consistency. 

WINE: The wine list is much-improved over older versions (I can tell), but the restaurant lacks a liquor license. I asked for a cocktail menu with dessert and was turned down, which lost the restaurant a star. Our waiter recommended an excellent provencal-style rose, which went well with both the halibut and veal (not an easy task). 

PRICE: In the high range in terms of price-to-value. Portions were not huge, but were sufficient. I think it's a little annoying to be charged a $1.95 Healthy San Francisco fee after paying $79 for a tasting menu. But overall, a great experience. I'll be back.
author: Tom P.

description:
Context: we have been in SF for 16 years, love food of all varieties, and have had hundreds of meals in the city of all shapes, sizes, and colors. This is our first restaurant review, it felt like time to speak up. We went a good few days since Central Kitchen opened. We also live around the corner.

So ...

Central Kitchen is like a poor attempt at elitist food for the nonhungry/perpetual dieter  ... in a quiet residential part of the Mission. Hard to believe this is the same owner as Flour&Water. Especially since that is a block away so they certainly had a chance to feel out the neighborhood.

Small portions arrayed artfully but with little substance and flavor ... form triumphs over function.

The ham appetizer was crunchy with salt, even though cured ham is already salty.

The roast pork main was like a mediocre cold cut (and literally cold) -- the good part was the crispy skin.

The 2 other entrees and 2 appetizers were fine but not spectacular, with the cod appetizer being the exception.

Over-priced and you will need to eat before or after unless you order more than is standard.

Also super loud non dinner music ... more appropriate for a dive bar ;)

Given the heated food competition in this town, this is a sign of a food 'bubble'.

On the plus side? The space is airy and tastefully designed, the waitstaff and service reasonable (actually a big compliment in SF).
author: Filip K.

description: I've been hearing a lot of great things about Central Kitchen and when I heard they were opening up for brunch I jumped at the chance because I really love fancy breakfast food. We got there a little early with reservations and were seated right away. The outdoor patio is beautiful and we were blessed with a really nice day. I started off with the cocktail Easy Like and it was a really nice mimosa substitution with my food. To eat I got the Olive Oil Fried Eggs which were served on top of cauliflower, romanesco, and crispy barley. I loved it! There were so many different flavors and textures that complimented the egg. My fave part was the crispy kale chips on top. It was a small portion. I think I only got one egg and my picture confirms it but it was so good I was really satisfied at the end of my meal. Hope to come back and try dinner!
author: Beatriz C.

description:
A little expensive (170$ for 2 people including a cheaper wine, 2 appys, and 2 not-so-large entrees). But good. Really good. The roasted duck thing - exceptional!

Glad to have this place in our hood, and hope the property values keep climbig ;-)
author: Priya K.

description: I love Central Kitchen.  I've been there for both Sunday brunch and dinner, and there food is this perfect articulation of what makes restaurants in this country great.  The menu doesn't necessarily give a great preview of how amazing your meal will be, but once your food arrives, you have a plate of something so deliciously amazing and difficult to articulate.  Brunch is as decadent and delicious as one would expect an American breakfast to be, and dinner is fantastic.  Good wine list as well, great bar next door.
author: Hannah N.

description:
one of the best dining experiences i've had.. especially for bang for the buck!

for 79 bucks per person, 7-9 course tasting menu at this level is not common, even in san francisco. Aziza and Commontwealth (at least, it used to) provide similar quality of tasting menu.

the most memorable dish was their halibut, honestly, I haven't had a fish dish that incredibly executed in the longest time. this simple olive oil baked halibut just blew my mind.

the service was superb and the outdoor patio was absolutely stunning.

can't wait to go back for their a la carte!
author: Sung C.

description:
this rating is based solely on my "nightcap" experience here the other night.

we came in after having dinner elsewhere and noticed that they closed at 10pm on sunday nights...

walked right on in with no reservations and there was plenty of seats in the dining area....we asked for a "bar area" and they walked up right over to a strip of seats that were all facing the main kitchen dining area.  the setup was very different, being that usually your back is facing any given dining room when youre seated at a bar, but was nice because you could see the chefs in the kitchen on the opposite side of the room, and people watch as they stuffed their faces right before our eyes...

service was quick as we were at the bar...

ordered 2 glasses of wine and looked at the dessert menu...

i immediately saw that they had a plum sorbet on the menu...i love plums....i love sorbet...this was something ive always wanted, without ever knowing that it existed... needless to say, i need this in my gut asap.  upon "trying" to order it, the server pointed out that it was part of the prefixed menu..................fml.

we opted for a cheese plate and left it at that.  

i kept thinking about it. plum sorbet. seems simple, noting too fancy, but it was the fact that ive never had this flavor sorbet before....

i called the server over and asked if she could ask the chef if anything could be done about my predicament....she came back smiling and said it was all good and that the chef would put together something for us.

the server came back with 3 large quenelles of plum sorber sitting atop of fresh plum slivers....

i shouldve savored every bite, but the thing tasted too good. it was killed in just under a minute.

definitely want to come back for the regular tasting menu BUT until then, the only thing ill remember about this place is how great their desserts are and how accommodating the staff is as well!
author: Kyu L.

description: fresh, light and delicious - unusual combinations of flavors that work.  Wine list is limited (no Napa wines by the glass, at least tonight) and only one hard cider - a 750 ml bottle for $25.  But the service, the food and the decor are all 5 stars.  We'll be back!
author: Artemis C.

description: We had one of each the snack dirty rice & duck cold,  app halibut, warm app butternut soup , $ entree of hen. Absolutely delish. Don't pass on dessert bc it's just as good!
author: Elizabeth M.

description: I've been here for both dinner and brunch. Both were excellent. The drinks are very yummy and, although they do have a limited menu, they do everything amazingly well. They do switch out their menu items, so it's not like they only make those few items only. The flavors that they manage to achieve is ridiculous and I will definitely be back in the future to discover their other new menu items.
author: Annette D.

description: We did the tasting menu with wine pairing.  Interesting use of ingredients and nice presentation. Definitely trying to be creative, though part of me finds it a bit fussy and overdone.  The space is really nice.
author: Eric C.

description: This is a find worth going back several times to explore the entire menu.  The tasting menu looks good, but struck me as overpriced, so I went with the cheese plate appetizer which was excellent with local cheeses and fennel jam.  I had the duck for my entree and it was perfectly prepared, an unusual feat in and of itself.  The decor is industrial but the vibe hip.  My only regret is that they do beer and wine only...no cocktails!  Waitstaff is very friendly and attentive...perhaps too much so...I had to have had 5 different people ask me if I was enjoying my meal!
author: Howard B.

description:
went for a late brunch.  love the open air space with artfully hung lightbulbs.  all the food was delicious, the following were outstanding:  
-scrambled eggs w/ toasted baguette + chevre & mushroom spread
-bread pudding w/ farmers cheese + apricots (not too sweet)

will definitely be back.
author: Elana R.

description: If "fit for foodies" means a hip atmosphere, very loud music and food being a second thought, then Central Kitchen fits the bill. I had the smoked ricotta casonsei which was so oversalted all you could taste was salt. The chickpea panisse was ok. The best part of dinner was the sweet pea ice cream, sadly not worth what we paid. There are too many other restaurants to visit to bother coming back. Very disappointing.
author: Naabi B.

description:
Our experience started when we arrived for our party of four 8:45 reservations. The hostesses said it would be 15 minutes--well that turned into 35 minutes! They should have offered us wine or beer (complimentary) but instead offered water!?!?

We were seated on the makeshift outdoor/indoor patio where it was very cold and drafty. 

Once seated, each couple ordered a salad and appetizer to share. After another half an hour we were served two salads and one appetizer. After a short while we inquired as to the other appetizer, which they said they would look into. Another 15 went by, and our entrees were served. 5 minutes after that, they tried to serve us the other appetizer! The appetizer was overcooked and clearly rushed in an effort to gt it to our table, which they had no problem serving us despite us starting our main course.

The entrees were sub par, tiny portions and flavorless. Against our better judgment (probably because we were still starving after sending back an entree for being inedible) we ordered dessert which was again sub par and flavorless !

There was a prominent sf figure at the restaurant that night--who everyone was interested in catering to rather than the rest of the customers. Save your money and appetite and hit up other eateries.
author: Jen b.

description:
Honestly, having dined at pretty much all of SF's best spots, I wasn't expecting this much of a surprise. The quality of the service, the exquisite food, the unique atmosphere... amazing. My main course, the Hen, was artfully prepared and delicately complex.

Truthfully, when the waitress came by to ask how the meal was going, I told her I was sad... she was surprised, naturally, and asked why. I explained my disappointment was because I wouldn't be able to eat there... Every. Single. Day. Laughter. Good times! Unbelievable gem of a restaurant that I'll cherish as one of my go-to spots in SF from here on out.

Well played, Central Kitchen. Well played.
author: Jefe B.

description: Recently I decided to give Central Kitchen another try - this time for brunch since I'd seen it highly praised elsewhere on the interwebs. Overall, the experience was far more positive than my first debacle of a dinner a year ago. The service was attentive and the food very good (the salmon in particular was lovely, the soft-scrambled eggs less so). If you're looking for a fun, tasty brunch spot in a beautiful setting on a Sunday, this is a good pick.
author: Emily M.

description: I feel badly that I was the only one of the 8 of us not raving about brunch, but for $40, I'd like to leave a bit happier. Ordered what I thought would be the most flavorful items on the menu, but the Eggs, Chorizo & Sweet Potato "Hash" watery and a tad bland, and the bacon in the (admittedly otherwise heavenly) Sticky Bun undetectable. Everything beautifully plated; nice staff; my teeny-tiny cocktail delish.
author: Faith A.

description: Fantastic experience.  As a dairy free eater, dining out can be disheartening, but central kitchen made me feel incredibly special.  They asked immediately about food allergies, and then went on to prepare each dish with care and accommodation.  Finally , although they didn't have any dairy free desserts, they created the most delightful bowl of ginger sorbet topped with lavender sea salt on a bed of cherries, strawberries and blackberries.  They even sprinkled it with nasturtiums! It was the perfect end to a wonderful meal.  Thank you Central Kitchen for such a lovely thoughtful and personalized dinner.
author: Tess H.

description:
Amazing meal. The presentation, service and of course most importantly the taste of the meal we had last night at Central Kitchen were all superb. I've been here three times and each time gets better and better. Our groups server was Gino, and he did an amazing job of explaining all the food and wine options/nuances. 

Highlights of the meal: Superb wine selection, from Napa/Sonoma to Eclectic European choices. The hot appetizers were all delicious, as well as the entrees. I had the Pork Belly and Game Hen Dish, superb. We shared some desserts which were all top notch.
author: Albert C.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this place. The atmosphere was hip and inviting. I was already decided in my mind that is what going to be a fantastic experience, and it seemed impossible for anything to deter that (I was in a great mood, had a great companion, and basically was in the mood to fall in love with the place). 

Forget the fact that the food menu was really short and limited, had no GF or other healthy alternatives, and that they served you such little portions of everything, you felt like you needed to go somewhere else to eat afterwards. None of that bugged me since I was just in the mood to enjoy.

What finally intruded on our joy, was the TERRIBLE SERVICE--OH MY GOD!!! That's the last thing I would have expected from this place. A nice young man with a beard & red plaid shirt served us and seemed like such a cool dude....until he started completely ignoring our table for 15-20 minute chunks (which he later described as 2 minutes waiting periods). My friend and i were happily engrossed in conversation and willing to roll with the long waiting periods...until our server pushed it beyond the breaking point for every single thing we needed. We basically had to get up out of our chairs and hail him down any time we needed something. It was such a bummer, because it totally ruined the vibe and my friend and I had no interest in being those kinds of annoying customers--we just wanted to relax and enjoy.

When it started to get to a ridiculous point, we politely mentioned something to our server   (ie.,  he didn't even check on us after there was a huge mistake with our order and the kitchen needed to send out another salad they forgot--again, it took 20 minutes and we had to get up and physically find our server to check on the already forgotten entree). Here's the WORST PART, after mentioning something, our friendly server proceeded to be totally defensive and tell us why he is not taking a long time. We decided to just drop it, recognizing he is the type of guy who doesn't take responsibility and likes to deflect. To make matters even WORSE, the manager got wind of our mild complaint, and then she came over to defend, justify and give excuses as to why things were going fine and we were not being ignored.  This part was actually embarrassing as we felt totally on the spot and called out in front of other customers.

In sum, these people are totally clue-less and have a warped sense of customer service. Each server is free to get lost in other activities and completely ignore there tables to their hearts' content.

I don't recommend this place....and after all that, the food was just whatever....we ended up going to Plow afterwards since we were still hungry after 2 items each (Now Plow is an incredible brunch spot!!)
author: Avery S.

description:
Best meal I've had in San Francisco and I've been to many great restaurants in SF.

Yes there are some kinks as other reviewers said, but the food is great, atmosphere is great, and service is great.  I think people are comparing CK to Flour + Water which it is not.  The chef is trying to make CK his signature restaurant and you can tell that by the quality and presentation of his food here.  I even opened up this yelp account, so that I could comment on this place to address other people's comments.  I am pretty confident, the owners will make the changes to address people's concerns and probably already have.  That's probably why I had such a great experience.

While this is more expensive than the "neighborhood" restaurant, the quality of the meal is what you're paying for and that's fine with me.  

People complain about the size of the portions but I was completely satisfied after the typical appetizer, meal and dessert (which was deee-licious).  We even ordered another dessert since it was go great and I felt stuffed after.

I can't speak to the wine, since I'm not a wine drinker.

Overall, this was a great meal and I'd highly recommend it.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Justin N.

description: Attractive but noisy restaurant that will leave you wanting more -- because they don't serve you very much.  They seem to put the most emphasis on presentation (which is excellent) but if you're there are to eat a meal you may want to have a snack beforehand. Of the four dishes that we had, one was very good, one was okay, and the other two didn't taste that great although they looked beautiful. Oh, and it took quite a while to get the food on the table.
author: R S.

description: One of the best restaurants we've ever been to.  Service was great.  We had raw hamachi, black cod, and oxtail/pork belly.
author: Sara B.

description:
Had a very good experience here last night. The food and service were excellent. The 4 stars is just a small ding for value and booking experience.

Service - sat as soon as we entered in the "outdoor" area. The space is really cool - fresh air without the typical San Francisco wind chill making it too cold.  The service throughout was very attentive and assured. Perhaps they are getting slicker after being open several weeks now.
Food -  we decided not to go for the tasting menu so we started the calamari and true cod. Both were delicious with something unique about each dish.
For mains we had the hen and sea bass. My roasted hen was a great mix of texture and flavors while my wife's sea bass was unbelievably tender and juicy, which is what you get when you poach it in olive oil I suppose but it wasn't in the least but greasy.
Our desserts were equally delicious.

Overall, we will definitely be back but probably less than we go to Flour +Water.
author: andrew l.

description: What a treat.  Brunch or dinner, I continue to be amazed with the dynamic flavors in their dishes.  Central Kitchen is a very special place to eat - it has great ambience, food, staff, drinks, and music.
author: Stephanie F.

description: Great space and an equally great eating experience.  Service was very attentive (bordering on too much, even) and the appetizers were adventurous and absolutely delicious.  Entrees were slightly less exciting than the apps so I'd recommend ordering a bunch of apps and maybe even skipping the entree all together.
author: Sivan W.

description: This place serves amazing food.  The portions may be small, but the flavors are loud and robust.  The kitchen staff really cares about their food.  And, the desserts elevate this restaurant to another level.  The cooking style at Central Kitchen reminds me of Momofuku Ko, in terms of their bold, innovative and unapologetic flavors.  Highly recommended.
author: Bob K.

description:
If you're ever been to Flour & Water (or read a review) you know what a debacle it can be. I made a reservation at Central Kitchen for Easter brunch hoping it would provide a better experience than their sister restaurant. I was wrong. 

Our reservation was at 1:30pm. We weren't seated until 2:20pm. You'd think the massive delay would prompt the wait staff to move a little faster -- not so. We didn't see a plate of food until 3:00pm. Was the food good? Sure. Was it worth waiting an hour and a half for? Nope.
author: Erin Z.

description:
Had high (but not ridiculously high) hopes but came away disappointed. We ordered almost everything on the menu and nothing was that great. It was obvious a lot of skill went into creating each dish, and they certainly looked very pretty, but we all felt like the end result didn't taste any better than things we could make at home. 

Also, we came prepared for the small portions and we don't eat very much, but all of us were surprised by how completely unsatisfied we were. We assumed we'd end up mostly satisfied but nowhere near stuffed, which is fine; I prefer not to feel like I could roll myself out of the restaurant. But we left and realized we were still hungry. We ended up stopping into another restaurant and eating a full meal! (Note: I suppose we could've asked for more bread in order to fill ourselves up, but I don't like doing that. Besides, no one offered to bring us more, despite the fact that there was no food on our table for long stretches of time.)

On the other hand, the service was great. Everyone was very nice and helpful. The hostess, our server and a few other people who brought us our food or stopped by to check up on us, were all super nice and did a great job. Such a great job that I really wish I had better things to say about the food.

As we were enjoying our second (proper) meal, we all discussed Central Kitchen and the consensus was that, based on the meal we just had alone, we wouldn't return. And we all had a general feeling of dissatisfaction about how much we spent, considering that we ended up eating somewhere else 30 minutes after we left.
author: K B.

description: Had a phenomenal experience there last night! Delicious food and friendly staff.
author: Richard M.

description:
Yet another new place in the Mission... I was kind of scared by the extremely mixed reviews, but I ended up LOVING it.   

Parking isn't so difficult in this part of the Mission.  The space is low key and easy to miss, but don't be fooled - the inside is super cute, with a patio option and an inside option with a direct view of the open kitchen.  It's not too tiny but still feels intimate, and the colors and decor are simple but sophisticated.  All the staff knows the menu well, and everyone was super friendly and took the time to chat with us without appearing flustered or rushed. I didn't find it "too trendy" at all.

First off, I have a bias towards any place with complimentary house sparkling water, especially if a bottle is left for you on the table.  The wine list isn't huge but has a good variety, and I thought the Prosecco went well with the mostly seafood based tasting menu for tonight.

Warm rolls are served with house butter with just a little sea salt.  We started with 3 canapes: 
1. Melon with lardo and pine nuts
2. Corn broth with pine nut oil - usually corn is creamy, but they squeezed out the fresh juice from corn on a cob and made it into a consomme
3. Plum and blueberry soda with tarragon tea - sparkling, refreshing, fruity

Then onto the tasting menu...
1. Salmon belly with cucumber gelee - refreshing and light, good way to open
2. Salt cod with summer peppers - loved the fried, battered, warm salt cod.  The summer peppers, nepitella seeds, and amaranth brightened the flavors and colors, but I wasn't as big a fan of the chilled tomato soup poured over it.
3. BEST HALIBUT EVER - perfectly crusted top with a subtle oyster vinaigrette, amazing greens underneath that was an emulsion of blended coriander and onion, not too rich.  Each bite made me sad because I knew there was less and less left.
4. Roasted quail - tender, flavoful, with richness cut by blackberries, and sous vide corn so fresh you could smell it.
5. Peach and lovage sorbet - lovage is reminiscent of celery, and the accompanying non-traditional cannoli reminds me of a Chinese sweet egg roll with a lighter cream inside.
6. Fromage blanc - steamed cheesecake with fresh figs - a nice variation on a normally heavier dessert.

Last, we ended with a complimentary beignet with chocolate sauce.  I know lots of people complain about portions, but for me, with the variety and pacing and extra dishes, the meal was well timed and well portioned.  The tasting menu had a good progression from lighter bites to a richer quail, with desserts that weren't too rich.  I thought it featured local, seasonal items well without being too overpowering with sauces.

At $125 (split the bottle of prosecco with a friend, tasting menu, 4% healthy SF tax, tip), I thought it was a very reasonable price for an exceptional dining experience.
author: Marilyn T.

description: Fine dining in jeans with T-Rex playing in the background. I just love this place. Between fantastic, friendly service, unbelieveable flavors, and an atmosphere that feels young and vibrant, I am right at home. Eat here. Try everything. Come back again. Perfect for a date, drink, or rad little treat.
author: Modern S.

description:
Credit to be given.

This group has put together a great concept in a super swell space.  They have taken a huge space and made it into several smaller spaces to have separate experiences.
You will find a hip well-designed resta with a beautiful open kitchen, a fabulous salumeria that makes the level of sandwich that all other sandwiches strive to be and   soon they are going to unveil a bar.  I love the location and know that it is going to serve all the folks living around there.
You can tell that a lot of heart and soul has gone into this project and you will be the benefactor of it.
I think the best part is that they could have just done a safe formulaic berretta or starbelly and they did not.   They are pushing the envelope and presenting the mission with more complex, higher quality and more thoughtful food than most of the restaurants that are opening these days.  Think Commonwealth meats Frances meats Sons and Daughters.
author: Kate S.

description: Best Brunch in town. I made reservations for the following weekends, so i don't mind sharing the information now. Only bad thing is that they don't have liquor license, so cocktails are a little weird. Other than that, perfection. I like the music the food and the service. Don't come too late if you want to enjoy the oysters, and don't skip their bread pudding.
author: Too M.

description: Good, but overpriced and a little precious. Otherwise, some interesting flavor combinations, and a nice space.
author: Mark P.

description:
Unfortunately, Central Kitchen was a big disappointment for me.  I LOVE Flour and Water. So when this place was annouced to be open, I couldn't wait to try it.  I had a few important people in town and took them to Central Kitchen. I thought I was offering a treat. Unfortunately, we were all very disappointed. I should have known better than to bring important guests to a new restaurant.

To be fair, the service was ok and I like the ambiance.  The food was not up to par. We even decided to splurge and order to 5 course tasting menu for the table.  To clarify, I am not a big fan of molecular gastronomy.  If you like it, maybe this is the place for you. However, I've tried similar style of cooking at other restaurants around town and the outcome of the food (aesthetic and flavor) turned out better.  This time I think Central Kitchen tried a bit too hard to be what they are not.

Yes, I also do agree with the reviews that says $$$ menu for tiny portions.  But that's was not the deal breaker for me.  It was the presentation and the taste.

Foam is cool, but not after 4 course of foaminess.

Unfortunately, I would not go back and I don't recommend it.  

Sorry.
author: Tell-it-like-it-is M.

description: Great space. Great people.  Lousy food.  The mixed pork dish amounts to little more than an assortment of lukewarm ham and sausage, colored by asparagus and other greens.  For $27, this bland plate just isn't making the grade, even under the guise of creativity.  Wishing I was at Marlowe or Slow Club tonight.
author: Peter S.

description: Spectacular. We had the Huevos (light, fluffy eggs expertly seasoned with chile and a celery salsa) and the eggs Benedict with fried chicken, both of which were delicious. You're definitely missing out if you don't try brunch at Central Kitchen!
author: K. T.

description: I must admit, when i first heard the flour+water ppl opened Central kitchen, i got very excited and could not really wait to see the place and all the wonders that it could present. Unfortunately conclusion is over-pricey and the food is not as good as flour+water at all. They tried to create a chef's tasting menu but i think they need to work more on that.
author: Beril Y.

description:
spotty cuisine and service, yet expensive ... hm

i've gone now four times: twice for brunch, twice for dinner. only 1/4 times did the food delight from head to toe -- at christmas eve dinner, and i had high hopes for more, but -- alas, my last experience delivered soggy entrees. they made our table wait 35 minutes beyond our reservation and then comped us nothing. the dessert and appetizers proved quite nice. but the service did not make us or the meal feel special. then the bill arrived. i think i'll try elsewhere next time i'd like a chic meal.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Been there last night with 4 friends. 
We had an amazing time. Service was flawless and the food was yummy and creative at the same time. Our waitress was beyond sweet. She was kind enough to offer us little treats, allows us to taste several wines until we decided which one we prefer and finally ordering a main dish that was not included in the dinner menu but only in the tasting menu. 5 stars for the service.
Food was very good and since I was the one who proposed the place I was happy to see my guests happy and smiling. 
We had:
APPETIZERS:
- chicken liver mousse with mulled wine & mustard seed (out of this world), 
- shaved kohlrabi with pickled chard, black sesame & pork belly (very good)
MAIN:
- seared duck breast with coal roasted rutabaga, apple & walnut (divine)
- roasted pork with lentils, clam & leek relish & garlic puree (very tasty)
- cod. black cioppino. saffron. ( orgasmic !! ) (that one was only in the tasting menu)
DESSERT
- walnut. brown butter. parsnip milk. (excellent)
- white chocolate. milk chocolate. dark chocolate (very good).

Summing the experience:
If you love good quality food without the pretentiousness of the SF "scene" restos,  this is your place. Real food, real people, real smiles...and an amazing ambiance.
FOOD : 5 stars
SERVICE : CAN I GIVE 6 stars ?
AMBIANCE: 5 stars
WINE LIST : 3 stars
author: Marios B.

description: Worth the trip! The decor was inviting and the staff and food amazing! This trip to San Francisco and  Yountville was all about food and wine. Central Kitchen did not disappoint!
author: Tom E.

description: This place was great awhile back--today, however - not so much. Went in for brunch and all of our brunch courses arrived cold. Second, the leftovers we couldn't finish (cold brunch food wasn't too appealing) was dropped off in a bag in the center of the table, which awkwardly stopped our conversations in mid-sentence. Third, the check was dropped off before we were asked if we wanted anything else - again, strangely - dropped off in the center of the table, not discretely off to the side like most restaurants are prone to do. Fourth - the damn hipster music that they insist on blaring on full volume is really a bit obnoxious. It's pretty clear that the music was for the staff, and without any regard for the comfort level of the clientele. To the staff of Central Kitchen: Reality Check 101--brush up on your service levels, take a few hospitality classes, and for chrissakes - serve the food hot.
author: Angelo S.

description:
I want to start off by saying that this place is in a great location.  Parking wasn't hard (San Francisco standards) and it's easy getting here if you don't live in SF.  Second, for those that care about service (not everyone does), this place rates high.  Everyone was very friendly, they brought out dishes fast, and the staff knew what every dish tasted like.  This last part is key.  (Come on... you know you don't like going to places where the waiter is a vegetarian and hasn't tasted anything on the meat side of the menu.)  Nothing against vegetarians, but I want my wait staff to describe what it tastes like.  By the way, if I go to Greens, I want my wait staff to be a vegetarian. 

Now lets talk about the most important part, the food.  Overall, the food was very good.  Together we got the rutabaga bites.  Very yummy.  I couldn't stop easting them.  They were fried crispy on the outside and inside was a soft rutabaga cloud.  Yum!  My wife, as usual, got two appetizers... the Hen Confit and Yellow-tail Crudo.  She loved both.  The Hen Confit was crispy outside and perfectly done chicken meat on the inside - tender and moist.  The Yellow-tail was one of the best dishes here. The slices of fish were slightly thicker than you would find at a sushi restaurant and the quality was very high.  I also really liked the citrus (I thought it was tangerine, but my wife says it was grapefruit) scattered around the plate.  Lastly, the roasted pork was my only disappointment.  The flavors were perfect, the skin was really nice, but the meat was much too tough.  However, the bright spot was that the vegetables and sauces on the plate complemented the meat perfectly.  It was really tasty.  But again, it seems like everything was lined up except the texture.  Bummer.  This is one place that I hope to come back to find that the dish has improved and I hope they knock my socks off.  

Oh... I almost forgot... the most important part... the wine. (feel free to call me a wino)   This place is a find!  They have a lot of a great wines on their list, and most of them are below $50. (You gotta love it)  We ended up getting an awesome Greek red wine from Saint George.  $30ish for a bottle.  Great wine for the price! 

Looking forward to going back to try something good... Just hoping their pork is tender.
author: Ryan A.

description: Wish I could give a higher rating but I just didn't think the food was very good and it was way too expensive. Expectations were pretty high since it's a sister restaurant to flour and water (which is also overpriced and too expensive but at least the food is good). We started with the chicken liver mousse, which seems pretty popular but I found it was just average. We also ordered the deviled egg toast, which was the one thing that I did enjoy. We shared the saffron spaghetti, just average. Entrees were a big letdown and they were pricy. The pork dish was soooo fatty, like only a few bites of pork and 75% inedible. I'm not exaggerating and I'm not a person that needs extremely lean meats. The other pasta dish on the menu with clams was bizarre. It had decent flavor but texture was terrible and it looked like soggy tortilla chips. Blah. Dessert looked good but we didn't want to try any by this point. Wine list is great, a good variety from places around the world. Service was friendly. Bill was 185$ with tax and tip, wayyyy too much for what we were served. Don't think I'll return.
author: Kate N.

description:
We were suppose to go to Flour+ Water but couldn't find a table. Central Kitchen off we go. 

We weren't prepared for the price tag that came with the place because we just wanted a "casual" dining experience and didn't want to do the tasting menu (which is actually very reasonable at around 90 bucks each). We ended up sharing couple plates of first and second course and loveeed it. 

I remember the quail dish and the calamari dish was delicious and the pork belly that followed was cooked to perfection.  Definitely want to come back for a special occasion.
author: Yale S.

description: Great food and service. Splits are easy and they time plates so you can have a nice relaxing dinner. We spent over two delightful hours enjoying ourselves. Food is local, sustainable and really delicious. I would recommend this very highly.
author: Alan G.

description:
This IS as good as it gets. Went here for dinner last night and I'm still letting the wonderful experience sink in...

The ambience, service and food are truly worthwhile. A beautifully designed upscale restaurant with down to earth, attentive service and imaginative, delicately created food. Central Kitchen tops all the trendy, foodie restaurants in this city and should be on your SF bucket list. Seriously.
author: Brynn R.

description: wonderful space, delectable food, limited wine list... can't wait to see if there are improvements!
author: Kerstin A.

description: Very innovative, fresh and tasty dishes. A bit pricy considering the quantity of food served. Except that, amazing experience in a stylish but very laid back place in SF. Loved it!
author: Marie C.

description: Our party of four had reservation at 1:30 on 02/23. We were there 15 minutes earlier and were told that we would be seated shortly. 20 minutes later still the same answer and no specifics. In the meantime they took a party of 4 that was late for their seating. No one offered us a glass of water and when I asked about a complimentary glass of wine they gave me a wine list. Finally at 2PM we decided to leave and asked to cancel our reservation. No restaurant, maybe with a few exceptions, is worth waiting that long. I understand that they do not want to waste even a single seat and want to have full house but it is bad PR and they should not take reservations especially through Open Table. They should switch to first come, first served.
author: Ryszard D.

description: Amazing food, though definitely rich. Absolutely gorgeous space & impeccable service. Very high prices. Great spot for a special dinner but a different vibe & experience from their sister restaurant Flour & Water, a bit less accessible & a bit more formal. Can't wait for their brunch which starts in another 6 months or so.
author: sarahjane s.

description: The fine dining version of sister restaurant Flour & Water. Richer sauces, smaller portions, higher prices. But tastes just as good. Better for a date than for solo dining.
author: Kokoe J.

description: Nice atmosphere and the wait staff was helpful when needed.  The food was well prepared, but nothing wow'd me in presetation or quality.  The menu lacks depth, has great preparations and local ingredients but needs more choices even within the same ingredients.
author: Mike C.

description:
Service was very nice and helpful.

Food was good not great.  

Prices were high to very high (dinner for 2 - $240, including a $50 bottle of wine)

Basically just ok; no reason to make a return trip even if the prices were better.
author: John B.

description: What a true experience! I had to wait to eat until 9 pm but it was all worth it. The flavors of each dish is so fresh, it feels like you picked it from the garden right outside. The server was very engaging and added to the overall experience. I want to come back and try the tasting menu next time. You have to have the whole table experience it together. I can't wait to go back!
author: Lisa M.

description:
The space is so unique and well designed, I guess like everything Paxton Gate does.
We have been here so many times and I seriously cannot get enough. The menu options, presentations, and even portions are more than pleasing and just what we needed in SF to represent California cuisine. There is so much thought put into the conception then the execution of each dish. The vibe is Mission hip casual which makes for great people watching but a relaxing experience.
The Sunday brunch is pretty new and a blessing to this neighborhood.
And honestly, the price is right...look who's cooking for you and where the ingredients are being sourced from...top notch menu=fair prices for the quality of the experience.
author: david r.

description: I took my grandmother for her birthday and the experience was wonderful. Other than a bland potato and leek soup, the food was excellent. The service was attentive but not hovering. Try the potatoes with mushroom as aioli and the pork with spiced pear.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I was hoping this place would be up to par with Flour and Water, but something went terribly wrong here. Many complain that the portion sizes are too small. That doesn't bother me IF the food is good. Unfortunately, the flavors just weren't there.  I got the tasting menu and was disappointed by most of the dishes. The only thing that really blew me away was the dessert.
author: Ronnie H.

description: Hosted a holiday dinner for clients at Central Kitchen this week.  We did the chefs menu and appetizers and I was very pleased.  The appetizers were outstanding (meats, cheeses and a few passed items).   Dinner was very good.  Most of the courses were excellent.  A few missed the mark a little bit but overall the food was very good.  We drank some good wine although frankly they could stand to expand the wine selections and they ran out of a few bottles that we wanted to try.  Desserts were excellent.  Atmosphere is very cool and modern.  Service was excellent.  Overall I highly recommend Central Kitchen.
author: Matt S.

description: Surprised to see all the three star ratings here? Everything about my evening here was perfect. Wonderful food and wine, great service and atmosphere. Its great as is but I imagine will only improve with time.
author: tex w.

description: Lovely patio, polite and helpful front staff and servers, perfectly limited menu so that my Sunday-morning-sleepyhead didn't have to deal with too many choices. Just a great brunch experience here with friends. Especial love for the fried chicken benedict because of the perfect textures & spice.
author: Ellen A.

description: Truely lovely new spot. It's the perfect mix of fine dining principles, sustainable sourcing, casual but chic atmosphere, attentive friendly service and beautifuly designed space. 5 stars all the way. Have set a standing date with the husband to come back soon and often. Well done Michael Gaines.
author: Lindsey W.

description: Nice ambience, but the food was just ok. Small plates were good, however the large plates were a disappointment for all 6 people in our party.  The pork with stone fruit was a plate-full of fat. I couldn't eat it. I don't think I'll be back anytime soon.
author: Al K.

description:
Amazing food and amazing service. Waitress was so attentive and helped with explaining and recommending items. The food was so delicious and was such an interesting journey fornthebpalette. Smoked trout, sardines and hen were exquisite lay made. Fresh flavours, surprising, but  also rustic. Exactly what California food should be. Extra fresh ingredients and perfect execution.
This is now my favorite restaurant in sf. Will definitely be back many times!
author: Jumana M.

description:
2 stars for the food.  4 stars for ambiance and service.

Really wanted to like this place.  Very cool restaurant design-wise.  Servers were attentive and friendly although they did bring one course (pea and goat milk curd salad) to our table before the "walnut foam" was ready, which eventually arrived and was more like cream than a foam.  Fortunately I had already eaten half of it, because it was much better without the foam/cream.
